title: Staggs v. State
description: The sole issue we address is whether the trial court erred in denying Petitioner Post-Conviction Relief where counsel acted under an actual conflict of interest.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Daniel V. Staggs, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26297
Submitted February 14, 2007 - Filed April 2, 2007Â Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Frank L. Eppes, of Eppes & Plumbee, PA, of Greenville, for Petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Karen C. Ratigan, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the denial of Post-Conviction Relief (PCR) to Petitioner, Daniel Staggs.Â  The sole issue we need address is whether trial counsel had a conflict of interest in representing Staggs in his trial for murder, while simultaneously representing Staggsâ€™ father, mother and brother on accessory after the fact charges.[1]Â  We find that he did and, accordingly, we reverse.
FACTS
Staggs was arrested for the murder of Daniel L. Grier.Â  It appears Grier was shot after he and Staggs were engaged in a â€œroad rageâ€ type incident in Greenville. Â Staggs was represented by attorney Michael A. Devine.[2]Â  Subsequent to Staggsâ€™ arrest, his father, mother and brother were charged as accessories after the fact.Â  Thereafter, Devine undertook to represent his Â father, mother and brother while simultaneously representing Staggs on the murder charge.Â  Â Â 
Staggs did not testify at trial based upon counselâ€™s recommendation.Â  Counsel also declined to offer the testimony of Staggsâ€™ family members at trial.Â  Staggs was convicted of murder and possession of a firearm during commission of a violent crime and sentenced to life plus five years for the weapons charge.Â  
Staggs filed for PCR, contending counsel had a conflict of interest in representing him together with his family members.Â  The PCR court denied relief.Â  We reverse.
DISCUSSION
To establish a violation of the Sixth Amendment right to effective counsel due to a conflict of interest arising from multiple representation, a defendant who did not object at trial must show an actual conflict of interest adversely affected his attorneyâ€™s performance.Â  Cuyler v. Sullivan, 446 U.S. 335 (1980); Fuller v. State, 347 S.C. 630, 557 S.E.2d 664 (2001); Thomas v. State, 346 S.C. 140, 551 S.E.2d 254 (2001).Â  An actual conflict of interest occurs where an attorney owes a duty to a party whose interests are adverse to the defendantâ€™s.Â  Id.Â  In Thomas, this Court held that a defendant who shows that a conflict of interest actually affected the adequacy of his representation need not demonstrate prejudice to obtain relief.Â Â  
Staggs asserts Devine had an actual conflict inasmuch as the interests of his mother, father, and brother were adverse to his own. Â We agree.Â Â Â  
At PCR, Staggs testified Devine advised him he did not want him taking the stand in order to preserve the right to final closing argument.Â  However, Staggsâ€™ sister-in-law, who is married to his brother Yancey, testified that Devine told her he was not going to allow Staggs to testify because â€œhe say he cannot testify because he was representing all four of us. Â And if Daniel said, if anything, it could hurt us.Â  If we said anything, it could hurt Daniel.Â  It was in our best interest that nobody said anything about anybody.â€Â  Staggsâ€™ father Billy testified similarly at PCR that Devine had told him to persuade Staggs not to testify because it might hurt their case.Â  
It is clear from the testimony of Staggsâ€™ father and sister-in-law that Devine had an actual conflict of interest and that the conflict adversely affected his performance.Â  Under Fuller and Thomas, Staggs is clearly entitled to relief.Â  Accordingly, the order of the PCR court denying Staggs relief is reversed and the matter remanded for a new trial.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Although Staggs also raised the issue of trial counselâ€™s failure to preserve issues relating to the trial courtâ€™s self-defense and manslaughter charges, we need not address those issues in light of our remand for a new trial.
[2] Â Staggs also had co-counsel; however, Devine was lead counsel.Â  Devine has since been indefinitely suspended from the practice of law.Â Â  In the Matter of Devine, 345 S.C. 633, 550 S.E.2d 308 (2001).Â

title: City of Camden v. Fairfield Electric Cooperative, Inc.
description: At issue in this appeal is whether Fairfield Electric Cooperative, Inc. has legal authority to provide electric service to a newly constructed Loweâ€™s Store located in an area recently annexed by the City of Camden.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        City of Camden, Respondent,
        v.
        Fairfield Electric Cooperative, Inc., Appellant, 
        and
        Loweâ€™s Home Centers Of Camden, South Carolina, Intervenor, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26298
Heard January 30, 2007 - Filed April 2, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Marcus A. Manos and Manton M. Grier, Jr., both of Nexsen Pruet LLC, of Columbia, for Primary Appellant Fairfield Electric Cooperative.
        Thomas H. Pope, III, of Newberry, for Secondary Appellant Loweâ€™s Home Centers.
        James M. Brailsford, III, of Edisto Island, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  Â This is an appeal from an order of the circuit court granting the City of Camden summary judgment and holding that Fairfield Electric Cooperative, Inc. has no legal authority to provide electric service to a newly constructed Loweâ€™s Store located in an area recently annexed by city.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
This case involves a 12.981 acre tract of land, originally located just outside the city limits of Camden, SC, which was owned by Town and Country, Inc.Â  In early 2002, Town and Country began negotiating to sell the property to Loweâ€™s for construction of a Loweâ€™s store.Â  In the summer of 2002, Town and Country requested Fairfield Electric Cooperative to install a security light on the property.[1]Â  Fairfield installed the security light on July 29, 2002.Â  Thereafter, on September 10, 2002, Town and Country requested the City annex the property.Â  
On September 3, 2002, prior to purchasing the property, Loweâ€™s wrote a letter to Town and Country, indicating that it had chosen Fairfield as its electric supplier for the proposed store in the â€œunassignedâ€ area.Â  Fairfield notified the City of this letter, and indicated it had been serving the premises and would â€œhonor their request to serve this new store.â€Â  On September 23, 2002, Camdenâ€™s City Manager responded that Camden would not give Fairfield permission to serve any new customers in the current City limits, or any area which might be annexed in the future, stating, â€œ[w]hen the site on which Loweâ€™s proposes to build its new store becomes a part of the City, the City Council will assert its legal right to be the power provider, regardless of the customerâ€™s preference.â€Â  
Camden annexed the property on October 8, 2002.Â  Town and Country thereafter sold the parcel to Loweâ€™s on January 6, 2003, and Loweâ€™s began to clear and grade the tract to begin construction of the store.Â  Both the security light placed on the property by Fairfield Electric and the Cityâ€™s sewer easement were temporarily disconnected during construction.Â  After completion of construction, Fairfield continued to provide the new Loweâ€™s store with electricity,Â  and the City of Camden brought this action pursuant to S. C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-49-250(1) for an order compelling Fairfield to cease and desist.Â Â  The circuit court ruled Fairfield had no legal authority to provide electricity to the new Loweâ€™s store.Â  Fairfield appeals.
ISSUE
Did the circuit court err in ruling Fairfield was without authority to service the new Loweâ€™s store?
DISCUSSION
Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-29-240, a rural electric cooperative generally has the power to sell and distribute electricity only in rural areas, i.e., those with a population under 2500.Â  Carolina Power and Light v. Town of Pageland, 321 S.C. 538, 471 S.E.2d 137 (1996).Â  There are two exceptions to this rule contained in South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 33-49-250(1), to wit: 

  1) a cityâ€™s act of incorporating or annexing into a city or town an area in which the cooperative is serving shall constitute the consent of the governing body of such city or town for the cooperative to continue serving all premises then being served and to serve additional premises within such area until such time as the governing body of the city or town shall direct otherwise, and 
  2) the right of a cooperative to continue to serve in a city or town in which it is the principal supplier of electricity shall not be affected by the subsequent growth of such town beyond a population of two thousand five hundred persons.

(emphasis supplied).Â  The purpose of the exceptions is to â€œprevent the ouster of co-ops from areas they have historically served due to population growth or annexation.â€ Duke Power Laurens Elec. Co-op., Inc., 344 S.C. 101, 105, 543 S.E.2d 560, 562 (Ct.App.2001).Â  
It is undisputed here that the second exception does not apply as Fairfield is not the principal supplier of the disputed area.Â  Accordingly, the sole issue before us is whether the Loweâ€™s store was a â€œpremises then being servedâ€ at the time of annexation so as to come within the first exception.Â  We find that it does not. 
The term â€œpremisesâ€ is not defined in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-49-10 et seq., the Electric Cooperative Act.Â  The circuit court therefore looked to the definition of â€œpremisesâ€ contained in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 58-27-610 (2) of the Territorial Assignments Act of 1969.Â Â  That section defines â€œpremisesâ€ as follows:

  the building, structure or facility to which electricity is being or is to be furnished;Â  provided, that two or more buildings, structures or facilities which are located on one tract or contiguous tracts of land and are utilized by one electric consumer for farming, business, commercial, industrial, institutional or governmental purposes, shall together constitute one â€œpremises,â€ except that any such building, structure or facility shall not, together with any other building, structure or facility, constitute one â€œpremisesâ€ if the electric service to it is separately metered and the charges for such service are calculated independently of charges for service to any other building, structure or facility.

The circuit court ruled the security light placed on the unimproved lot owned by Town and Country did not constitute a â€œbuilding, structure or facilityâ€ to which electricity was being furnished, such that it was not a â€œpremises then being servedâ€ pursuant to the statute and therefore did not come within this exception.Â  Fairfield asserts the circuit courtâ€™s reliance upon this definition of â€œpremiseâ€ is misplaced inasmuch as the Territorial Assignments Act was enacted some six years after passage of the Electric Cooperative Act.Â  Accordingly, it contends the Legislature could not have intended for this definition of â€œpremisesâ€ to apply in the context of Â§ 33-49-250(1).Â  We disagree.Â  We find the circuit court properly looked to the definition of â€œpremisesâ€ as set forth in Â§ 58-27-610(2), and the court properly applied that definition.Â  
There is a presumption that the legislature has knowledge of previous legislation when later statutes are enacted concerning related subjects.Â  State v. McKnight, 352 S.C. 635, 648, 576 S.E.2d 168, 174 (2003); Berkebile v. Outen, 311 S.C. 50, 426 S.E.2d 760 (1993).Â  Accordingly, the Legislature is presumed to have had knowledge of the definition of â€œpremisesâ€ contained in Â§ 58-67-210.[2]
Fairfield contends the trial courtâ€™s holding will effectively require continuous ownership of a premises, and prohibit cooperatives from serving premises they have historically served when those premises changes ownership.Â  We disagree with this contention.
As noted in City of Newberry, â€œalthough the annexation exception also implies consent for cooperatives to serve additional premises, i.e., new customers, within an annexed area, the statute expressly limits a cooperativeâ€™s authority to provide new or increased service by allowing it only until such time as the governing body of the city or town shall direct otherwise. . . .â€Â  352 S.C. at 576, 575 S.E.2d at 86.Â  It is clear that a co-operative may continue serving customers due to a change in ownership; the statute merely requires the coop to be serving a building, structure, or facility at the time of annexation.Â  
Finally, we decline to hold that the security light placed by Town and Country is a â€œstructureâ€ within the contemplation of Â§ 33-49-250.Â  Such a holding would allow cooperative providers to effectively circumvent the statutory scheme set up by the Legislature simply by placing security lights in any areas in which it has distribution lines.Â  Such a result is untenable.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s ruling that Fairfield Electric Cooperative is without authority to serve the recently annexed Loweâ€™s property.
AFFIRMED. 
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  At the time, Fairfield had a distribution line which crossed the property, and the city of Camden had a sewer easement.Â  
[2]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-49-250(1) was rewritten by 2004 Act No. 179, Â§ 5, effective February 19, 2004 and now provides that an electric cooperative has power to:

  to generate, manufacture, purchase, acquire, accumulate, and transmit electric energy and to distribute, sell, supply, and dispose of electric energy to . . . persons. . . provided that the premises to be served must be located in an area a cooperative is permitted to serve pursuant to Section 58-27-610 through Section 58-27-670.

Section 58-27-610 is the section of the Electric Cooperative Act which specifically defines â€œpremises.â€

title: State v. Slater
description: Lord Byron Slater was convicted of murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.  The court of appeals reversed Slaterâ€™s conviction and remanded the case for a new trial finding that Slater was entitled to a self-defense charge.  See State v. Slater, 360 S.C. 487, 602 S.E.2d 90 (2004).   The State appealed and this Court granted a Writ of Certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Petitioner
v.
Lord Byron Slater, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Charleston County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26299
Heard March 7, 2007 - Filed April 9, 2007Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Petitioner.
Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of the South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: Lord Byron Slater (â€œSlaterâ€) was convicted of murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Slater appealed his conviction and sentence to the court of appeals alleging that the trial court committed reversible error in failing to charge the jury on self-defense.Â  The court of appeals reversed Slaterâ€™s conviction and remanded the case for a new trial.Â  See State v. Slater, 360 S.C. 487, 602 S.E.2d 90 (2004).Â Â  The State appealed and this Court granted a Writ of Certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision.Â  We reverse.
Factual / Procedural Background
Slater attended a step show at North Charleston High School in February 2001.Â  After the step show ended, Slater went outside and began talking with some of the girls at the school.Â  During this time, Slater noticed a gathering around a truck.Â  Slater went to his car, retrieved a gun, and walked toward the truck.Â  According to Slater, he initially retrieved his gun with the intention of shooting it into the air to cause a commotion.Â  Slater alleges, however, that he changed his mind and returned to his car where three of his friends were waiting for him. Moments later, Slater noticed that another disturbance was taking place in an adjacent parking lot.Â  Carrying his gun with him, Slater went to the adjacent parking lot to investigate.Â Â Â  
In the second parking lot, a robbery was unfolding where the victim was on the ground being assaulted by five men.Â  Slater knew neither the victim nor his attackers.Â  Slater testified that he walked up to the robbery and surprised one of the attackers.Â  According to Slaterâ€™s testimony, the man turned around and pointed a gun toward him.Â  Slater quickly turned away from the man and started running back toward his car.Â  Slater also testified that as he ran, he heard a gunshot and responded by shooting his own gun behind him.Â  As Slater and his friends left the scene, Slater continued shooting in the air as the car pulled away and the victim lay dying on the ground from several gunshot wounds. Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Slater and his three friends drove to Slaterâ€™s house, where Slater left the gun.Â  The four then went back to the parking lot where the shooting had occurred.Â  On the way, the police stopped them and searched the car but did not find a weapon.
Early the next morning, detectives from the city of North Charleston went to Slaterâ€™s residence to arrest him for the murder of the victim.Â  Following the arrest, they obtained a search warrant for Slaterâ€™s house.Â  The detectives recovered various ammunitions from Slaterâ€™s yard and from inside his house, including two guns, bullets, and shell casings.
At the police station, Slater told the police that he had not shot anyone.Â  However, a ballistics expert testified at trial that the bullets which fatally wounded the victim came from Slaterâ€™s gun, as did the ones retrieved from the crime scene.Â  Additionally, numerous witnesses placed Slater at the crime scene with a gun.Â  At trial, Slater himself admitted to shooting his gun, but insisted that he did not mean to shoot anyone.Â  
Before the case was submitted to the jury, Slater requested a jury charge on the law of self-defense.Â  The trial court declined Slaterâ€™s request on the grounds that the evidence did not support the charge.Â  Despite the trial courtâ€™s refusal to include the jury charge on self-defense, the court included a manslaughter option in the jury charge.Â  The jury convicted Slater of murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, and Slater appealed.
At the court of appeals, Slater alleged that the trial court erred in failing to charge the jury on the law of self-defense. The court of appeals agreed and reversed Slaterâ€™s conviction and sentence.Â  We granted the Stateâ€™s Writ of Certiorari, and the State raises the following issue for review:

Â Did the court of appeals err in finding that Slater was entitled to a charge on self-defense? 

Law / Analysis
The State argues that the court of appeals erred in finding that Slater was entitled to a self-defense charge.Â  We agree.
A self-defense charge is not required unless it is supported by the evidence. State v. Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 280, 440 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1994).Â  To establish self-defense in South Carolina, four elements must be present: (1) the defendant must be without fault in bringing on the difficulty; (2) the defendant must have been in actual imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury, or he must have actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) if his defense is based upon his belief of imminent danger, defendant must show that a reasonably prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage would have entertained the belief that he was actually in imminent danger and that the circumstances were such as would warrant a person of ordinary prudence, firmness, and courage to strike the fatal blow in order to save himself from serious bodily harm or the loss of his life; and (4) the defendant had no other probable means of avoiding the danger.Â  State v. Bryant, 336 S.C. 340, 344-45, 520 S.E.2d 319, 321-22 (1999).Â Â  â€œIf there is any evidence in the record from which it could reasonably be inferred that the defendant acted in self-defense, the defendant is entitled to instructions on the defense, and the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to do so is reversible error.â€Â  State v. Muller, 282 S.C. 10, 10, 316 S.E.2d 409, 409 (1984).
In the instant case, Slater fails to meet the first requirement for the self-defense charge: specifically, Slater was not without fault in bringing on the difficulty.Â  â€œAny act of the accused in violation of law and reasonably calculated to produce the occasion amounts to bringing on the difficulty and bars the right to assert self-defense.â€Â  Bryant, 336 S.C. at 345, 520 S.E.2d at 322.Â  In the instant case, the record clearly reflects that Slater approached an altercation that was already underway with a loaded weapon by his side.Â  Such activity could be reasonably calculated to bring the difficulty that arose in this case.Â  
Additionally, the uncontradicted evidence illustrates that Slater acted in violation of the law by carrying a weapon.Â  The court of appeals relied on State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 513 S.E.2d 104 (1999), to support its finding that Slaterâ€™s unlawful possession of a weapon did not foreclose the possibility of asserting self-defense.Â  Although we agree that â€œthe mere unlawful possession of a firearm, with nothing more, does not automatically bar a self-defense charge,â€ we reject the position that the unlawful possession of a weapon could never constitute an unlawful activity which would preclude the assertion of self-defense.Â Â  
 Burriss, which deals with the defense of accident, is instructive in the instant case.Â  In Burriss, this Court discussed the use of an accident defense where the defendant unlawfully possessed a gun.Â Â  Burriss maintained that he was lawfully armed in self-defense when the gun accidentally fired.Â  Id. at 259, 513 S.E.2d at 106.Â Â  Because a defendant must be acting lawfully to use the defense of accident, we discussed whether a person in unlawful possession of a weapon may lawfully arm himself in self-defense.Â  Id. at 262, 513 S.E.2d at 108.Â  Clarifying an ambiguity in this Courtâ€™s prior case law, we noted that where the defendantâ€™s unlawful possession of a weapon is merely incidental to the defendantâ€™s lawful act of arming himself in self-defense, the unlawful possession of the weapon will not prevent the use of an accident defense.Â  Id. at 262 n.5, 513 S.E.2d at 108 n.5.Â  We further explained, however, that the unlawful possession of a firearm can, under some circumstances, constitute an unlawful activity so as to preclude an accident defense if the weapon is the proximate cause of the killing.Â  Id.Â  Although Burriss takes the additional step of applying the rule in the context of accident, the analysis is equally applicable in determining if a defendant in unlawful possession of a weapon is entitled to a charge on self-defense.Â  
Here, Slaterâ€™s unlawful possession of the weapon was the proximate cause of the homicide. Â Slater was not merely in unlawful possession of a weapon; he carried the cocked weapon, in open view, into an already violent attack in which he had no prior involvement.Â  Slaterâ€™s actions, including the unlawful possession of the weapon, proximately caused the exchange of gunfire, and ultimately the death of the victim.Â  Consequently, Slater fails to meet the requirement that he be without fault in bringing on the difficulty and may not avail himself of a charge on self-defense.
Accordingly, the trial court correctly found that Slater was not entitled to a self-defense charge and the court of appeals erred in reversing Slaterâ€™s conviction on this ground. 
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse the court of appealsâ€™ decision reversing the trial courtâ€™s exclusion of a jury charge on the law of self-defense.
 MOORE and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in result only.

title: In the Matter of Kenneth S. Roper
description: In this opinion, Kenneth S. Roper is publicly reprimanded for failing to properly oversee a closing, including the execution of related documents, and providing false or misleading information on a document required by the laws of this State.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Kenneth S. Roper, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26300
Submitted March 12, 2007 - Filed April 9, 2007Â  

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Joseph P. Turner, Jr., Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Kenneth Scott Roper, of Liberty, Pro Se.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and consents to the issuance of a public reprimand.Â  We accept the Agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.
Facts
Respondent closed an equity line of credit for a client and the clientâ€™s wife.Â  The client informed respondent his wife was unable to attend the closing, after which respondent allowed the client to leave the closing and take the documents home to have his wife sign them.Â  Respondent had no reason to question the clientâ€™s honesty or trustworthiness, as respondent and the client had known each other since childhood, attended church together, the client was a law enforcement officer and member of city council, and respondent had worked with the client when respondent was an assistant solicitor and, later, a city attorney.Â  However, the clientâ€™s wife alleged she had no knowledge of the loan and that the client forged her name to the documents when he left respondentâ€™s office.Â  
Respondent signed as witness to the signature of the clientâ€™s wife on the closing documents despite the fact that he had not witnessed her signature.Â  In doing so, respondent gave false and misleading information on a document, record, report or form required by the laws of this state.Â  A member of respondentâ€™s staff notarized the documents despite the fact that all of the signatures had not occurred in her presence.
Law
Respondent admits that his conduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (a lawyer shall not violate the Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding the professional conduct of lawyers) and Rule 7(a)(6) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the oath of office taken upon admission to practice law in this state).Â  In addition, respondent admits he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (a lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 4.1(a) (in the course of representing a client a lawyer shall not knowingly make a false statement of material fact or law to a third person); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).
Conclusion
We find respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand. Accordingly, we accept the Agreement and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: Key Corporate Capital v. County of Beaufort
description: The Court held that the plain language of the applicable tax sale statute did not entitle successful bidders to the interest earned on the purchase price when the tax sales were voided by the County.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Key Corporate Capital, Inc., National Tax Assistance Corporation, TransAm Tax Certificate Corp. d/b/a Destiny 98TD, Advantage 99TD, TA Escrow 97 and Destiny 98,
Respondents,
v.
County of Beaufort, Treasurer of Beaufort County, and Tax Collector of Beaufort County,
Petitioners.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Thomas Kemmerlin, Master in Equity

Opinion No.Â  26302
Heard December 7, 2006 - Filed April 9, 2007Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
David S. Black, and Mary B. Lohr, both of Howell Gibson & Hughes, of Beaufort, for Petitioners.
James H. Ritchie, Jr., of Holcombe, Bomar, Gunn & Bradford, of Spartanburg, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â Â Â Â Â Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in Key Corp. Capital, Inc. v. County of Beaufort, 360 S.C. 513, 602 S.E.2d 104 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We reverse.
FACTS
In 1998 and 1999, respondents Key Corporate Capital, Inc., National Tax Assistance Corporation, and TransAm Tax Certificate Corporation purchased several properties at Beaufort County tax sales. Â The Beaufort County Treasurer subsequently voided twelve of these tax sales.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-150 (2000).[1]  
The parties stipulated to the following facts:Â  (1) the tax sales were voided because the Treasurer discovered â€œerrors, oversights, and/or miscommunications within the Beaufort County offices;â€ (2) the tax sales were not voided â€œdue to any actions or inactions on the part ofâ€ respondents; (3) the tax sales would have been set aside by a court if the Treasurer had not voided them;Â  (4) the County retained the purchase price on each property for at least 28 days, and for three of the properties, the funds were held for over a year; (5) the Treasurerâ€™s Office refunded the full purchase price to respondents; and (6) the County earned a 6% rate of interest on respondentsâ€™ funds with an actual earned amount of $28,010.93 in interest.
Seeking the interest their money earned while in the Countyâ€™s possession, respondents brought suit against the County of Beaufort, the Treasurer of Beaufort County, and the Tax Collector of Beaufort County (collectively â€œpetitionersâ€ or â€œthe Countyâ€).Â  One of respondentsâ€™ theories for relief was unjust enrichment.Â  Petitioners answered, asserting that respondents were limited to the statutory remedy.Â  The master-in-equity heard the matter and ruled in favor of respondents.Â  Specifically, the master found that:Â  (1) the applicable statute, section 12-51-150, was silent as to interest; and (2) applying the rules of equity, petitioners would be unjustly enriched if they retained the interest earned on respondentsâ€™ funds when it was petitionersâ€™ errors that caused them to void the tax sales.Â  Therefore, the master awarded respondents actual damages of $28,010.93.Â  
The Court of Appeals affirmed.Â  Key Corp., supra.Â  First, the Court of Appeals found that section 12-51-150â€™s silence on the subject of interest did not â€œentitle[] the County to retain the interest.â€Â  Key Corp., 360 S.C. at 516, 602 S.E.2d at 106.Â  The Court of Appeals then reasoned that because other sections within Chapter 51 specifically address interest,[2] the Legislatureâ€™s omission regarding interest in section 12-51-150 required that the rules of equity be applied.Â  Like the master-in-equity, the Court of Appeals found â€œit would be unjust to allow the County to keep the interest on the purchase prices of tax sales that were voided due to the Countyâ€™s own errors and omissions;â€ therefore, the Court of Appeals concluded that respondents were entitled to the interest actually earned while in the Countyâ€™s possession.Â  Id. at 519-20, 602 S.E.2d at 107-08.
ISSUE

Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the award of interest to respondents?

DISCUSSION
Petitioners argue that the Court of Appeals erred in not following the plain and unambiguous language of section 12-51-150 which, at the relevant time, provided only for a return of the â€œamount paidâ€ to the successful bidder when a tax sale is voided.Â  Petitioners further contend it was error to apply the principles of equity because the statute provided an adequate remedy at law, i.e., the refund of the purchase price paid by the bidder.Â  We agree with both these arguments.Â  
The sale of the property of a defaulting taxpayer is governed by statute.Â  Durham v. United Cos. Fin. Corp., 331 S.C. 600, 603, 503 S.E.2d 465, 467 (1998).Â  â€œIf a statuteâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and conveys a clear meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose another meaning.â€Â  Buist v. Huggins, 367 S.C. 268, 276, 625 S.E.2d 636, 640 (2006) (internal quotes and citation omitted).Â  Instead, the words of the statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation. Â Id.Â  Moreover, â€œit is beyond this Courtâ€™s power to effect a change in the statutes enacted by the Legislature.â€Â  State v. Corey D., 339 S.C. 107, 120, 529 S.E.2d 20, 27 (2000); see also Keyserling v. Beasley, 322 S.C. 83, 86, 470 S.E.2d 100, 101 (1996) (this Court does â€œnot sit as a superlegislature to second guess the wisdom or folly of decisions of the General Assemblyâ€).
We need not go any further than the plain language of section 12-51-150 to determine that it was error to award respondents the earned interest. Â At the time in question, this statute provided a clear remedy if a tax sale was voided - a â€œrefundâ€ of â€œthe amount paidâ€ to the successful bidder.Â  If the Legislature had intended the County to earn and then refund interest, it could easily have specified these requirements in the statute as it did in sections 12-51-100 and 12-51-130.Â  See footnote 2, supra.
Indeed, the Legislature amended this section just last year to expressly provide that when a tax sale is voided, the purchaser would be provided a refund plus actual interest earned.Â  Section 12-51-150 now reads as follows, in pertinent part:Â  

If the official in charge of the tax sale discovers before a tax title has passed that there is a failure of any action required to be properly performed, the official may void the tax sale and refund the amount paid, plus interest in the amount actually earned by the county on the amount refunded, to the successful bidder.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-150 (Supp. 2006) (emphasized language effective June 14, 2006).
We have long acknowledged the presumption that in adopting an amendment to a statute, the Legislature intended to change the existing law. Â See Vernon v. Harleysville Mut. Cas. Co., 244 S.C. 152, 155, 135 S.E.2d 841, 844 (1964); see also North River Ins. Co. v. Gibson, 244 S.C. 393, 398, 137 S.E.2d 264, 266 (1964) (where the Court recognized â€œthe rule of construction that the adoption of an amendment which materially changes the terminology of a statute ... raises a presumption that a departure from the original law was intendedâ€); Hyde v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Mental Health, 314 S.C. 207, 210, 442 S.E.2d 582, 583 (1994) (Toal, J., dissenting) (â€œWhere a statute has been amended, there is a presumption that the legislature intended to change the law.â€).[3]
We see no reason not to apply this presumption and therefore conclude that the Legislatureâ€™s amendment to section 12-51-150 sought to effect a change in the law.Â  Because the amendment materially changed the terminology of the statute, a departure from existing law clearly was intended, rather than a clarification of original intent.Â  See North River Ins. Co. v. Gibson, supra. Â In fact, to hold otherwise would indicate that this amendment essentially was a futile act, which we are disinclined to do.Â  See Denene, Inc. v. City of Charleston, 352 S.C. 208, 212, 574 S.E.2d 196, 198 (2002) (â€œThe Court must presume the legislature did not intend a futile act, but rather intended its statutes to accomplish something.â€); TNS Mills, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Revenue, 331 S.C. 611, 503 S.E.2d 471 (1998) (same).Â  
Accordingly, we hold that the plain language of the prior version of section 12-51-150 clearly limits respondentsâ€™ remedy to a refund of the purchase price without interest.
Moreover, we find it was error to fashion an equitable remedy in this case.Â  While equitable relief is generally available where there is no adequate remedy at law, an adequate legal remedy may be provided by statute.Â  Santee Cooper Resort, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 298 S.C. 179, 185, 379 S.E.2d 119, 123 (1989). Â Indeed, a â€œcourtâ€™s equitable powers must yield in the face of an unambiguously worded statute.â€Â  Id.Â  There is simply nothing inadequate about the remedy of a full refund provided by the plain language of the prior version of section 12-51-150; hence, there was no reason for the lower courts to resort to equity principles.
Finally, as to respondentsâ€™ argument that an equitable remedy is justified by the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in H & K Specialists v. Brannen, 340 S.C. 585, 532 S.E.2d 617 (Ct. App. 2000), we simply disagree.Â  In H & K Specialists, the Court of Appeals held that section 12-51-100[4] applied to the case because the tax sale was set aside in a later court action.Â  The Court of Appeals deemed the master-in-equityâ€™s return of the property to the delinquent taxpayers â€œas the ultimate redemptionâ€ thereby triggering section 12-51-100â€™s remedy of the return of the purchase price plus interest to the successful bidder.Â  Id. at 588, 532 S.E.2d at 619. Â While the Court of Appeals did note that the Countyâ€™s errors and omissions created the â€œinequitable situationâ€ present in the case,[5] this does not establish that the Court of Appeals fashioned an equitable remedy in favor of the appellant.Â  Id. at 589, 532 S.E.2d at 620. Â On the contrary, the Court of Appeals merely held that the setting aside of the tax sale was tantamount to a redemption which triggered section 12-51-100 and the remedy contained therein.Â  In the instant case, however, there is no question that the applicable statute is section 12-51-150 which, in its previous form, did not provide the successful bidder with interest on the purchase price.
CONCLUSION
In sum, we hold that the version of section 12-51-150 in effect at the relevant time only required the County, upon voiding the tax sales, to refund the purchase price, and not the interest, to respondents.Â  Therefore, the Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion is 
REVERSED.
MOORE and BURNETT, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which PLEICONES, J., concurs.
CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I would affirm the court of appealsâ€™ decision, but remand the case for a determination of the appropriate amount Beaufort County must disgorge as a result of its unjust enrichment.
A court may grant equitable relief where there is no adequate remedy at law.Â  Santee Cooper Resort, Inc. v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 298 S.C. 179, 185, 379 S.E.2d 119, 123 (1989).Â  An adequate remedy at law is one which provides the plaintiff with â€œthe full end and justice of the case. It is not enough that there is some remedy at law, but that remedy must be as practical, efficient, and prompt as the remedy in equity.â€Â 
Chisolm v. Pryor, 207 S.C. 54, 60, 35 S.E.2d 21, 24 (1945) (internal citations omitted).Â Â  
â€œRestitution is a remedy designed to prevent unjust enrichment.â€Â  Stanley Smith & Sons v. Limestone College, 283 S.C. 430, 435 n.1, 322 S.E.2d 474, 478 n.1 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  To recover on a theory of restitution, the plaintiff must show that: (1) he conferred a non-gratuitous benefit on the defendant, (2) the defendant realized some value from the benefit, and (3) it would be inequitable for the defendant to retain the benefit without paying the plaintiff for its value. Sauner v. Pub. Serv. Auth. of South Carolina, 354 S.C. 397, 581 S.E.2d 161 (2003).
The majority finds that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-150 (2000) provided the Respondentâ€™s with an adequate remedy at law.Â  Although I agree that the statute provides some remedy for the Respondents, I do not find the remedy adequate because it is neither practical, complete, nor efficient.Â  While the statute mandates the return of the amount paid by the bidder, the statute fails to provide complete relief to the Respondents who, through no fault of their own, have been denied the use of their funds.Â  The interpretation propounded by the majority provides little incentive for the County to resolve its mistakes in a timely fashion, and instead, encourages the County to indefinitely hold funds which rightfully belong to the bidder.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Here, the Respondents gave the County money in exchange for the title to real property.Â  Although the County failed to deliver title for the real property to the Respondents, the County retained the money and utilized the funds to earn interest. Clearly, this constitutes a non-gratuitous benefit for which the County received some value.Â  Surely it is inequitable for the County to retain these benefits without compensating the Respondents for their value.
The County argues that no inequity occurred because the Respondents had actual notice that interest would not be given in the event the tax sale was voided.Â  However, in my opinion, the notice provided to the bidders refers to the statutory interest payments bidders normally receive if a property is redeemed by the taxpayer, see S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-100 (2000), and not the interest the County earns on the funds through a deposit account or other similar investment.Â  While it is reasonable that the County should not pay statutory interest that it has not received through redemption, it is unreasonable and inequitable to allow the County to retain interest earned on funds which rightfully belonged to the Respondents.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Additionally, the majority holds that the legislature intended to prohibit the return of any interest earned on bid money retained by the County because the statute is silent on the issue of interest and the legislature could have included such language in Â§ 12-51-150 as it has in other statutes.Â Â Â  I disagree.
First, I would find that the statuteâ€™s silence regarding the return of interest is ambiguous and does not clearly demonstrate legislative intent to prohibit the return of such interest.Â  This Court has acknowledged that â€œsubsequent legislation may be of service as indicating the construction given to the former by the legislature itself.â€Â  Abell v. Bell, 229 S.C. 1, 5, 91 S.E.2d 548, 550 (1956) (internal citations omitted).Â  Furthermore, this Court recognizes: 

the rule of construction that the adoption of an amendment which materially changes the terminology of a statute under some circumstances indicates persuasively and raises a presumption that a departure from the original law was intended. Â However, like all rules of construction, the presumption is merely an aid in interpreting an ambiguous statute and determining the legislative intent. Â The presumption is strongest â€œin the case of an isolated independent amendment. . . and. . . is of little force in respect of amendments adopted in a general revision or codification of the laws.â€

North River Ins. Co. v. Gibson, 244 S.C. 393, 398, 137 S.E.2d 264, 266 (1964) (holding that the legislatureâ€™s modification of language in a statute accomplished by general revision of the laws indicated the legislatureâ€™s intent to clarify the existing law and not to materially change the existing law).
The legislature recently revised Â§ 12-51-150 to include additional language requiring a county that voids a tax sale to also relinquish the amount of interest actually earned on the amount paid by the bidder.Â  See Act No. 386, 2006 S.C. Acts 3077.Â  Like the statute at issue in Gibson, Â§12-51-150 was modified through an act which provided a general revision to many statutes in our Code of Laws.Â  Because the modification of the statute was accomplished through an act of general revision and not an isolated independent amendment, I would hold that the revision by the legislature indicated its intent to clarify the statute as opposed to an intent to materially modify the law.Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Second, I find the majorityâ€™s reliance on the fact that the legislature could have included language requiring the return of interest in Â§ 12-51-150 as it had in other statutes inconsequential.Â  Both Â§Â§ 12-51-100 and -130 refer to situations distinctly different from the one at hand.Â  As I have discussed, Â§ 12-51-100 clearly refers to the statutory interest provided by Â§ 12-51-90.Â  Section 12-51-130, on the other hand, allows the County to retain interest earned on money which it rightfully possesses due to the failure of the defaulting taxpayer or owner of record to claim the funds in a timely fashion.Â  Therefore, in my opinion, the legislatureâ€™s discussion of interest in these statutes provides no indication of its intent to prohibit the relinquishment of interest pursuant to Â§12-51-150.Â  These statutes simply address interest in different contexts.Â Â  
For the foregoing reasons, I would affirm the court of appeals and allow the Respondents to maintain an action against the County for restitution. However, in recognition of the unintentional nature of the Countyâ€™s mistake and the costs associated with carrying out these types of transactions, I believe that the equitable remedy of restitution only allows the Respondents to recover the amount in which the County was unjustly enriched.Â Â  Therefore, I would remand the case to the trial court with instructions to determine the amount of unjust enrichment the County must disgorge.Â Â Â  
PLEICONES, J., concurs.

[1] The version of section 12-51-150 relevant to the instant action states as follows:

In the case that the official in charge of the tax sale discovers before a tax title has passed, the failure of any action required to be properly performed, the official may void the tax sale and refund the amount paid to the successful bidder.Â  If the full amount of the taxes, assessments, penalties, and costs have not been paid, the property must be brought to tax sale as soon as practicable.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-150 (2000) (emphasis added).Â  As will be discussed infra, this statutory section was recently amended to also provide to the successful bidder any interest earned on the purchase price.Â  See 2006 S.C. Act No. 386, effective June 14, 2006.
[2] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-100 (where the defaulting taxpayer redeems the property, the successful bidder at the tax sale is entitled to be â€œrefunded the purchase price plus the interestâ€); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-130 (County is directed to invest amounts paid at a tax sale that exceed the amount owed by delinquent taxpayer in a separate account â€œso as not to be idle,â€ and if taxpayer does not claim the overage within the specified time period, County is entitled to both the overage and â€œthe earnings for keeping the overageâ€).
[3] But see Stuckey v. State Budget and Control Bd., 339 S.C. 397, 401, 529 S.E.2d 706, 708 (2000) (â€œA subsequent statutory amendment may be interpreted as clarifying original legislative intent.â€).Â  
[4] This section, entitled â€œCancellation of sale upon redemption; notice to purchaser; refund of purchase price,â€ states:

Upon the real estate being redeemed, the person officially charged with the collection of delinquent taxes shall cancel the sale in the tax sale book and note thereon the amount paid, by whom and when. Â The successful purchaser, at the delinquent tax sale, shall promptly be notified by mail to return the tax sale receipt to the person officially charged with the collection of delinquent taxes in order to be expeditiously refunded the purchase price plus the interest provided in Section 12-51-90.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-51-100 (2000).
[5] The County failed to provide the delinquent taxpayers with proper notice, which led to the tax sale being set aside by the master, and then erroneously refunded the purchase price to the delinquent taxpayers instead of the successfully bidder.

description: The Court holds that insurers may limit the portability of basic UIM coverage from at-home vehicles when an insured is involved in an accident while in a vehicle he owns, but does not insure under the policy.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Robert J. Burgess, Respondent,
        v.
        Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26304
Heard November 14, 2006 - Filed April 9, 2007Â Â Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Robert C. Brown and J. Austin Hood, both of Brown & Brehmer, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Kristi Fisher Curtis, of Sumter, and Nelson Russell Parker, of Land Parker & Welch, PA, of Manning, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  We granted certiorari to consider this Court of Appeals decision finding invalid an automobile insurance policy purporting to limit the portability of underinsured motorist (UIM) coverage.Â  Burgess v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., 361 S.C. 196, 603 S.E.2d 861 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Burgess was injured in a motor vehicle accident while operating his motorcycle, which was insured by Alpha Property and Casualty Insurance Company.Â  Burgessâ€™s damages exceeded the at-fault driverâ€™s coverage, and Burgess had no UIM coverage on the motorcycle.Â  He did, however, own three other vehicles insured by Nationwide, each of which had $25,000 in UIM coverage.
Nationwide declined Burgessâ€™ UIM claim, relying on this policy provision:

3.  If a vehicle owned by you or a relative is involved in an accident where you or a relative sustains bodily injury or property damage, this policy shall:
  
a)  be primary if the involved vehicle is your auto described on this policy; or
b)  be excess if the involved vehicle is not your auto described on this policy.Â  The amount of coverage applicable under this policy shall be the lesser of the coverage limits under this policy or the coverage limits on the vehicle involved in the accident.
(Emphasis supplied).
  

Burgess brought this declaratory judgment action, and the circuit court held that Nationwide must pay Burgess $15,000 in UIM benefits under one of its policies insuring Burgessâ€™ â€œat-homeâ€ vehicles.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed, and we granted Nationwideâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari.
ISSUE

Whether the Court of Appeals was correct when it concluded Nationwideâ€™s policy provision purporting to limit the portability UIM coverage is void because it violates S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002)?

ANALYSIS
The Court of Appeals first held that UIM, like uninsured motorist (UM) coverage, is â€œpersonal and portable,â€ that is, the coverage follows the individual insured and not the insured vehicle.Â  See Hogan v. Home Ins. Co., 260 S.C. 157, 162, 194 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1973) (â€œunlike the provisions relative to liability coverage, the statute plainly affords uninsured motorist coverage to the named insured and resident relatives of his or her household at all times and without regard to the activity in which they were engaged at the time.Â  Such coverage is nowhere limited by the statute to the use of the insured vehicleâ€).
The Court of Appeals then analyzed the impact of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 on the issue of the policy provisionâ€™s validity.Â  In relevant part, this statute provides:

Automobile insurance carriers shall offer, at the option of the insured, uninsured motorist coverage up to the limits of the insuredâ€™s liability coverage in addition to the mandatory coverage prescribed by Section 38-77-150.Â  Such carriers shall also offer, at the option of the insured, underinsured motorist coverage up to the limits of the insured liability coverage to provide coverage in the event that damages are sustained in excess of the liability limits carried by an at-fault insured or underinsured motorist or in excess of any damages cap or limitation imposed by statute.Â  If, however, an insured or named insured is protected by uninsured or underinsured motorist coverage in excess of the basic limits, the policy shall provide that the insured or named insured is protected only to the extent of the coverage he has on the vehicle involved in the accident.Â 
 â€¦.
(bold in Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion).

The Court of Appeals held the â€œIf, howeverâ€ sentence in Â§ 38-77-160 applied only to stacking cases, found the issue here was not stacking but rather Nationwideâ€™s attempt to â€œexclude basic UIM coverage in a situation where the vehicle involved in the collision is owned by the insured but not specifically covered by a UIM policy,â€ and concluded that nothing in the statute permitted an insurer to exclude basic UIM coverage under these circumstances.Â  Furthermore, the court held that the endorsement purporting to preclude Burgessâ€™s recovery of basic UIM was void as against public policy because Â§ 38-77-160 only permits an insurer to limit excess UIM coverage.
We begin by noting that we agree with the Court of Appeals that, as a general proposition, UIM coverage follows the individual insured rather than the vehicle insured, that is, UIM coverage, like UM, is â€œpersonal and portable.â€Â  See Hogan v. Home Ins. Co., supra.Â  Further, we agree with the Court of Appeals that the â€œIf, howeverâ€ sentence in Â§ 38-77-160, relied upon by Nationwide here, does not literally apply to these facts since Burgess is not attempting to stack excess UIM coverage from his Nationwide policy.[1]Â  In our view, however, this statutory language does provide support for Nationwideâ€™s contention that its policy provision does not violate public policy.Â  The â€œIf, howeverâ€ sentence in Â§ 38-77-160 evinces the legislatureâ€™s intent, in a stacking situation, to bind the insured to the amount of UIM coverage he chose to purchase in the policy covering the vehicle involved in the accident.Â  Thus, the statute itself contains a limit on the â€œportabilityâ€ of UIM coverage. 
Neither Â§ 38-77-160 nor our prior decisions decide the issue presented here: Is public policy offended by an automobile insurance policy provision that limits basic UIM portability when an insured is involved in an accident while in a vehicle he owns, but does not insure under the policy?Â  We find it is not.Â  UIM coverage is entirely voluntary, and permits insureds, at their option, to purchase insurance coverage for situations where they are injured by an at-fault driver who does not carry sufficient liability insurance to cover the insuredsâ€™ damages.Â  Essentially, the insured is buying insurance coverage for situations, as where he is a passenger in anotherâ€™s vehicle or is a pedestrian, where he cannot otherwise insure himself.Â  When, however, the insured is driving his own vehicle, he has the ability to decide whether to purchase voluntary UIM coverage.Â  Burgess chose not to do so when insuring his motorcycle.
An automobile insurance company, in setting its rates, bases those rates at least in part on the probabilities involving the insured and the vehicle(s) he is insuring.Â  Where, as here, the vehicle is not insured by the company from whom coverage is sought, the carrier cannot accurately calculate its risks.Â  It is one thing to insure against â€œunknowableâ€ risks, such as the chance that one will be injured by an underinsured at-fault driver while a passenger in anotherâ€™s vehicle, or as a pedestrian; it is an entirely different calculus where a companyâ€™s insured owns and operates a motor vehicle, especially a motorcycle, not insured by the carrier making its risk assessments.
We hold that public policy is not offended by an automobile insurance policy provision which limits the portability of basic â€œat-homeâ€ UIM coverage when the insured has a vehicle involved in the accident.Â  Compare State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Calcutt, 340 S.C. 231, 530 S.E.2d 896 (Ct. App. 2000) (endorsement providing for set-off of workersâ€™ compensation benefits for UIM valid where UIM set-off is not, because UIM coverage is voluntary).Â  Upholding this limit on portability encourages persons to purchase UIM insurance on all their vehicles.Â  To hold, as did the Court of Appeals, that basic UIM is portable even in this situation permits an individual who owns multiple vehicles to purchase UIM insurance on only one vehicle, yet have basic UIM coverage on all.Â  We find this result undesirable.
CONCLUSION
The decision of the Court of Appeals requiring Nationwide to provide Burgess with $15,000 UIM benefits is
 REVERSED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] Stacking is defined â€œas the insuredâ€™s recovery of damages under more than one policy until all of his damages are satisfied or the limits of all available policies are met.â€Â  Giles v. Whitaker, 297 S.C. 267, 376 S.E.2d 278 (1989).Â  Since Burgess seeks recovery under only one policy, technically he is not seeking to stack coverage.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, Petitioner,
v.
Kimberly Erwood, Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26305
Heard November 14, 2006 - Filed April 9, 2007Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
J. R. Murphy and Adam J. Neil, both of Murphy & Grantland, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
James C. Cothran, Jr. and Thomas Barksdale Cabler, both of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  We granted certiorari to review a decision of the Court of Appeals holding invalid, as against public policy, a provision in an automobile insurance policy purporting to limit the portability of basic uninsured motorist (UM) coverage.Â  Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co. v. Erwood, 364 S.C. 1, 611 S.E.2d 319 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Erwood was a passenger on an uninsured motorcycle owned and driven by her husband when he had an accident.Â  Erwoodâ€™s husband was at-fault in the accident.Â  Erwood owned an automobile insured by Nationwide under a policy providing $15,000 in UM coverage.Â  She sought to recover under the UM provision of her Nationwide policy, but Nationwide denied her claim.
Nationwide brought this declaratory judgment action, and the circuit court granted it summary judgment.Â  On appeal, the Court of Appeals reversed, citing Burgess v. Nationwide Mut Ins. Co., 361 S.C. 196, 603 S.E.2d 861 (Ct. App. 2004) reversed Op. No. 26304 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed April 9, 2007).Â  Although we do not find Burgess, which concerned a policy limitation on the portability of underinsured (UIM) coverage, controls this case, we affirm the result reached by the Court of Appeals here.
ISSUE

Whether an automobile insurance policy limiting basic UM coverage is void as against public policy?

ANALYSIS
Erwood was injured while a passenger on an uninsured motorcycle owned by her spouse.Â  Nationwide relied upon this policy provision to deny Erwoodâ€™s claim:

3.  If a vehicle owned by you or a relative is involved in an accident where you or a relative sustains bodily injury or property damage, this policy shall:
  
a)  be primary if the involved vehicle is your auto described on this policy; or
b)  be excess if the involved vehicle is not your auto described on this policy.Â  The amount of coverage applicable under this policy shall be the lesser of the coverage limits under this policy or the coverage limits on the vehicle involved in the accident.
(emphasis supplied).
  

The Court of Appeals held, as it had in Burgess, that UM coverage is â€œpersonal and portable,â€ that is, it follows the insured and not the vehicle.Â  We agree.Â  See e.g., Hogan v. Home Ins. Co., 260 S.C. 157, 162, 194 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1973) (â€œunlike the provisions relative to liability coverage, the statute plainly affords uninsured motorist coverage to the named insured and resident relatives of his or her household at all times and without regard to the activity in which they were engaged at the time.Â  Such coverage is nowhere limited by the statute to the use of the insured vehicleâ€).
The court also held that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002) does not permit an automobile insurance company to exclude or restrict basic UM coverage.Â  Unlike the Court of Appeals, however, we conclude that the controlling statute is not Â§ 38-77-160, which covers stacking claims,[1] but rather the statute referred to in Hogan, which is now found at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-150 (Supp. 2002).Â  Section 38-77-150 mandates UM coverage in all automobile insurance policies.Â  We find that the mandatory nature of this coverage distinguishes it from the voluntary UIM coverage at issue in Burgess, and that pubic policy requires that basic UM coverage be afforded to Erwood even when she is a passenger on her spouseâ€™s uninsured motorcycle.[2]Â  Compare State Farm Mut Auto. Ins. Co. v. Calcutt, 340 S.C. 231, 530 S.E.2d 896 (Ct. App. 2000) (insurance policy endorsement providing for set-off of workerâ€™s compensation benefits for UIM valid where UM set-off is not, because UIM coverage is voluntary).
CONCLUSION
We affirm, as modified, the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision holding that Erwood is entitled to collect basic UM benefits under her Nationwide policy.
Affirmed as Modified.
 MOORE and WALLER, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J., and BURNETT, J., dissenting in separate opinions.
Chief Justice Toal: I respectfully dissent.Â  I would hold that uninsured motorist coverage is not â€œportableâ€ for a party who is injured while operating or while a passenger of a vehicle of which the party would be an insured had he or she purchased insurance coverage.Â  
Just as it does in the context of underinsured motorist coverage, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002) contains a limitation on just how â€œpersonal and portableâ€ uninsured motorist coverage can be.Â  We recognized this limitation and made good use of it in deciding that an insured may not apply underinsured coverage from an insurance policy covering one vehicle to a separate policy, covering a separate vehicle, under which the insured declined the insurance companyâ€™s offer of such coverage.Â  See Burgess v. Nationwide Mut. Ins. Co., Op. No. 26304 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed April 9, 2007).Â  In reaching that decision, we noted that â€œ[u]pholding this limit on portability encourages persons to purchase UIM insurance on all their vehicles.â€Â  Id.Â  Because this situation is no different, and because the public policy concerns are identical, I see no need to retreat from that holding in the instant case.[3]
I think the majority rightly expresses concern at the thought that under similar logic to that used in the court of appealsâ€™ decision, an owner of an uninsured vehicle involved in an accident could be entitled to use uninsured motorist coverage from a separate vehicle to recover for his or her injuries.Â  Undeniably, this result would be absurd.Â  Instead, the owner of multiple vehicles who chooses to insure only one with uninsured and underinsured motorist coverage ought to be precluded from recovering basic UM and UIM limits on any of his or her vehicles for which he or she has not purchased this coverage.Â  In my view, this is the precise concern that drove us to hold as we did in Burgess, and by holding as the majority does in the instant case, we chip away at that foundation.
Although I appreciate the view expressed by my brother Justice Burnett in dissent, I believe it is far too late in the day to argue that the language of an insurance contract is the end of the inquiry in these cases.Â  See Charleston County Sch. Dist. v. State Budget & Control Bd., 313 S.C. 1, 6, 437 S.E.2d 6, 8 (1993) (noting that statutory provisions relating to insurance contracts have long been held by this Court to be part of these contracts).Â  Because the court of appeals found a provision of the contract in the instant case was contrary to public policy and therefore void, we must necessarily proceed beyond the terms of the contract in our analysis.
For the reasons I have outlined, I would reverse the court of appealsâ€™ decision and find that Respondent is not entitled to basic uninsured motorist coverage from her automobile insured by Nationwide.


BURNETT, J.:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion, it is unnecessary to address either S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160 (2002) or the personal and portable nature of UM coverage for the language of the insurance contract itself provides no coverage for Erwood.
The construction of an agreement is a matter of contract law. Â McDuffie v. McDuffie, 313 S.C. 397, 399, 438 S.E.2d 239, 241 (1993).Â  The primary objective in construing a contract is to ascertain and give effect to the intention of the parties. Â Williams v. Teran, Inc., 266 S.C. 55, 59, 221 S.E.2d 526, 528 (1976).Â  The Court must first look at the language of the contract in order to determine the intention of the parties.Â  Superior Auto. Ins. Co. v. Maners, 261 S.C. 257, 263, 199 S.E.2d 719, 722 (1973).Â Â  If its language is plain,
unambiguous, and capable of only one reasonable interpretation, no construction is required and the
contractâ€™s language determines the instrumentâ€™s force and effect.Â  Blakely v. Rabon, 266 S.C. 68, 72, 221 S.E.2d 767, 769 (1976).Â  Â Â 
â€œWhen a contract is unambiguous, clear and explicit, it must be construed according to the terms the parties have used, to be taken and understood in their plain, ordinary and popular sense.â€Â Â  C.A.N. Enter., Inc. v. South Carolina Health and Human Serv. Fin. Comm'n, 296 S.C. 373, 377-378, 373 S.E.2d 584, 586 (1988) (quoting Warner v. Weader, 280 S.C. 81, 83, 311 S.E.2d 78, 79 (1983)). Â â€œ[I]t is not the function of this Court to rewrite it or torture the meaning of a policy to extend coverage never intended by the parties.â€Â  Torrington Co. v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 264 S.C. 636, 643, 216 S.E.2d 547, 550 (1975).

Erwood entered into an insurance contract with Nationwide.Â  The insurance contract applied to any vehicle owned by her or her relative and contemplated the involvement or ownership of an uninsured vehicle.Â  As noted by the majority, the pertinent portion of Erwoodâ€™s insurance contract states:

3.  If a vehicle owned by you or a relative is involved in an accident where you or a relative sustains bodily injury or property damage, this policy shall: 
  
a)    be primary if the involved vehicle is your auto described on this policy; or 
b)    be excess if the involved vehicle is not your auto described on this policy.Â  The amount of coverage applicable under this policy shall be the lesser of the coverage limits under this policy or the coverage limits on the vehicle involved in the accident.Â  
  

Subsection (a) of the policy is inapplicable because the involved vehicle was uninsured.Â  Subsection (b), therefore, applies to limit the amount of coverage available.Â  The amount of coverage applicable under subsection (b) is the lesser of coverage limits under Erwoodâ€™s policy or the coverage limits on the vehicle involved in the accident.Â  The vehicle involved in the accident was uninsured.Â  Thus, the clear and unambiguous language of this provision does not provide any coverage for Erwood.Â  When the language of a policy is â€œplain, unambiguous, and capable of only one reasonable interpretation,â€ it must be given full force and effect.Â  See Blakely, 266 S.C. at 72, 221 S.E.2d at 769.Â  Accordingly, I would reverse the decision of the Court of Appeals.Â  

[1] Since Erwood is not seeking to stack insurance coverage, we are not concerned by her status as a Class I insured.
[2] We do not decide whether basic UM coverage is universal, such that the owner of an uninsured vehicle involved in the accident would be entitled to basic UM coverage from an at-home vehicle.Â  We are troubled by the thought that a person operating a vehicle without insurance in violation of the Motor Vehicle Financial Responsibility Act would be allowed to collect benefits from the insurer of another of the owner/operatorâ€™s vehicles.
[3] In reaching this conclusion, I note that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-30(7) (2002) defines an insured as both the named insured and, if a resident of the same household, the spouse of the named insured.Â

Lexington County Joint Municipal Water and Sewer Commâ€™n, 367 S.C. 141, 625 S.E.2d 227 (2006).Â  We hereby grant the petition, dispense with further briefing, and reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.Â
