title: Connor Holdings, LLC v. Cousins
description: The Court affirmed the special refereeâ€™s dismissal of this private enforcement action based on Appellantsâ€™ lack of standing.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Connor Holdings, LLC and MAL Entertainment, Inc., Appellants,
        v.
        Charles Cousins, in his capacity as Director of Planning of the Town of Hilton Head Island, and Island Cabaret, Inc., Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Ralph E. Tupper, Special Referee

Opinion No. 26307
Heard March 8, 2007 - Filed April 9, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        John P. Seibels, Jr., of Seibels Law Firm, P.A., of Charleston, for Appellants.
        Gregory M. Alford, of Alford Wilkins & Strickroth, P.C., of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent Charles Cousins. 
        Bert G. Utsey, III, and Grahame E. Holmes, both of Peters, Murdaugh, Parker, Eltzroth and Detrick, P.A. of Walterboro, for Respondent Island Cabaret, Inc.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Connor Holdings, LLC and MAL Entertainment, Inc. (collectively Appellants) appeal the dismissal of their action against Charles Cousins, in his capacity as Director of Planning of the Town of Hilton Head Island, and Island Cabaret, Inc.Â  We certified the appeal from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and we affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Connor Holdings currently owns a commercial building located at #1 Dunnaganâ€™s Alley in the Town of Hilton Head Island (Town).Â  Connor Holdings leases the building to MAL Entertainment, which operates an adult entertainment business.Â  In August and September 2002, MAL Entertainment filed a written complaint with Cousins in accordance with Townâ€™s Land Management Ordinance (LMO) Â§ 16-8-103(C).Â  MAL Entertainment asked Cousins to investigate whether Island Cabaret had a valid special exception to operate an adult entertainment business at 130 Arrow Road in the Town and further asked Cousins to prevent Island Cabaret from operating an adult entertainment business until the necessary special exception was obtained. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
When Cousins failed to respond to MAL Entertainmentâ€™s complaint, MAL Entertainment and Connor Holdings commenced this action against Cousins and Island Cabaret.Â  Appellants sought an injunction against Island Cabaret from establishing or reestablishing an adult entertainment use at 130 Arrow Road until Island Cabaret received a valid special exception as required by the LMO.Â  They also sought a writ of mandamus requiring Cousins to exercise his authority in accordance with the LMO as it related to Island Cabaretâ€™s establishment and operation of an adult entertainment business. 
After a hearing on the matter, the special referee found Connor Holdings and MAL Entertainment lacked standing and failed to exhaust their administrative remedies.Â  He also determined Cousins properly complied with the LMO and properly construed the LMO to find Island Cabaret had a valid special exception.Â  The special referee granted summary judgment in favor of Cousins and Island Cabaret.Â  
ISSUE

  Did the special referee err in granting summary judgment to Cousins Â  and Island Cabaret on the ground Appellants lacked standing?Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
A lower court may properly grant a motion for summary judgment when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the lower court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences that may be drawn from the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Manning v. Quinn, 294 S.C. 383, 385, 365 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the special referee erred in finding they lacked standing under LMO Â§ 16-8-105. Â We disagree.
Standing to sue is a fundamental requirement in instituting an action.Â  Joytime Distribs. & Amusement Co. v. State, 338 S.C. 634, 639, 528 S.E.2d 647, 649 (1999).Â  LMO Â§ 16-8-105 provides:

  An adjacent or neighboring property owner who would be specially damaged by any violation may in addition to other remedies, institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent the unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance, or use, or to correct or abate the violation, or  to prevent the occupancy of the building, structure or land.Â  This is in addition to the right of the Town to bring an enforcement action.

LMO Â§ 16-8-105 plainly gives an adjacent or neighboring property owner the right to bring an enforcement action when the property owner is specially damaged by certain violations of the LMO.Â  See Overcash v. S.C. Elec. & Gas Co., 364 S.C. 569, 576, 614 S.E.2d 619, 622 (2005) (â€œThe main factor in determining whether a statute creates a private cause of action is legislative intent.â€).Â  
Connor Holdings owns the property located at #1 Dunnaganâ€™s Alley and MAL Entertainment is its tenant.Â  Therefore, MAL Entertainment, as a tenant, lacks standing under LMO Â§ 16-8-105 to pursue this enforcement action.Â  
As a neighboring property owner, Connor Holdings may pursue this action if it is specially damaged.Â  Special damages in a zoning enforcement action generally are the diminution in the value of the plaintiffâ€™s property due to the violating use.Â  See Momeier v. John McAlister, Inc., 203 S.C. 353, 359, 27 S.E.2d 504, 511 (1943) (finding a material depreciation in the value of the plaintiffâ€™s property constituted special damages in a zoning enforcement case); Bell v. Bennett, 307 S.C. 286, 295, 414 S.E.2d 786, 791-92 (Ct. App. 1992); (finding the master-in-equity properly dismissed defendantâ€™s claim that plaintiff failed to comply with a zoning ordinance because defendant failed to plead or prove his property value was diminished by plaintiffâ€™s violating use).Â  Connor Holdings, however, does not allege a diminution in the value of its property.Â  Rather, Connor Holdings alleges, in an affidavit, its special damages include adverse affects to its economic and property interests and a transformation of its adult entertainment use from conforming to nonconforming due to Island Cabaretâ€™s operation.Â  
Although this Court has not addressed whether a loss in profits due to competition constitutes special damages, the theory has been consistently rejected if increased competition is the sole basis for special damages.Â  See generally 4 Rathkopfâ€™s The Law of Zoning and Planning Â§ 63.34 (4th ed. 2005) (â€œ[G]enerally, persons whose only complaint is that the rezoning or grant of special permit or variance would create competition with them in the conduct of their business have been held not to have standing to litigate the validity of the zoning action.â€); 1 Am.Jur. Proof of Facts 3d 495 Â§ 7 (1988) (noting an owner of commercial property generally does not have standing if â€œspecial damages amount to a loss of business due to the position of the violating use as a competing business,â€ but commercial property owner may be specially damaged if he â€œallege[s] adverse impact on his business other than by increased competitionâ€).Â  Yet, Connor Holdings asserts the loss of profits from increased competition in conjunction with the change of its use from conforming to nonconforming constitutes special damages based on Skaggs-Albertsonâ€™s v. ABC Liquors, Inc., 363 So.2d 1082 (Fla. 1978).Â  
In Skaggs-Albertsonâ€™s, an owner of a liquor store objected to another liquor storeâ€™s violation of the zoning regulations.Â  The Florida Supreme Court acknowledged the general rule that â€œloss of business from a potential competitor ordinarily cannot provide the existing proprietor with the requisite standing.â€Â  363 So.2d at 1090.Â  The Court then noted, although other businesses were subject to regulation, the alcoholic beverage industry was subject to stringent government regulation.Â  The Court recognized the regulations restricted the number and proximity of liquor stores and the Court distinguished a liquor license, which is a form of property, from other types of licenses, which are not property.Â  Id.Â  Due to the unique regulation of the alcoholic beverage industry, the Court found the liquor store owner had standing on the basis of business competition.Â  Id.Â  
Connor Holdingsâ€™ alleged special damages are distinguishable from those in Skaggs-Albertsonâ€™s.Â  Although Connor Holdings is subject to more regulations under the LMO if its use is nonconforming, Connor Holdings is not subject to the same type of stringent regulations as the liquor store owner in Skaggs-Albertsonâ€™s.Â  In addition, Connor Holdings has failed to prove any adverse impact on its economic interests other than due to increased competition or to its property interests.Â  We conclude Connor Holdings lacks standing to pursue this action because it failed to plead or prove any special damages.Â  Rule 9(g), SCRCP (â€œWhen items of special damage are claimed, they shall be specifically stated.â€); Sheek v. Lee, 289 S.C. 327, 329, 345 S.E.2d 496, 497 (1986) (â€œSpecial damages must be alleged in the complaint to avoid surprise to the other party.â€).Â  
CONCLUSION
We affirm the special refereeâ€™s dismissal of the action based on Appellantsâ€™ lack of standing.Â  Based on the foregoing, we need not address Appellantsâ€™ remaining issues on appeal.Â  See Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
AFFIRMED.
MOORE and PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Edward B. Cottingham, concur. TOAL, C.J., concurring in a separate opinion.
Chief Justice Toal:Â  I concur in the result reached by the majority.Â  I write separately, however, to address two curiosities in this case on the issue of standing.Â  
 In the federal courts, the requirements for what is commonly termed as â€œconstitutional standingâ€ have been relatively long-established.Â  These requirements provide that in order to maintain a cause of action, (1) the plaintiff must have suffered an invasion of a legally protected interest (an â€œinjury in factâ€) which is concrete and particularized, and actual or imminent; (2) there must be a causal connection between the plaintiffâ€™s injury and the conduct of which the plaintiff complains; and (3) it must be likely that the plaintiffâ€™s injury will be redressed by a favorable decision.Â  Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 559-61 (1992).Â  We have used these boundaries of federal constitutional standing to outline the requirements of the minimum a plaintiff must show in order to bring an action in a South Carolina court.Â  E.g., Sea Pines Assâ€™n for Prot. of Wildlife, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res., 345 S.C. 594, 601, 550 S.E.2d 287, 291 (2001) (citing Lujan, 504 U.S. at 559-61).
I find the land management ordinance in this case interesting in two regards.Â  First, I would interpret the ordinanceâ€™s requirement that a neighboring landowner either sustain or be in danger of sustaining special damages as not bearing on the issue of standing.Â  Instead, I would hold that the requirement of special damages goes to the substantive adequacy of the neighborâ€™s claim.Â  The federal courts have adopted a rule providing that when a statutory limitation is not expressly characterized as jurisdictional, courts should treat the restriction as non-jurisdictional in character.Â  See Arbaugh v. Y & H Corp., 546 U.S. 500, Â­Â­__, 126 S.Ct. 1235, 1245 (2006).Â  I would follow their lead.Â  Holding otherwise would require the neighbor in the instant case to effectively prove his case before he can go to court.
But this distinction reveals the second curiosity.Â  In essence, the land management ordinance at issue in this case authorizes a neighboring property owner to bring a lawsuit to prevent any action which may inflict upon him â€œspecial damages.â€Â  Failing to see how this ordinance does anything other than repeat the constitutional standing requirement of an â€œinjury in fact,â€ I would resolve the case on those grounds alone.

title: State v. Bixby
description: This criminal case involves the issue of whether one who is charged as an accessory before the fact to murder is ineligible for the death penalty.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Appellant,
        v.
        Rita Greenwood Bixby, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Abbeville County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26308
Heard December 7, 2006 - Filed April 9, 2007Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of Columbia; and Solicitor Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for appellant.
        Jeffrey P. Bloom, of Columbia; and Joseph Collins Smithdeal, of Ayers, Smithdeal, & Bettis, PC, of Greenwood, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  On December 8, 2003, Abbeville County Deputy Sheriff Danny Wilson and South Carolina State Constable Donnie Ouzts were allegedly murdered by respondentâ€™s husband and son.[1]Â  The murders culminated from a dispute between respondent and her husband and the Department of Transportation in its attempt to seize a portion of their property for a road-widening project.Â  Respondent, who was not present at the scene of the murders, was indicted for misprision of a felony, criminal conspiracy, and two counts of accessory before the fact of murder.[2]
The State served notice of its intent to seek the death penalty on the accessory charges.Â  Respondent moved to dismiss the notice of intent to seek the death penalty and to declare her ineligible for the death penalty.Â  After a hearing, the trial judge entered an order stating that to notice respondent with the death penalty presupposes that she faces a charge of murder, which she does not.Â  He found respondent ineligible for the death penalty and granted the motion to dismiss the Stateâ€™s notice of intent.Â  The appeal from that decision follows and we affirm.
ISSUE

  
    Did the lower court err by finding respondent ineligible for the death penalty under South Carolina law because she was merely charged with accessory before the fact of murder?
  

DISCUSSION
Respondent was charged with accessory before the fact to the murders of the officers pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-40 (2003), which states:

  
    A person who aids in the commission of a felony or is an accessory before the fact in the commission of a felony by counseling, hiring, or otherwise procuring the felony to be committed is guilty of a felony and, upon conviction, must be punished in the manner prescribed for the punishment of the principal felon.
  

The punishment prescribed for the principal felon, i.e. for murder, is that a person who is convicted of or pleads guilty to murder must be punished by death, by life imprisonment, or by a mandatory minimum imprisonment term of thirty years.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(A) (2003).Â  Therefore, a plain reading of Â§16-3-20(A) and Â§16-1-40 indicates that one who is charged with accessory before the fact to murder is clearly subject to the punishments of life imprisonment or a mandatory minimum imprisonment term of thirty years because these are the punishments rendered when one is found guilty of murder.[3]Â  However, respondentâ€™s eligibility for the death penalty is not so clear.Â  A review of Â§ 16-3-20 is necessary to determine her eligibility.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20 (2003) states:

  
    (A) A person who is convicted of or pleads guilty to murder must be punished by death, by imprisonment for life, or by a mandatory minimum term of imprisonment for thirty years.Â  If the State seeks the death penalty and a statutory aggravating circumstance is found beyond a reasonable doubt pursuant to subsections (B) and (C), and a recommendation of death is not made, the trial judge must impose a sentence of life imprisonment.Â  . . .
    (B) When the State seeks the death penalty, upon conviction or adjudication of guilt of a defendant of murder, the court shall conduct a separate sentencing proceeding.Â  In the proceeding, if a statutory aggravating circumstance is found, the defendant must be sentenced to either death or life imprisonment.Â  If no statutory aggravating circumstance is found, the defendant must be sentenced to either life imprisonment or a mandatory minimum term of imprisonment for thirty years.Â  . . .
    . . .Â  Unless at least one of the statutory aggravating circumstances enumerated in this section is found, the death penalty must not be imposed.
      Where a statutory aggravating circumstance is found and a recommendation of death is made, the trial judge shall sentence the defendant to death.Â  . . . Where a statutory aggravating circumstance is not found, the trial judge shall sentence the defendant to either life imprisonment or a mandatory minimum term of imprisonment for thirty years.
  

(Emphasis added).Â  
A possible sentence of death applies only when one is convicted of or has pled guilty to the crime of murder.Â  Following the plain language of Â§ 16-3-20, the State may seek the death penalty upon conviction or adjudication of guilt of a defendant of murder.[4]Â  See State v. Muldrow, 348 S.C. 264, 559 S.E.2d 847 (2002) (words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction).Â  The statute does not provide any other crimes for which a defendant may be eligible for the death penalty.Â  Cf. State v. Blackmon, 304 S.C. 270, 403 S.E.2d 660 (1991) (when a statute is penal in nature, it must be construed strictly against the State and in favor of the defendant).
Although Â§ 16-1-40 provides that one who is convicted as an accessory before the fact must be punished in the manner prescribed for the punishment of the principal felon, the Legislature has not indicated any intent in Â§ 16-3-20 to have such an accessory be subject to the most severe punishment of death.Â  See State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004) (if Legislature had intended certain result in a statute it would have said so); State v. Cutler, 274 S.C. 376, 264 S.E.2d 420 (1980) (where there is conflict between general statute and specific statute, the specific prevails). 
Given the plain language of Â§ 16-3-20 and the fact the Legislature has not shown an intent to make one charged with accessory before the fact to murder death penalty-eligible, the trial judge properly found that respondent is not eligible for the death penalty and properly dismissed the Stateâ€™s notice of intent to seek the death penalty.
Our disposition of this issue makes it unnecessary to address petitionerâ€™s factual argument.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 428 S.E.2d 886 (1993) (appellate court need not address remaining issue when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).Â  Accordingly, the decision of the lower court is
AFFIRMED.
WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. TOAL,C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  I would reverse the decision of the trial court finding Respondent ineligible for the death penalty.Â  In my opinion, a charge of accessory before the fact to murder implicates the death penalty under South Carolina law.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
I agree with the majorityâ€™s contention that the plain language of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20 (2003) allowing the State to seek the death penalty only applies upon conviction or adjudication of guilt of a defendant of murder, and that the statute does not provide any other crimes for which a defendant may be eligible for the death penalty.Â  However, in my view, a conviction of accessory before the fact to murder is regarded by law as a conviction for murder and therefore Â§ 16-3-20 applies.Â  

  
    S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-40 (2003) defines an accessory as follows:Â  
    A person who aids in the commission of a felony or is an accessory before the fact in the commission of a felony by counseling, hiring, or otherwise procuring the felony to be committed is guilty of a felony and, upon conviction, must be punished in the manner prescribed for the punishment of the principal felon.Â  (Emphasis supplied).
  

In this case, Respondent was indicted on two counts of accessory before the fact to the underlying felony of murder.Â  To illustrate my interpretation of Â§ 16-1-40 and its applicability to the issue here, if we were to replace each instance of the general term felony in Â§ 16-1-40 with the specific felony of murder relevant in this case, the result is that a â€œperson who . . . is an accessory before the fact in the commission of a murder by counseling, hiring, or otherwise procuring the murder to be committed is guilty of a murder . . . .â€Â  Therefore, if a jury convicted Respondent for accessory before the fact to murder, the plain language of Â§ 16-1-40, in my view, would regard Respondent as guilty of the crime of murder.Â  Accordingly, Respondent would be eligible for the death penalty under Â§ 16-3-20.[5]
Furthermore, practical concerns dictate that an accessory before the fact to murder be eligible for the death penalty under South Carolinaâ€™s statutory scheme.Â  A person who counsels, hires, or otherwise procures a felony to be committed may be indicted and convicted as either an accessory before the fact or for the substantive felony.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-50 (2003).Â  Under the majorityâ€™s conclusion then, whether a defendant who counseled, hired, or otherwise procured a murder is eligible for the death penalty ultimately comes down to whether the State decides to prosecute the defendant as an accessory before the fact to murder or for the murder itself.Â  The General Assembly certainly did not intend such an illogical result.Â  
Ultimately, the majorityâ€™s conclusion rests on hesitancy to apply the clear language of the accessory statute.Â  However, Â§ 16-1-40 clearly states that an accessory is guilty of the principal felony and is punished accordingly.Â  I see no reason to depart from this reading of the plain language.
For the foregoing reasons, I would hold that a defendant who is an accessory before the fact to murder is guilty of murder by operation of lawÂ Â  and is subject to the death penalty in accordance with Â§ 16-3-20.Â  Accordingly, I would reverse the trial courtâ€™s finding that Respondent was ineligible for the death penalty and reinstate the Stateâ€™s notice of intent to seek the death penalty.Â 

[1]Respondentâ€™s son, Steven Bixby, was convicted of murder and was subsequently sentenced to death on February 21, 2007. 
[2]The elements that must concur to justify the conviction of one as an accessory before the fact are:Â  (1) that the defendant advised and agreed, or urged the parties or in some way aided them, to commit the offense; (2) that the defendant was not present when the offense was committed; and (3) that the principal committed the crime.Â  State v. Smith, 316 S.C. 53, 447 S.E.2d 175 (1993). 
[3]See, e.g., State v. Lewis, 293 S.C. 107, 359 S.E.2d 66 (1987). 
[4]The dissent states that resting the defendantâ€™s eligibility for the death penalty on the Stateâ€™s decision whether to prosecute a defendant as an accessory before the fact to murder or for the murder itself is an illogical result.Â  However, giving the prosecutor discretion in determining what charges to bring against a defendant and whether a defendant should be eligible for the death penalty is exactly what our law provides.Â  A prosecutor should not be hampered in making these determinations.Â  Cf. Ex parte Littlefield, 343 S.C. 212, 540 S.E.2d 81 (2000) (South Carolina Constitution and case law place the unfettered discretion to prosecute solely in the prosecutorâ€™s hands).
[5] Interestingly, in 1977 when the General Assembly created a bifurcated trial structure consisting of a guilt phase and a sentencing phase for cases in which the death penalty is sought, Â§ 16-1-40 read as follows:

  Whoever aids in the commission of a felony or is accessory thereto before the fact by counseling, hiring or otherwise procuring the felony to be committed shall be punished in the manner prescribed for the punishment of the principal felon.

In 1993, the General Assembly amended Â§ 16-1-40 to read in its present form.Â  See 1993 S.C. Acts 3229, 3237-38.Â  Although the 1993 amendment consisted mainly of grammatical changes, it is interesting to note the addition of the phrase that an accessory â€œis guilty of a felonyâ€ just before the language declaring the manner of â€œpunishmentâ€ for an accessory.Â  In my view, this alteration makes the statute easily applicable to the bifurcated trial structure created by the General Assembly fifteen years earlier.

title: In the Matter of Steven Robinson Cureton
description: This opinion suspends Steven Robinson Cureton from the practice of law for two years based on his commission of certain criminal offenses and his failure to adequately communicate with clients regarding his interim suspension.
text:
The Supreme Court of South Carolina

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Steven Robinson Cureton, Respondent.
			
		
	


ORDER

Following the issuance of this Courtâ€™s opinion imposing a two year suspension in this matter, information was received from the parties regarding the disposition of the charges which form the basis for that suspension.Â  In order to accurately reflect the status of the charges, we withdraw the former opinion and substitute the attached opinion.
IT IS SO ORDERED.

   
     
     
      s/Jean H. Toal

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Steven Robinson Cureton, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26301
Submitted March 12, 2007 - Refiled April 23, 2007Â Â  

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General Robert E. Bogan, of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Perry Hudson Gravely, of Pickens, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a definite suspension or any lesser sanction set forth in Rule 7(b), RLDE.Â  Respondent requests that, if a definite suspension is imposed, it run from the date of his interim suspension.[1]Â  We accept the Agreement and find a two year suspension from the practice of law is the appropriate sanction; however, we deny respondentâ€™s request that the definite suspension run from the date of his interim suspension.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.
Facts
A.Â  Criminal Matter
Respondent was arrested and charged with possession of alprazolam, a generic form of Xanax; possession of hydrocodone biterate, a generic form of Lortab; and possession of morphine sulfate, all in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(d)(2).Â  He was also charged with possession of marijuana, less than 28 grams, in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(d)(3), and possession of cocaine with intent to distribute, based on his possession of 3.84 grams of cocaine, in violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(b)(1).Â  The charges for possession of alprazolam and possession of morphine sulfate were dismissed.Â  With regard to the remaining charges, respondent pled guilty to possession of hydrocodone and acetaminophen, possession of marijuana and possession of cocaine.Â  Respondent does not dispute that he committed the offenses and admits that, at the time of his arrest, he suffered from a cocaine dependency for which he has since sought and completed inpatient and outpatient treatment.
B.Â  Legal Representation Matter
Respondent was retained by three clients and was paid a fee of either $3,000 or $3,500 by or on behalf of each client.Â  The clients maintain that, upon his suspension, respondent failed to adequately communicate with them regarding their cases and they were required to retain other counsel to complete their litigation.
Respondent acknowledges he did not communicate with the clients with reasonable diligence and promptness as required by Rules 1.3 and 1.4 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, and that his physical and mental condition, caused by his drug dependency, may have impaired his ability to handle the clientsâ€™ cases, in violation of Rule 1.16(a)(2), RPC, Rule 407, SCACR.Â  Respondent also acknowledges the clients are entitled to a refund of their retainer fees, less any amount respondent earned by performing work on the clientsâ€™ behalf.
Law
Respondent admits that by his conduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (a lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client); Rule 1.3 (a lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (a lawyer shall explain a matter to the extent reasonably necessary to permit the client to make informed decisions regarding the representation, keep the client reasonably informed about the status of the matter, and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.16(d) (upon termination of representation, a lawyer shall take steps to the extent reasonably practicable to protect a clientâ€™s interests, such as giving reasonable notice to the client, allowing time for employment of other counsel, surrendering papers and property to which the client is entitled and refunding any advance payment of fees or expenses that has not been earned or incurred); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(b)(it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to commit a criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness or fitness as a lawyer in other respects); and Rule 8.4(c) (it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to commit a criminal act involving moral turpitude).
Respondent also admits that he has violated the following provisions of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or to engage in conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law).
Conclusion
We find a two year suspension is the appropriate sanction for respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and suspend respondent from the practice of law for two years.Â  Respondent shall not be eligible for reinstatement until respondent has paid his fine and completed the sentence imposed, including release from the period of probation.Â  See Rule 33(f)(10), RLDE.Â  Finally, respondent shall, within thirty days of the date of this opinion, enter into a restitution plan with the Office of Disciplinary Counsel, and begin making restitution to presently known and/or subsequently identified clients, banks, and other persons and entities, including the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection, who have incurred losses as a result of respondentâ€™s misconduct in connection with these matters.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] In re Cureton, 363 S.C. 78, 609 S.E.2d 527 (2005).

title: State v. Ladner
description: In this direct appeal, the Court addressed issues related to an excited utterance by a child victim and affirmed appellant's conviction for first degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Bryan Ladner, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â DanielÂ  F.Â  Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26310
Heard February 14, 2007 - Filed April 23, 2007Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, Patricia Ann Kennedy and Keshia V. White, of Berkeley Public Defenders, Inc., of Moncks Corner, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  Appellant Bryan Ladner was indicted for criminal sexual conduct with a minor, first degree.Â  A jury found appellant guilty, and the trial court sentenced him to 14 yearsâ€™ imprisonment.Â  Appellant directly appeals from his conviction.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Appellant was charged with digitally penetrating the victimâ€™s vagina on October 31, 2003.Â  The victim, at the time, was approximately two and a half years old.
After the jury had been selected, but prior to any testimony being taken, the State informed the trial court it was not planning to call the victim as a witness.[1]Â  Instead, the State intended to introduce the victimâ€™s statement implicating appellant through the excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule.Â  In response, defense counsel stated that the victim might be called in the defenseâ€™s case-in-chief, and therefore, appellant requested a competency hearing.Â  Appellant also made a motion in limine to determine the admissibility of the hearsay statement. 
The hearing on the motion in limine proceeded, and the State put up Marla Jackson.[2]Â  Marla testified that on Halloween 2003 at around 7 p.m., appellant and others arrived at her house to take the victim trick-or-treating.Â  About one hour later, appellant returned the victim to Marlaâ€™s house.Â  Within approximately 45 minutes of the victim returning to Marlaâ€™s house, the victim went to the bathroom and complained that her crotch area[3] hurt when she urinated.Â  It was discovered that the victim was bleeding, so Marla laid her down in the bedroom and saw that she was red and swollen in her vaginal area.Â  Marla asked the victim what happened, and the victim said, â€œBryan did it.â€Â  The victim then stated, â€œNo, Bryan didnâ€™t do nothing.â€
The trial court ruled that the victimâ€™s statement to Marla identifying appellant as the perpetrator was admissible because it met all the elements of the excited utterance hearsay exception.Â  Further, the trial court stated that the victimâ€™s incompetency based on her youth would not bar admission under the excited utterance rule.Â  Defense counsel then requested the competency hearing.Â  The victim was questioned by defense counsel and so clearly demonstrated she was incompetent to testify that at the close of questioning, defense counsel conceded she was not competent as a witness.Â  Appellant requested that the trial court reconsider its hearsay ruling, but the trial court again ruled the statement admissible.
The following additional facts were developed during trial testimony.Â  Appellant lived with his fiancÃ©e Joanna Sweatman.Â  Joanna had been the victimâ€™s primary caretaker until September 2003, when the victim was sent to Tennessee to be taken care of by Joannaâ€™s mother, Eloise Cales.[4]Â  Eloise traveled with the victim back to South Carolina on October 30, 2003.Â  Arrangements were made on that day for Joanna and appellant to take the victim trick-or-treating the next evening.
Marla was the Stateâ€™s primary witness.Â  She testified that she was an â€œaunt figureâ€ to the victim.Â  Marla drove Eloise and the victim from Tennessee to South Carolina the day before Halloween 2003; both Eloise and the victim stayed at Marlaâ€™s house on October 30 and 31.Â  Marla described how she got the victim ready for trick-or-treating around 6 p.m. on October 31:

  [B]efore I put her panty hose on, I took her pull-up[5] off and washed her down because she had peed in her pull-up that we originally put on her after she had taken a bath earlier and I had to wash her, wipe her down and then put a new pull-up on her before I put her tights on her. 

The victim was outfitted as a princess for Halloween:Â  she had on a dress, make-up, and tights as her costume.Â  
Around 7 p.m., Joanna picked the victim up from Marlaâ€™s house; appellant was driving, and several others were in the car.Â  Appellant drove the group to a neighboring subdivision to go trick-or-treating.Â  Between 7:45 and 8 p.m., appellant returned the victim to Marlaâ€™s house.Â  Marla testified that she was on the porch giving out candy when the victim returned, and she noticed the victim had been crying because her face was red and her make-up was smeared.Â  Â Â  
Appellant explained that he brought the victim back because she was having a temper tantrum.Â  According to Marla, appellant did not even stay two minutes at her house.Â  Eloise came to the door and took the victim inside.Â  Shortly thereafter, Marla also went inside the house.Â  The victim sang a couple of songs, karaoke-style.Â  After her singing, while sitting on the couch, the victim grabbed at her crotch and said she had â€œto pee.â€Â  Eloise took her in the bathroom, and Marla went in to â€œfind out what was going on.â€Â  Eloise wiped the child and noticed blood on the toilet paper.[6]Â  She told Marla to take a look at the victim.Â  Marla testified as follows:

  And me and my mom and Eloise was [sic] in the room and [the victim] was all red in her crotch area and swollen and she had scratches all behind her legs.Â  She had a hand print - a large hand print on her arm, a larger hand print on her leg.Â  She had scratches around her wrist.Â  And I asked her what happened, because she said her tooch hurt, and I asked her what happened and she said, Bryan did it.Â  And then she goes, No, Bryan didnâ€™t do nothing, Bryan didnâ€™t do nothing.

(Emphasis added).
The victim was taken to an emergency room and treated by Dr. Charles Staples.Â  Qualified as an expert in sexual assault examinations, Dr. Staples testified the victim had bruises on her left cheek, arm, and inside thigh; his vaginal exam revealed redness.Â  In Dr. Staplesâ€™ opinion, the victimâ€™s injuries were consistent with sexual abuse that was acute, i.e., it had occurred in the previous 12 to 24 hours.
The victim was transported to, and examined at, Carolina Medical Assessment Center for a full sexual assault examination.Â  Dr. Elizabeth Gibbs, who was qualified as an expert in child sexual examinations, testified that her examination occurred around 1 a.m. on November 1, 2003.Â  She reported that the victimâ€™s left leg had been constricted from her left leg being held up.Â  Regarding the victimâ€™s vaginal injuries, Dr. Gibbs testified that the area was extremely swollen, there was a laceration on the left side, and bleeding was coming from the hymen.Â  She also stated the victim was in a great deal of pain from the vaginal injuries.Â  Dr. Gibbs opined the victim had suffered a blunt force penetrating injury to her vagina that had occurred within 24 hours of the time of examination.Â  Moreover, Dr. Gibbs stated that although cases of digital penetration generally present with much less trauma than this victim had, her injuries nonetheless could have been caused by digital penetration.
Based on the victimâ€™s identification of appellant, the police interrogated appellant in the early morning hours of November 1, 2003.Â  He gave two statements to Detective Aldo Bassi.Â  In his second statement, appellant wrote the following:

  [the victim] was tired and crying so [Joanna] asked me to take her home.Â  She put [the victim and another child] in the car.Â  [The victim] was crying [hysterically] and from the front seat I grabbed her arm to get her to stop, she didnâ€™t so I grabbed her leg still trying to get her attention for her to stop.Â  She kept crying and I pushed on her diaper in groin area. Â She still wouldnâ€™t stop so I pushed on her crotch w/my finger.Â  She [stopped] crying and was fine the rest of the way home.Â  (It was my right hand and my finger slightly penitrated [sic] her) I did this out of frustration [and] anger to make her stop crying [hysterically].

At trial, however, appellant testified that the victim was â€œthrowing a fitâ€ as he was driving her back from trick-or-treating so he reached back and â€œpopped her on the leg.â€Â  Appellant stated that Detective Bassi put words in his mouth about what had happened to the victim.Â  Appellant testified that he wrote the second statement because he â€œjust wanted to go home.â€Â  
ISSUES
 

  1.     Was the victimâ€™s hearsay statement testimonial and therefore inadmissible under Crawford v. Washington?
  2.     Did the trial court err by admitting the victimâ€™s hearsay statement under the excited utterance exception?
  3.     Did the trial court err by denying appellantâ€™s request for a directed verdict?

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Testimonial vs. Nontestimonial under Crawford v. Washington
Appellant argues it was error to admit the victimâ€™s hearsay statement because pursuant to Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36 (2004), the hearsay statement was testimonial and therefore inadmissible because he had no prior opportunity to cross-examine the victim.Â  We disagree.[7]
The Sixth Amendmentâ€™s Confrontation Clause guarantees that â€œ[i]n all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right â€¦ to be confronted with the witnesses against him.â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. VI.Â  In Crawford v. Washington, the United States Supreme Court (USSC) held that the admission of testimonial hearsay statements against an accused violates the Confrontation Clause if: Â (1) the declarant is unavailable to testify at trial, and (2) the accused has had no prior opportunity to cross-examine the declarant.Â  Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. at 54.Â  With regard to testimonial statements, Crawford overruled Ohio v. Roberts, 448 U.S. 56 (1980), which held that a hearsay statement is admissible if it bears adequate â€œindicia of reliability,â€ i.e., it falls under a firmly rooted hearsay exception or there is an adequate showing of â€œparticularized guarantees of trustworthiness.â€ Â See Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. at 60; Ohio v. Roberts, 448 U.S. at 66.Â  
The Crawford Court declined to comprehensively define â€œtestimonial.â€Â  It did, however, state that the â€œcore class of â€˜testimonialâ€™ statementsâ€ includes:

  ex parte in-court testimony or its functional equivalent, such as affidavits, custodial examinations, prior testimony that the defendant was unable to cross-examine, or similar pretrial statements that declarants would reasonably expect to be used prosecutorially; 
  
  extrajudicial statements contained in formalized testimonial materials, such as affidavits, depositions, prior testimony, or confessions;
  
  statements that were made under circumstances which would lead an objective witness reasonably to believe that the statement would be available for use at a later trial; and
  
  statements taken by police officers in the course of interrogations.

Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. at 51-52 (citations omitted).Â  In addition, the USSC stated that testimony â€œis typically â€˜[a] solemn declaration or affirmation made for the purpose of establishing or proving some fact.â€™â€Â  Id. at 51 (quoting 2 N. Webster, An American Dictionary of the English Language (1828)).Â  The Crawford Court further observed that â€œ[a]n accuser who makes a formal statement to government officers bears testimony in a sense that a person who makes a casual remark to an acquaintance does not.â€Â  Id. at 51.
Just last year, the USSC provided further guidance on the Crawford decision in Davis v. Washington, ___ U.S. ___, 126 S.Ct. 2266 (2006).Â  There, the USSC dealt with two different domestic violence cases and held (1) a victimâ€™s identification of her abuser in response to initial questions from a 911 emergency operator was not testimonial, but (2) where police responded to a domestic disturbance, found the wife and husband at home, and took a statement from the wife about the husbandâ€™s abuse (while the husband was in another room), the wifeâ€™s statements were testimonial.Â  The Davis Court explained: 

  Statements are nontestimonial when made in the course of police interrogation under circumstances objectively indicating that the primary purpose of the interrogation is to enable police assistance to meet an ongoing emergency. Â They are testimonial when the circumstances objectively indicate that there is no such ongoing emergency, and that the primary purpose of the interrogation is to establish or prove past events potentially relevant to later criminal prosecution.

Davis v. Washington, 126 S.Ct. at 2273-74.Â  The Davis Court specifically noted that its holdings related to police interrogations.Â  Id. at 2274 n.1. 
Furthermore, while Crawford apparently left Roberts viable as the primary authority for analyzing nontestimonial hearsay, Davis arguably â€œdeclared that the Sixth Amendment simply has no application outside the scope of testimonial hearsay.â€Â  Tom Lininger, Reconceptualizing Confrontation After Davis, 85 Tex. L. Rev. 271, 285 (2006); see also U.S. v. Tolliver, 454 F.3d 660, 665 n.2 (7th Cir. 2006) (Davis â€œappears to have resolved the issue, holding that nontestimonial hearsay is not subject to the Confrontation Clauseâ€), cert. denied 127 S.Ct. 1019 (2007).
The hearsay statement at issue in the instant case was made by a two-and-a-half year old girl to her caretakers immediately after they discovered blood coming from her vaginal area.Â  The victim indicated that her â€œtoochâ€ hurt, and Marla asked what happened.Â  The victim responded by saying appellant â€œdid it,â€ and then quickly stating he â€œdidnâ€™t do nothing.â€ [8]Â  
We find the victimâ€™s statement to Marla is clearly nontestimonial.Â  Significantly, the victimâ€™s statement is much more akin to a remark to an acquaintance rather than a formal statement to government officers.Â  See Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. at 51.Â  Given the circumstances surrounding the victimâ€™s statement identifying appellant as the person who hurt her, as well as to whom the statement was made, the statement does not amount to â€œa solemn declaration or affirmation made for the purpose of establishing or proving some fact.â€Â  Id.Â  Significantly, Marlaâ€™s questions, as well as the victimâ€™s responses, were not designed to implicate the criminal assailant, but to ascertain the nature of the childâ€™s injury.Â  Cf. State v. Davis, 371 S.C. 170, 178, 638 S.E.2d 57, 61 (2006) (generally, statements made outside of an official investigatory or judicial context are nontestimonial).
Cases in other jurisdictions with similar facts have also held the child-victimâ€™s statements to be nontestimonial. Â See generally Jerome C. Latimer, Confrontation After Crawford:Â  The Decisionâ€™s Impact On How Hearsay Is Analyzed Under The Confrontation Clause, 36 Seton Hall L. Rev. 327, 364-66 (2006) (statements made by children to persons unconnected to law enforcement have consistently been found to be nontestimonial).Â  For example, in Purvis v. State, 829 N.E.2d 572 (Ind. Ct. App. 2005), cert. denied, 126 S.Ct. 1580 (2006), the court held that the ten-year-old victimâ€™s statements to his mother and her boyfriend immediately after the boy was molested were not testimonial.Â  The victim, after being asked by the motherâ€™s boyfriend â€œwhat happened?â€ stated that the defendant had â€œput his â€˜privateâ€™ into [the victimâ€™s] mouth and made [the victim] â€˜suck on it.â€™â€Â  The boy repeated similar statements to his mother soon afterward.Â  Id. at 576-77.
In finding no Confrontation Clause violation under Crawford, the Purvis court explained as follows:

  The rationale of the rule in Crawford is to exclude from evidence statements that have not been cross-examined that were gathered for the purpose of use at a later trial.Â  [The victimâ€™s] statements to [his mother and the man he treated as his father] were not elicited for the purpose of preparing to prosecute anyone but rather to gain information about what happened, find out if [the victim] was harmed, and remedy any harm that had befallen him. Â Â 

Id. at 579.Â  The court also noted that simply because â€œparents turn over information about crimes to law enforcement authorities does not transform their interactions with their children into police investigations.â€Â  Id. 
In State v. Aaron L., 865 A.2d 1135 (Conn. 2005), the Connecticut Supreme Court found that a statement made by the victim when she was two-and-a-half years old was properly admitted.Â  The child had spontaneously told her mother: Â â€œâ€˜Iâ€™m not going to tell you that I touch daddyâ€™s pee-pee.â€™â€Â  Id. at 1145.Â  Regarding the Crawford issue, the Court stated that â€œthe victimâ€™s communication to her mother clearly does not fall within the core category of ex parte testimonial statements that the court was concerned with in Crawford.â€Â  Id. at 1146 n.21.
In Herrera-Vega v. State, 888 So.2d 66 (Fla. Dist. Ct. App. 2004), a three-year-old girl â€œspontaneously told her mother, as she was putting on the childâ€™s underpants, that twenty-year-old Vega had placed his tongue in her â€˜private parts.â€™ Â [The victim] reluctantly repeated the story to her father minutes later.â€Â  Id. at 67.Â  The court there held the trial court did not violate Crawford by allowing the parents to testify to their daughterâ€™s statements.Â  Id. at 69.
In sum, the victimâ€™s hearsay statement in the instant case was not admitted in violation of Crawford because it is a nontestimonial statement.Â  Accordingly, there was no Confrontation Clause violation.
2.Â  Excited Utterance
Appellant also argues the victimâ€™s statement was improperly admitted under the excited utterance hearsay exception.Â  Appellantâ€™s arguments on this issue are twofold.Â  First, appellant contends the statement does not qualify as an excited utterance.Â  Specifically, appellant argues the victim was no longer under the influence of the startling event as evidenced by her singing karaoke songs and eating candy after she returned to Marlaâ€™s home.Â  Second, appellant contends that because the victim was declared incompetent to testify at trial, her hearsay statement made over one year prior to trial is similarly unreliable.Â  We disagree.
â€œâ€˜Hearsayâ€™ is a statement, other than one made by the declarant while testifying at the trial or hearing, offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter asserted.â€ Â Rule 801(c), SCRE. Â The general rule is that hearsay is not admissible.Â  Rule 802, SCRE.Â  There are, however, numerous exceptions to this rule, such as the excited utterance exception. Â The rules of evidence define excited utterance as a â€œstatement relating to a startling event or condition made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement caused by the event or condition.â€ Â Rule 803(2), SCRE. Â 
An excited utterance may be admitted whether or not the declarant is available as a witness.Â  See Rule 803, SCRE (entitled â€œHearsay Exceptions; Availability of Declarant Immaterialâ€).Â  Moreover, when a statement is admissible because it falls within a Rule 803 exception, it may be used substantively, that is, to prove the truth of the matter asserted.Â  State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 283-84, 523 S.E.2d 173, 177 (1999).Â  Consequently, in the instant case, if the victimâ€™s statement qualifies as an excited utterance, the State properly admitted it to prove that appellant committed the assault.
Looking at the rule, there are three elements that must be met to find a statement to be an excited utterance:Â  (1) the statement must relate to a startling event or condition; (2) the statement must have been made while the declarant was under the stress of excitement; and (3) the stress of excitement must be caused by the startling event or condition.Â  State v. Sims, 348 S.C. 16, 21, 558 S.E.2d 518, 521 (2002).Â  The excited utterance exception is based on the rationale that â€œthe startling event suspends the declarantâ€™s process of reflective thought, reducing the likelihood of fabrication.â€ Â State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. at 284, 523 S.E.2d at 177.Â  A court must consider the totality of the circumstances when determining whether a statement falls within the excited utterance exception, and that determination is left to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Sims, supra.
In our opinion, the trial court did not abuse its discretion by admitting the victimâ€™s statement as an excited utterance.Â  Clearly, the statement related to the startling event of the victim being severely injured in her vaginal area.Â  The victim was complaining of pain and was bleeding when the statements were made, and thus, the victim made the declaration while under the stress of her attack.Â  Finally, this stress obviously was caused by the startling event of the sexual assault itself.Â  The requirements of Rule 803(2), SCRE, were easily satisfied in this case.Â  See also Purvis v. State, 829 N.E.2d at 581 (where the court found the victimâ€™s statement to his father figure, made almost immediately after being molested, and while the boy was â€œplainly upset,â€ clearly â€œmet all the criteriaâ€ for excited utterances).
We turn now to appellantâ€™s claim that because the victim was declared incompetent to testify, her excited utterance was inherently unreliable and therefore was erroneously admitted.Â  This is a novel issue in South Carolina.[9]
The majority of courts that have encountered this issue have held that even though a child could be declared incompetent to testify at trial, the childâ€™s â€œspontaneous declarations or res gestae statementsâ€ are nonetheless admissible.Â  See Jay M. Zitter, Annotation, Admissibility of Testimony Regarding Spontaneous Declarations Made by One Incompetent to Testify at Trial, 15 A.L.R. 4th 1043 (1982); see also 2 McCormick on Evidence Â§ 272 (6th ed. 2006) (â€œan excited utterance is admissible despite the fact that the declarant was a child and would have been incompetent as a witness for that reasonâ€); 2 Whartonâ€™s Criminal Evidence Â§ 7:1 (15th ed. 1998) (noting that courts have admitted out-of-court statements by children found incompetent to testify).Â  
In Morgan v. Foretich, 846 F.2d 941 (4th Cir. 1988), the Fourth Circuit dealt with this issue in a civil case for damages arising out of child sexual abuse.Â  Before proceeding to the legal analysis of the evidentiary issues, the Morgan court noted generally the following:

  An estimated one in five females suffers from sexual abuse as a childâ€¦. Â [I]n two-thirds of child abuse cases, the incident is never even reportedâ€¦. Â Even when the incident is reported, prosecution is difficult and convictions are few.Â  Much of this difficulty stems from the fact that methods of proof in child abuse cases are severely lacking. Â Often, the child is the only witness. Â Yet age may make the child incompetent to testify in court, and fear, especially when the perpetrator is a family member, may make the child unwilling or unable to testify.

Id. at 943 (footnotes and citations omitted).[10]Â  After thoroughly analyzing the hearsay issue, the court decided that four of the victimâ€™s statements made to her mother when the victim was two and three years old should have been admitted as excited utterances; significantly, the court also found that the victimâ€™s â€œyouthful incompetencyâ€ would not prevent the admission of the hearsay statements.Â  Id. at 946-48.
The Washington Court of Appeals faced this exact issue in a case with facts strikingly similar to the case at bar. Â See State v. Bouchard, 639 P.2d 761 (Wash. Ct. App. 1982).Â  In Bouchard, the defendantâ€™s conviction for indecent liberties with his three-year-old granddaughter was affirmed; the victim had suffered a perforated hymen which the State asserted was the result of the grandfatherâ€™s digital penetration of the victim.Â  Id. at 762.Â  The hearsay evidence was described by the court as follows:

  The little girlâ€™s mother testified that when her daughter returned home she complained of â€œwaterâ€ in her pants. Â When the mother changed the childâ€™s clothing, she found blood around her daughterâ€™s lower abdominal and vaginal areas. Â When questioned about the blood, the child told her mother, â€œGrandpa did it.â€ Â The father and attending physicians testified that the child made similar statements to them.

Id. at 763. Â Â The Bouchard court rejected the defendantâ€™s arguments that the statements were inadmissible hearsay and the victimâ€™s incompetency should have prevented the admission of the statements.Â  The court held the victimâ€™s statements fell within the excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule and specifically stated â€œ[t]he fact that the declarant herself (an infant) would not be competent to testify does not prohibit the use of the excited utterances.â€ Â Id. 
We hold that the incompetency of a declarant at the time of trial does not preclude the admission of that declarantâ€™s excited utterance through a different, competent witness.Â  See, e.g., State v. Bauer, 704 P.2d 264, 267 (Ariz. Ct. App. 1985) (â€œexcited utterances of children who are incompetent to testify because of their age are admissible in evidenceâ€); Kilgore v. State, 340 S.E.2d 640, 643 (Ga. Ct. App. 1986) (rejecting the contention â€œthat because the victim would have been incompetent to testify in court, her out-of-court statements were thus unreliable and incompetentâ€); People v. Smith, 604 N.E.2d 858, 871 (Ill. 1992) (excited utterances are sufficiently reliable to be admitted even where the declarant is incompetent); Com. v. Pronkoskie, 383 A.2d 858, 861 n.5 (Pa. 1978) (â€œa finding of incompetency to testify does not necessarily undermine the indicia of reliability attendant upon an excited utterance of the incompetent witnessâ€); Bouchard, supra.
The legal rationales underlying the rules about both competency and the excited utterance hearsay exception make plain that one ruling has little to do with the other.Â  The competency of a witness depends solely on the facts as they exist when the testimony is given. Â 81 Am. Jur. 2d Witnesses Â§ 160 (2004).[11]Â  Conversely, the intrinsic reliability of an excited utterance derives from the statementâ€™s spontaneity which is determined by the totality of the circumstances surrounding the statement when it was uttered.Â  Sims, supra. Â This reliability â€œwill normally remain undiluted by faulty memory, inability to understand questions or otherwise to communicate on the witness stand.â€ Â Pronkoskie, 383 A.2d at 861 n.5.Â  In other words, the trustworthiness of the excited utterance â€œstems not from [the declarantâ€™s] competency, but rather from the unique circumstances in which [the] statements were made.â€ Â People v. Smith, 604 N.E.2d at 871.  Thus, the fact that a declarant is not able to testify at trial does not diminish the reliability of that declarantâ€™s excited utterance.Â  Because the reliability of the excited utterance is unaffected by the incompetency determination, but rather is independently evaluated under long-standing rules developed from the common law, we find appellantâ€™s argument that the victimâ€™s incompetency at the time of trial should disqualify the admission of her excited utterance untenable.
Accordingly, in the instant case, it was well within the trial court discretion to admit the victimâ€™s statements under the excited utterance exception to the hearsay rule.
3.Â  Directed Verdict
Finally, appellant argues the trial court erred by denying his directed verdict motion because the evidence only raised a suspicion that he was guilty.Â  We disagree.
On a directed verdict motion in a criminal case, the trial court is concerned with the existence or non-existence of evidence, not its weight. E.g., State v. Burdette, 335 S.C. 34, 46, 515 S.E.2d 525, 531 (1999). Â If the State presents any evidence which reasonably tends to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt, or from which the defendantâ€™s guilt could fairly and logically be deduced, the case must go to the jury. Â Id. Â A defendant is only entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to put up evidence of the offense charged. Â State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).Â  On appeal from the denial of a directed verdict motion, this Court must view the evidence in a light most favorable to the State. Â Burdette, supra.
We find the trial court correctly denied the directed verdict motion in this case. Â Viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to the State, including the testimony which places appellant with the victim at the most likely time the injury was inflicted, the victimâ€™s identification of appellant as the perpetrator, as well as appellantâ€™s inculpatory statements, it is clear that the case was properly submitted to the jury.Â  To the extent appellant is arguing that the Stateâ€™s case was based on unreliable evidence, the trial court is only concerned with the existence of the evidence, not its weight, when deciding a directed verdict motion. Â McHoney, supra; Burdette, supra.
CONCLUSION
For all the above reasons, appellantâ€™s conviction is AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] At the time of trial, the victim was approximately three and a half years old.Â  The State indicated to the trial court that although it originally had planned on calling the victim as a witness, the Stateâ€™s position was that the child could not testify because of her tender years.
[2] The victim was staying at Marlaâ€™s house when the relevant events occurred.Â  The relationships between the victim and her various caretakers will be further explained infra.
[3] The child referred to her crotch area as her â€œtooch.â€
[4] Both Joanna and Eloise were defense witnesses.Â  Eloise testified that the victimâ€™s mother was â€œunableâ€ to take care of the victim and asked Joanna to take care of her.Â  Joanna testified that her brother was dating the victimâ€™s mother â€œand he didnâ€™t want a baby in the house so they brought her to me and gave her to me and asked me to keep her.â€Â  Joanna explained that she was paid to take care of the victim and she did so for approximately one year. 
[5] A pull-up is similar to a diaper and is used by toddlers who are not fully potty-trained.
[6] Blood was also observed on the victimâ€™s pull-up.Â  
[7] Regarding issue preservation, we agree with appellant that although there was no contemporaneous objection during Marlaâ€™s trial testimony, the hearsay issues are not procedurally barred because proper objections were made at the pretrial proceedings held just before Marlaâ€™s testimony. Â See State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 642-43, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001) (where no evidence is taken between the trial courtâ€™s in limine ruling and the admission at trial of the evidence, the issue is preserved).
[8] Other hearsay statements by the victim identifying appellant were also admitted during the Stateâ€™s case.Â  When asked if the victim told him what had happened, Dr. Staples testified, without objection, as follows:Â  â€œShe indicated to me that she had been touched by her auntâ€™s boyfriend that was previously identified at triage as someone named Bryan.Â  And I asked her if the auntâ€™s boyfriend was Bryan and she told me yes.â€Â  Because the trial courtâ€™s ruling dealt only with Marlaâ€™s testimony, however, we restrict our analysis to this particular statement by the victim.Â  Nonetheless, we note that since there was no objection to this part of Dr. Staplesâ€™ testimony, any arguable error regarding Marlaâ€™s testimony would be deemed harmless.Â  See State v. Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 336 S.E.2d 150 (1985) (erroneous admission of hearsay evidence is subject to harmless error analysis; error is only harmless when it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial); State v. McFarlane, 279 S.C. 327, 330, 306 S.E.2d 611, 613 (1983) (â€œIt is well settled that the admission of improper evidence is harmless where it is merely cumulative to other evidence.â€).
[9] In Sims, there was a somewhat similar factual scenario; however, this precise legal issue was not raised.Â  There, a five-year-old boy witnessed a brutal attack on his mother, who later died.Â  At trial, the boy was declared competent to testify, but while on the stand, he stopped answering questions and would not tell the jury the identity of the person who was in the apartment on the night his mother was attacked.Â  The responding police officer was recalled to the stand and testified that the boy had identified the defendant. The trial court subsequently ruled the statement was admissible hearsay. Â Sims, 348 S.C. at 20, 558 S.E.2d at 520.Â  This Court affirmed, finding the boyâ€™s statement was an excited utterance.
[10] See generally Robert G. Marks, Note, Should We Believe The People Who Believe The Children?: Â The Need For A New Sexual Abuse Tender Years Hearsay Exception Statute, 32 Harv. J. on Legis. 207, 207, 214 (1995) (where the author observes that the â€œsexual abuse of children is one of Americaâ€™s most terrifying social problemsâ€ and child sexual abuse â€œis an extremely difficult crime to prosecuteâ€).
[11] Under South Carolina law, a person will be found incompetent as a witness â€œif the court determines that (1) the proposed witness is incapable of expressing himself concerning the matter as to be understood by the judge and jury either directly or through interpretation by one who can understand him, or (2) the proposed witness is incapable of understanding the duty of a witness to tell the truth.â€Â  Rule 601(b), SCRE.

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of Mark S. Keegan, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26312
Submitted March 27, 2007 - Filed April 23, 2007Â

        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Susan M. Johnston, Deputy Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Mark S. Keegan, of Greenville, pro se.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to the issuance of a letter of caution, an admonition, or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Respondent employed an individual as a paralegal for approximately one year.Â  On October 23, 2006, October 30, 2006, and January 3, 2007 the paralegal manipulated the software system on the law firm computer and caused checks to be issued payable to herself in the amounts of $1,571.13, $1,224.00, and $3,400.00 from the Real Estate Trust Account.Â  The paralegal negotiated the checks for her own purposes.Â  On November 13, 2006, the paralegal misappropriated $2,813.73 from the General Trust Account by providing false payouts representing client liability, but listing personal account numbers for her vehicle taxes and vehicle payment.Â  These checks were used for the paralegalâ€™s personal purposes.Â  
Respondent represents that in October 2005 he retained an accountant to reconcile his Real Estate Trust Account.Â  The accountant reconciled his Real Estate Trust Account for the previous six months.Â  Thereafter, the accountant reconciled the account on a monthly basis from October 2005 through September 2006.Â  The accountant did not receive respondentâ€™s monthly bank statements for October, November, and December 2006.Â  The accountant telephoned respondentâ€™s office in January 2007 and the paralegal told her they no longer needed her services.Â  
Respondent was aware that no account reconciliations were conducted from October 2006 until January 2007.Â  When the reconciliations resumed, the misappropriations were discovered.Â  Respondent transferred funds from his operating account to the trust accounts to cover the losses.
Respondent reported the misappropriation to federal authorities.Â  The paralegal confessed to the theft and has executed a note and mortgage to respondent to reimburse him for the stolen money.Â Â  Â Â 
Respondent represents he did not understand that account reconciliations must be conducted on a monthly basis, not in large monthly groups.Â  He agrees that, had he been properly supervising the paralegal, she would not have been able to unilaterally cancel the accountantâ€™s reconciliation services and, consequently, conceal her thefts.Â  He further agrees that, had he followed the financial recordkeeping provisions of Rule 417, SCACR, the first stolen check would have been quickly discovered and additional client funds would not have been compromised.Â  After discussing these matters with ODC and reviewing the applicable rules, respondent recognizes the shortcomings in his reconciliation system and has implemented procedures which comply with the Courtâ€™s rules.Â  Â 
LAW
Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall safekeep client funds); Rule 5.3 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to ensure that his firm has in effect measures giving reasonable assurance that conduct of non-lawyer employees is compatible with professional obligations of the lawyer); and Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  He further admits that his misconduct violated the recordkeeping provisions of Rule 417, SCACR.Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â Â Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
 We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
