        Judson K. Chapin, III, of Greenville, for Petitioners.
        Matthew Price Turner and Rhett D. Burney, both of Turner and Burney, P.C., of Laurens, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Respondent Richard Aiken (â€œAikenâ€) filed a law suit against Appellants World Finance Corporation of South Carolina and World Acceptance Corporation (collectively, â€œWorld Financeâ€) alleging various torts arising from the misuse of Aikenâ€™s personal financial information by employees of World Finance.Â  The circuit court denied World Financeâ€™s motion to compel arbitration on the grounds that Aikenâ€™s claims were not within the scope of the arbitration clause.Â  The court of appeals affirmed and this Court granted certiorari.Â  We affirm as modified.
Factual/Procedural Background
World Finance is a nationwide consumer finance company with branch offices in South Carolina.Â  Aiken obtained a series of consumer loans from World Finance beginning in 1997 and continuing through late 1999.Â  Aiken paid off his last loan from World Finance in 2000.Â  
In order to apply for a loan, Aiken was required to supply non-public, personal information to World Finance, including his date of birth and social security number.Â  Upon approval of each loan, Aiken entered into an arbitration agreement with World Finance.Â  Each arbitration agreement provided, in relevant part:

  . . . ALL DISPUTES, CONTROVERSIES OR CLAIMS OF ANY KIND AND NATURE BETWEEN LENDER AND BORROWER ARISING OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE LOAN AGREEMENT, OR ARISING OUT OF ANY TRANSACTION OR RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN LENDER AND BORROWER OR ARISING OUT OF ANY PRIOR OR FUTURE DEALINGS BETWEEN LENDER AND BORROWER, SHALL BE SUBMITTED TO ARBITRATION AND SETTLED BY ARBITRATION IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UNTIED STATES ARBITRATION ACT, THE EXPEDITED PROCEDURES OF THE COMMERCIAL ARBITRATION RULES OF THE AMERICAN ARBITRATION ASSOCIATION (THE â€œARBITRATION RULES OF THE AAAâ€), AND THIS AGREEMENT.

Beginning in late 2002, several World Finance employees conspired to use the personal information provided by Aiken and other clients to obtain sham loans and embezzle the proceeds for the employeesâ€™ personal benefit.[1]Â  Upon discovering the misuse of his personal information, Aiken filed suit against World Finance in the court of common pleas for Laurens County seeking damages for outrage and emotional distress, negligence, negligent hiring/supervision, and unfair trade practices.Â  World Finance filed an answer, a motion to dismiss, and a motion to compel arbitration.
The trial court found that the effectiveness of the arbitration agreement ceased when the relationship of the parties ended.Â  Because Aiken paid off his last loan with World Finance prior to the tortious acts of the employees, the court concluded that Aikenâ€™s tort claims were completely independent of the loan agreements and not subject to the arbitration agreements. Therefore, the court denied World Financeâ€™s motions to compel arbitration.
The court of appeals affirmed the decision of the trial court.Â  See Aiken v. World Finance Corp. of South Carolina, 367 S.C. 176, 623 S.E.2d 873 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  This Court granted certiorari and World Finance raises the following issues for review: 

  
    I. 
    Did the court of appeals err in deciding whether Aiken’s underlying claims were subject to arbitration without first submitting the issue to an arbitrator?
  
  
    II.
    Did the court of appeals err in finding that Aiken’s claims were not significantly related to the underlying loan agreement and therefore not within the scope of arbitration? 
  

Standard of Review 
The determination of whether a claim is subject to arbitration is subject to de novo review.Â  Wellman, Inc. v. Square D Co., 366 S.C. 61, 67, 620 S.E.2d 86, 89 (Ct. App. 2005).Â Â  Nevertheless, a circuit courtâ€™s factual findings will not be reversed on appeal if any evidence reasonably supports the findings.Â  Thornton v. Trident Med. Ctr., L.L.C., 357 S.C. 91, 94, 592 S.E.2d 50, 51 (Ct. App. 2003). Â 
Law/Analysis 
I.Â  The appropriate forum for determining the scope of the arbitration clause.
World Finance argues that under the terms of the arbitration agreement, arbitration is the proper forum for determining the scope of the arbitration agreement.Â  Therefore, World Finance claims that the court of appeals erred in determining whether the arbitration agreement covered Aikenâ€™s claims without first submitting the issue to an arbitrator.Â  We find that this issue is not properly preserved for review.Â  
In order to be preserved for appellate review, an issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  Pye v. Estate of Fox, 369 S.C. 555, 564, 633 S.E.2d 505, 510 (2006).Â  World Finance made no argument regarding the proper forum for determining the arbitrability of the underlying claims in either its motion to compel arbitration or in the hearing before the circuit court.Â  Instead, World Financeâ€™s argument focused solely on the merits of the motion (i.e., whether Aikenâ€™s claims were within the scope of the arbitration agreement).Â  Consequently, the trial courtâ€™s order only addresses whether the scope of the arbitration agreement encompasses the underlying claims.Â  
We agree with the court of appeals that the issue of the proper forum for determining the scope of the arbitration agreement is not properly preserved for review.Â  Accordingly, the court of appeals did not err in deciding the question of whether Aikenâ€™s underlying claims were within the scope of the arbitration agreement.
II.Â  Significant relationship between the underlying claims and the contract containing the arbitration agreement.
World Finance argues that the court of appeals erred in finding that Aikenâ€™s claims were not within the scope of the partiesâ€™ arbitration agreement.Â  We disagree.
Both state and federal policy favor arbitration of disputes and unless a court can say with positive assurance that the arbitration clause is not susceptible to any interpretation that covers the dispute, arbitration should generally be ordered.Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596-97, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118-19 (2001).Â  However, arbitration is a matter of contract and a party cannot be required to submit to arbitration any dispute which he has not agreed to submit.Â  Id. at 596, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â  Given these principles, courts generally hold that broadly-worded arbitration agreements[2] apply to disputes in which a â€œsignificant relationshipâ€ exists between the asserted claims and the contract in which the arbitration clause is contained. Id. at 598, 553 S.E.2d at 119 (quoting Long v. Silver, 248 F.3d 309 (4th Cir. 2001)).Â  
World Finance primarily argues that because Aikenâ€™s contracts with World Finance gave the conspirators access to Aikenâ€™s information in order to carry out their crimes, there is a significant relationship between Aikenâ€™s claims and the underlying loan agreement, thereby warranting arbitration.Â  We find this argument unpersuasive.Â  In our opinion, the â€œrelationshipâ€ asserted by World Finance between Aikenâ€™s tort claims and the partiesâ€™ prior dealings under the loan agreements hardly rises to the level of â€œsignificant.â€Â  Applying what amounts to a â€œbut-forâ€ causation standard essentially includes every dispute imaginable between the parties, which greatly oversimplifies the partiesâ€™ agreement to arbitrate claims between them.Â  Such a result is illogical and unconscionable. See Seifert v. U.S. Home Corp., 750 So. 2d 633, 638 (Fla. 1999) (â€œ[T]he mere fact that the dispute would not have arisen but for the existence of the contract and consequent relationship between the parties is insufficient by itself to transform a dispute into one â€˜arising out of or relating toâ€™ the agreement.â€).Â  See also The Vestry and Church Wardens of the Church of the Holy Cross v. Orkin Exterminating Co., Inc., 356 S.C. 202, 209, 588 S.E.2d 136, 140 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œ[T]he mere fact that an arbitration clause might apply to matters beyond the express scope of the underlying contract does not alone imply that the clause should apply to every dispute between the parties.â€).Â  
The court of appeals also rejected this overly simplified approach.Â  Relying heavily on the fact that Aiken had paid his loans in full when the employeesâ€™ tortious acts occurred, the court of appeals found that there was no significant relationship between Aikenâ€™s tort claims and his loan agreements with World Finance.Â  See Aiken, 367 S.C. at 182-83, 623 S.E.2d at 876.Â  Therefore, the court held that Aikenâ€™s claims were not within the scope of the arbitration agreement found in the underlying contract.[3]Â  
Although we agree with the ultimate conclusion reached by the court of appeals, we do not consider the timing of the employeesâ€™ tortious conduct to be relevant to the arbitrability of Aikenâ€™s claim.Â  Instead, we pronounce a more definitive rule for determining whether a significant relationship exists between a dispute between parties to a contract and the underlying contract, thereby implicating an arbitration agreement in the contract.Â  Because even the most broadly-worded arbitration agreements still have limits founded in general principles of contract law, this Court will refuse to interpret any arbitration agreement as applying to outrageous torts that are unforeseeable to a reasonable consumer in the context of normal business dealings.[4]Â  
In this case, we find the theft of Aikenâ€™s personal information by World Finance employees to be outrageous conduct that Aiken could not possibly have foreseen when he agreed to do business with World Finance.Â  Consequently, in signing the agreement to arbitrate, Aiken could not possibly have been agreeing to provide an alternative forum for settling claims arising from this wholly unexpected tortious conduct.[5]Â  Accordingly, we hold that Aikenâ€™s claims for unanticipated and unforeseeable tortious conduct by World Financeâ€™s employees are not within the scope of the arbitration agreement with World Finance.[6]Â  
In establishing the line for claims subject to arbitration, this Court does not seek to exclude all intentional torts from the scope of arbitration.Â  For instance, the parties in the instant case stipulate that a tort claim which essentially alleges a breach of the underlying contract (e.g., breach of fiduciary duty, misappropriation of trade secrets) would be within the contemplation of the parties in agreeing to arbitrate.Â  We only seek to distinguish those outrageous torts, which although factually related to the performance of the contract, are legally distinct from the contractual relationship between the parties.Â  See McMahon v. RMS Electronics, Inc., 618 F. Supp. 189, 191 (S.D.N.Y. 1985).Â  
Our decision today does not ignore the state and federal policies favoring arbitration as a less formal and more efficient means for resolving disputes.Â  See Lackey v. Green Tree Fin. Corp., 330 S.C. 388, 396, 498 S.E.2d 898, 902 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  This Court merely seeks, as a matter of public policy, to promote the procurement of arbitration in a commercially reasonable manner.Â  To interpret an arbitration agreement to apply to actions completely outside the expectations of the parties would be inconsistent with this goal.Â 
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm as modified the decision of the court of appeals denying World Financeâ€™s motion to compel arbitration.
MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J. concurring in a separate opinion.


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the majority that the first issue is not preserved, and I concur in the decision holding that Aikenâ€™s tort claims are without the partiesâ€™ arbitration agreement.Â  I write separately, however, as I do not agree with the majorityâ€™s decision to the extent it finds that identity theft is not foreseeable.Â  See Huggins v. Citibank, N.A., 355 S.C. 329, 585 S.E.2d 275 (2003) (â€œ[The Court] is greatly concerned with the rampant growth of identity theft and financial fraud . . . .â€).Â  I would hold that parties executing a lender-borrower contract containing an arbitration provision do not intend identity theft to be within the ambit of the contract, and further that there is no â€œsignificant relationshipâ€ between the loan agreement and the allegations of Aikenâ€™s tort claims.Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 553 S.E.2d 110 (2001).
With this reservation, I concur.

[1] The now-former employees pleaded guilty for these offenses and were sentenced in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina.
[2] Courts typically characterize arbitration agreements purporting to govern disputes â€œarising out of or related toâ€ the underlying contract between the parties as â€œbroadâ€ arbitration clauses encompassing a wide range of issues.Â  See J.J. Ryan & Sons, Inc. v. Rhone Poulenc Textile, S.A., 863 F.2d 315, 321 (4th Cir. 1988).Â  
[3] While relying mainly on the â€œsignificant relationshipâ€ test to determine whether a claim is arbitrable, the court of appeals also seemed to endorse an additional test used specifically for determining whether a tort claim is arbitrable.Â  The court cited to Zabinski for the proposition that tort claims were within the scope of arbitration when â€œthe particular tort claim is so interwoven with the contract that it could not stand alone.â€Â  Aiken, 367 S.C. at 181, 623 S.E.2d at 875 (citing 346 S.C. at 597 n.4, 553 S.E.2d at 119 n.4).Â  We note that the Zabinski articulation of this test is found in a footnote containing references to tests used by â€œother jurisdictionsâ€ and therefore has not been adopted by this Court as a separate test applicable specifically to tort claims in this context. 
[4] Because the parties do not raise the issue of whether any arbitration agreement purporting to apply to such outrageous and unforeseen tortious acts is unconscionable, we leave this determination for another day.
[5] See also Towles v. United Healthcare Corp., 338 S.C. 29, 41, 524 S.E.2d 839, 846 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œWhen a party invokes an arbitration agreement after the contractual relationship between the parties has ended, the partiesâ€™ intent governs whether the clauseâ€™s authority extends beyond the termination of the contract.â€ (citing Zandford v. Prudential-Bache Sec., Inc., 112 F.3d 723, 727 (4th Cir. 1997))).Â  
[6] Additionally, we are somewhat puzzled by the concurring opinionâ€™s characterization of identity theft as a foreseeable tort.Â  Although this Court indicated its concern over the â€œrampant growth of identity theftâ€ in Huggins v. Citibank, N.A., 355 S.C. 329, 334, 585 S.E.2d 275, 277 (2003), the rule we set forth today is based on the concept of the expectations of a â€œreasonable man,â€ a standard deeply rooted in tort law.Â  Therefore, a determination of foreseeability under the rule is to be made from the standpoint of the injured party; not this Court.Â  We do not believe that this Court should proclaim that fraudulent acts such as identity theft are foreseeable in the course of normal business dealings.Â Â

title: Ex Parte: GEICO
description: Government Employeeâ€™s Insurance Company appeals the family courtâ€™s denial of its petition to join or intervene in a family court action involving the validity of a common law marriage.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				Ex Parte:
				Government Employeeâ€™s Insurance Company, 
				Appellant,
				In Re:
				Ronnie Cooper, 
				Respondent,
				v.
				Yolanda Goethe, 
				Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Beaufort County
Â Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26315
Heard December 6, 2006 - Filed April 23, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Margaret M. Fanning, of Wilson & Heyward, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Peter George Currence, of McDougall & Self, of Columbia, for Respondent Cooper.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: We certified this case for review from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â Â  Government Employeeâ€™s Insurance Company (â€œGEICOâ€) appeals the family courtâ€™s denial of its petition to join or intervene in Ronnie Cooperâ€™s (â€œCooperâ€) family court proceeding involving the validity of his common law marriage with Yolanda Goethe (â€œGoetheâ€).Â  We affirm

Factual / procedural Background
GEICO brought a declaratory judgment action against Cooper to determine the partiesâ€™ rights pursuant to an automobile insurance policy issued to Goethe.Â  Specifically, Cooper claims he is entitled to stack underinsured motorist coverage provided by the Goethe policy on the grounds that he is a Class I insured.Â  GEICO denied Cooperâ€™s claim, alleging that Cooper is not a Class I insured because he is neither the spouse nor resident relative of Goethe.
After GEICO denied Cooperâ€™s claim to stack coverage, Cooper filed an action in family court seeking an order validating his common law marriage to Goethe since 1991. GEICO petitioned the family court to permit it to join the action pursuant to Rule 19, SCRCP, or to intervene pursuant to Rule 24, SCRCP.Â  As grounds supporting its motion, GEICO alleged that the family courtâ€™s decision on the partiesâ€™ common law marriage would impact GEICOâ€™s ability to protect its interests under the insurance policy issued to Goethe. 
After a hearing on the petition, the family court denied GEICOâ€™s motion.Â  The family court found that GEICO was not a necessary party for joinder and did not have standing to intervene.Â  GEICO appeals raising the following issues for review:

	
		
			I.  
			Did the family court err in denying GEICOâ€™s 
			petition to join Cooperâ€™s family court action regarding the validity 
			of a common law marriage?  
			
 
		
		
			II.  
			Did the family court err in denying GEICOâ€™s 
			petition to intervene in Cooperâ€™s family court action regarding the 
			validity of a common law marriage?
		
	


Standard of Review
The decision to grant or deny a motion to join an action pursuant to Rule 19, SCRCP, or intervene in an action pursuant to Rule 24, SCRCP, lies within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  See Berkeley Elec. Coop., Inc. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 302 S.C. 186, 189, 394 S.E.2d 712, 714 (1990); and Hunnicutt v. Richenbacker, 268 S.C. 511, 517, 234 S.E.2d 887, 890 (1977).Â  â€œThis Court will not disturb the lower courtâ€™s decision on appeal unless a manifest abuse of discretion is found resulting in an error of law.Â  Moreover, the error of law must be so opposed to the lower courtâ€™s sound discretion as to amount to a deprivation of the legal rights of the party.â€Â  Jeter v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Transp., 369 S.C. 433, 633 S.E.2d 143, 146 (2006).Â  

Law / Analysis
I.Â  Joinder
GEICO argues that the family court erred in denying its petition for joinder pursuant to Rule 19, SCRCP.Â  We disagree.

	
	Rule 19(a), SCRCP provides in pertinent part:
	A person who is subject to service of process and whose joinder will not deprive the court of jurisdiction over the subject matter of the action shall be joined as a party in the action if (1) in his absence complete relief cannot be accorded among those already parties, or (2)
	he claims an interest relating to the subject of the action and is so situated that the disposition of the action in his absence may (i) as a practical matter impair or impede his ability to protect that interest or (ii) leave any of the persons already parties subject to a substantial risk of incurring double, multiple, or otherwise inconsistent obligations by reason of his claimed interest.Â Â Â  
	

Id. (emphasis added).Â  â€œThe principle behind this Rule is that whenever possible persons materially interested in the action should be joined so that they may be heard and a complete determination had.â€Â  Rule 19, SCRCP note.Â  
GEICO alleges that Cooper and Goethe commenced the family court action to bolster Cooperâ€™s position against GEICO in the pending litigation involving Cooperâ€™s rights under the Goethe policy.Â  The crux of GEICOâ€™s argument for joinder is that failure to join it as a party in the family court action will perpetuate a fraud on the court and ultimately impair GEICOâ€™s ability to protect its interests under the insurance policy.Â  We find that although GEICO may be affected by the outcome of the family court action, its interest is insufficient to meet the requirements for joinder pursuant to Rule 19(a)(2)(i), SCRCP. 
GEICO relies on Rule 19(a)(2)(i), SCRCP to support its motion for joinder.Â  This provision of the rule allows a party to join an action where â€œhe claims an interest relating to the subject of the action and is so situated that the disposition of the action in his absence may as a practical matter impair or impede his ability to protect that interest.â€Â  Id.Â  In the instant case, however, GEICO has failed to show that it has an interest relating to the subject of the action.Â  The family court action involves the subject of whether Cooper and Goethe are common law married, and GEICOâ€™s economic interest under the Goethe policy is merely tangential to the family court action.Â  While the existence of a common law marriage may impact GEICOâ€™s liability to Cooper, GEICO has no real interest in the subject matter before the family court. Â 
Furthermore, the family court did not err in finding that GEICO was not a necessary party to the family court action.Â  This Court has interpreted Rule 19, SCRCP to require that a party be a â€œnecessary partyâ€ to be joined in an action pursuant to the rule.Â  See Slatton v. Slatton, 289 S.C. 128, 130, 345 S.E.2d 248, 249 (1986).Â  â€œA necessary party is one whose rights must be ascertained and settled before the rights of the parties to the action can be determined.â€Â  Id.Â Â  
In this case, the family court had no need to ascertain or settle GEICOâ€™s rights before it determined the rights of Cooper and Goethe in their action to recognize their common law marriage.Â  GEICO argues that the family courtâ€™s reliance on this definition of necessary party as defined in Slatton is misplaced because it is based on a repealed section of the South Carolina Code.Â  See Slatton, 289 S.C. at 130 n.1, 345 S.E.2d at 249 n.1.Â  Although Slatton does not interpret Rule 19, SCRCP, we note (1) that the repealed statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-200 (1976), upon which the definition of â€œnecessary partyâ€ is based was replaced with Rule 19, SCRCP, (2) that this Court recognized the continued application of the definition despite the repeal of the statute, and (3) that the Court decided Slatton after the adoption of Rule 19, SCRCP.Â  Accordingly, the definition of necessary party as used in Slatton remains an accurate articulation of the law of South Carolina.Â  
The dissent argues that a finding by the family court validating the existence of the common law marriage between Cooper and Geothe will increase GEICOâ€™s burden of proof in its pending declaratory judgment action, thereby impairing GEICOâ€™s ability to protect its economic interest in the payment of insurance benefits.Â  This argument misses the mark.Â  First, GEICOâ€™s interest is merely peripheral to the subject matter of the family court action.Â  Second, while it is true that GEICO may need to meet an increased burden of proof, GEICO maintains the ability to protect any economic interest which may be affected by the family court action.Â  Although the rules of joinder and intervention are to be liberally construed, permitting GEICO to join in a family court action in which it has no real interest stretches beyond liberal constructionÂ  and creates a situation in which any party with a remotely tangential interest will be allowed to interject themselves into pending litigation.Â  We do not interpret the rules to allow such manipulation.
For these reasons, we hold that the family court did not err in denying GEICOâ€™s petition to join the family court action pursuant to Rule 19, SCRCP.Â  Â Â  Â Â 
II.Â  Intervention
GEICO argues that the family court erred in denying its petition to intervene pursuant to Rule 24, SCRCP.Â  We disagree.

	Rule 24(a), SCRCP provides:
	Upon timely application anyone shall be permitted to intervene in an action: (1) when a statute confers an unconditional right to intervene; or (2) when the applicant claims an interest relating to the property or transaction which is the subject of the action and he is so situated that the disposition of the action may as a practical matter impair or impede his ability to protect that interest, unless the applicantâ€™s interest is adequately represented by existing parties.

Generally, the rules of intervention should be liberally construed where judicial economy will be promoted by declaring the rights of all affected parties.Â  Berkeley Elec. Coop., 302 S.C. at 189, 394 S.E.2d at 714.Â  Accordingly, the Court should consider the practical implications of a decision denying or allowing intervention.Â  Id.Â  Â Â Â  However, a party must have standing to intervene in an action pursuant to Rule 24, SCRCP.Â  Bailey v. Bailey, 312 S.C. 454, 458, 441 S.E.2d 325, 327 (1994).Â  A party has standing if the party has a personal stake in the subject matter of a lawsuit and is a â€œreal party in interest.â€ Â Id.Â  â€œA real party in interest . . . is one who has a real, actual, material or substantial interest in the subject matter of the action, as distinguished from one who has only a nominal, formal, or technical interest in, or connection with, the action.â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).
We find that GIECO does not have â€œan interest relating to the property or transaction which is the subject of the actionâ€ as required by Rule 24(a)(2), SCRCP.Â  Additionally, we hold that the family court correctly found GEICO lacked standing because GEICO does not have an interest in the subject matter of the family court action.Â  Stated differently, GEICO has no real interest in whether Cooper and Goethe have a valid common law marriage.Â  GEICOâ€™s interest is in the financial implications of the family courtâ€™s decision, which is peripheral to the subject matter before the court.Â  This interest is insufficient to warrant GEICOâ€™s intervention in Cooperâ€™s family court action under Rule 24(a)(2), SCRCP.Â  
GEICO claims that this Courtâ€™s decision in Bailey is inapplicable and distinguishable from the case at hand.Â  In Bailey, the former wifeâ€™s prior attorneys moved to intervene in a divorce proceeding for the purposes of challenging the partiesâ€™ settlement agreement.Â  Id. at 454, 441 S.E.2d at 325.Â Â  The Court found that the attorneys did not have standing to intervene because the order directing payment from the former husband to the former wife in care of attorneys did not direct payment of fees and that the attorneys could litigate fee disputes in an alternative forum.Â  Id.Â  The Court further stated that intervention is only appropriate where the party seeking intervention has â€œa real proprietary interest in the subject matter of the proceedings;â€ an interest which is merely â€œperipheral and not the real interest at stakeâ€ will not warrant intervention.Â  Id.
GEICOâ€™s purported distinction is not persuasive.Â  Similarly to the analysis in Bailey, we find that the subject matter of the family court action in the instant case is the validity of a common law marriage, which does not involve a determination of insurance benefits.Â  Accordingly, GEICO does not have standing to intervene in the family court action because it does not have an interest sufficiently related to the subject matter of the action.Â  
For these reasons, we hold that the family court did not err in denying GEICOâ€™s petition to intervene in Cooperâ€™s family court action.

Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the family courtâ€™s order denying GEICOâ€™s petition to join or intervene in Cooperâ€™s family court action.
MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a 
separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent, and would hold the family court judge erred in declining GEICOâ€™s petition for joinder under Rule 19, SCRCP, and that he abused his discretion in denying GEICOâ€™s petition to intervene under Rule 24, SCRCP.
Respondent Cooper claimed that he was a Class I insured under an automobile policy appellant GEICO issued to respondent Goethe.Â  GEICO denied Cooperâ€™s claim, and brought a declaratory judgment action in circuit court to determine Cooperâ€™s rights, if any, under the Goethe policy.Â  By filing this circuit court action, GEICO undertook the burden of proving, by a preponderance of the evidence, that Cooper was not a Class I insured under Goetheâ€™s policy.Â  Vermont Mut. Ins. Co. v. Singleton, 316 S.C. 5, 446 S.E.2d 417 (1994).
After GEICOâ€™s circuit court suit was commenced, Cooper brought a family court action against Goethe to establish that they had entered a common law marriage.Â  Cooperâ€™s declaratory judgment suit was brought pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-1-520 (1985) which provides:

	When the validity of a marriage shall be denied or doubted by either of the parties, 
	[1] the other may institute a suit for affirming the marriage and, upon due proof of the validity thereof, it shall be decreed to be valid 
	and such decree shall be conclusive upon all persons concerned.
	(emphasis supplied).

For purposes of this appeal, the critical part of Â§ 20-1-520 is the last phrase: â€œupon due proof of the validity thereof, [the marriage] shall be decreed to be valid and such decree shall be conclusive upon all persons concerned.â€Â  An adjudication of a valid marriage under this statute is â€œconclusive upon the worldâ€ and can only be attacked by a non-party to the judgment upon grounds of fraud.Â  Headen v. Pope & Talbot, Inc., 252 F.2d 739 (3rd Cir. 1958).Â  Accordingly, if GEICO is not permitted to participate in this family court adjudication, and that court determines that Cooper and Goethe are lawfully married, GEICO will no longer be required to prove in circuit court that there is no marriage by a preponderance of the evidence, but will instead need to prove, by clear and convincing evidence, that Cooper procured the family court judgment by fraud.Â  See Hagy v. Pruitt, 339 S.C. 425, 529 S.E.2d 714 (2000).Â  Keeping this increased burden of proof in mind, I turn to the issues raised by GEICO in this appeal.
A.Â  Rule 19, SCRCP
GEICO first contends the family court erred in denying its petition for joinder under Rule 19, SCRCP.Â  I agree.Â  Rule 19(a) provides:

	(a)Â  Person to Be Joined if Feasible.Â  A person who is subject to service of process and whose joinder will not deprive the court of jurisdiction over the subject matter of the action shall be joined as a party in the action if (1) in his absence complete relief cannot be accorded among those already parties, or (2) he claims an interest relating to the subject of the action and is so situated that the disposition of the action in his absence may (i) as a practical matter impair or impede his ability to protect that interest or (ii) leave any of the persons already parties subject to a substantial risk of incurring double, multiple, or otherwise inconsistent obligations by reason of his claimed interest.Â  If he has not been so joined, the court shall order that he be made a party.Â  If he should join as a plaintiff but refuses to do so, he may be made a defendant, or, in a proper case, an involuntary plaintiff.

Rule 19(a) is the same as Rule 19(a), FRCP,[2] and expresses the principle that â€œwhenever possible persons materially interested in the action should be joined so that they may be heard and a complete determination had.â€Â  Notes, Rule 19, SCRCP.
The majority first holds that GEICO has no real interest in the family court action as its economic interest in the Goethe policy is â€œmerely tangential.â€ In my view, GEICO â€œclaims an interest relating to the subject of the [family court] action,â€ whether there is a valid marriage, which is all that Rule 19(a)(2) requires.Â  Further, as explained above, should the family court hold that Cooper and Goethe have entered a common law marriage, that finding will be conclusive against GEICO, unless it can prove by clear and convincing evidence, that the judgment was procured by fraud.Â  I would find GEICOâ€™s exclusion from the family court suit may â€œas a practical matter impair or impede [its] ability to protect that interest.â€ 
Moreover, since we have no state precedent interpreting Rule 19, SCRCP, we may look to federal precedent.[3]Â  See Gardner v. Newsome Chevrolet-Buick, 304 S.C. 328, 404 S.E.2d 200 (1991).Â  I note that Rule 19(a), SCRCP, does not contain the term â€œnecessary party.â€Â  That term was intentionally omitted when Rule 19, FRCP, was amended in 1966, and South Carolina chose to model its rule on the amended version of the federal rules.Â  As the commentators explain, the term was omitted in order to encourage courts to make pragmatic decisions concerning joinder.Â  See Wright Miller Kane 7 Federal Practice and Procedure Â§ 1601.Â  
Rule 19(a)(2), SCRCP asks first, whether the party seeking joinder claims an interest relating to the subject of the action, which I would find GEICO does.Â  Second, it asks whether that party is in such a position that disposition of the action in his absence may, as a practical matter, impair or impede his ability to protect that interest.Â  I would find GEICO meets this criterion.
I would hold that GEICO has met the requirement for Rule 19(a) joinder, and that the family court erred in failing to grant its petition.
B.Â  Rule 24, SCRCP
GEICO next argues that the family court erred in denying its request to intervene made pursuant to Rule 24, SCRCP.Â  I agree.
Rule 24(a)(2) provides for intervention of right:

	when the applicant claims an interest relating to the property or transaction which is the subject of the action and he is so situated that the disposition of the action may as a practical matter impair or impede his ability to protect that interest, unless the applicantâ€™s interest is adequately represented by existing parties. 
	

The decision to grant or deny a Rule 24(a)(2) motion is reviewed under an abuse of discretion standard, and each case is viewed in the context of its unique facts and circumstances.Â  Berkely Elec. Coop., Inc. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 302 S.C. 186, 394 S.E.2d 712 (1990).Â  â€œWe interpret [Rule 24(a)(2)] to permit liberal intervention particularly where, as here, judicial economy will be promoted by the declaration of the rights of all parties who may be affected.â€Â  Id.Â  In determining whether intervention is warranted, â€œwe must consider the pragmatic consequences of a decision to permit or deny intervention and avoid setting up rigid applications of [the rule].â€Â  Id.
For the reasons given in the preceding section, I would find that GEICO meets the intervention criteria of Rule 24(a)(2).Â  Furthermore, I cannot reconcile the standing discussion in Bailey v. Bailey, 312 S.C. 454, 441 S.E.2d 325 (1994) with my understanding of Rule 24.Â  As I read Bailey, there is no discussion of Rule 24(a)(2), and it is patent that the Court conducted no rule-based analysis.Â  In my opinion, if a party meets the requirements of Rule 24(a)(2), that is, it is entitled to intervene as a matter of right, then it ipso facto has â€œstanding.â€Â  Bailey may have reached the correct result, but its discussion of intervention as an issue of â€œstandingâ€ rather than as a matter governed by Rule 24, SCRCP, is simply misdirected.Â  I would hold the family court abused its discretion in denying GEICOâ€™s request to intervene under Rule 24 (a)(2).

Conclusion
I would reverse, and allow GEICO to participate in the family court action.Â  Under the somewhat unusual facts and procedural posture of this appeal, such a â€œpragmaticâ€ result will allow the issue of a common law marriage to be resolved in a single suit. 

[1] Given Ms. Goetheâ€™s non-participation in this appeal, it would appear that neither she nor Cooper truly denies or doubts the marriage.
[2] And differs significantly from that of former S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-200, which is the basis for the definition of â€œnecessary partyâ€ in Slatton v. Slatton, 289 S.C. 128, 345 S.E.2d 248 (1986).Â  That statute provided:

	Â§ 15-5-200.Â  New parties; interpleader.
	The court may determine any controversy between the parties before it, when it can be done without prejudice to the rights of others, or by saving their rights.Â  But when a complete determination of the controversy cannot be had without the presence of other parties, the court must cause them to be brought in.Â  And when, in an action for the recovery of real or personal property, a person not a party to the action but having an interest in the subject thereof makes application to the court to be made a party it may order him to be brought in by proper amendment.
	A defendant against whom an action is pending upon a contract or for specific real or personal property may, at any time before answer, upon affidavit that a person not a party to the action and without collusion by him makes against him a demand for the same debt or property and upon due notice to such person and the adverse party, apply to the court for an order to substitute such a person in his place and discharge him from liability to either party on his depositing in court the amount of the debt or delivering the property, or its value, to such a person as the court may direct.Â  The court may, in its discretion, make such an order.

[3]Unlike the majority, I do not read Slatton as interpreting, defining, or applying Rule 19. See Slatton, fn. 1:Â  â€œAfter the trial of this action, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-200 (1976) was repealed by Act. [sic] No. 100 of 1985.Â  See Rule 19, SCRCP.â€

title: State v. Turner
description: This case involves the issues of whether the trial court erred by (1) admitting identification testimony where the photographic line-up was unduly suggestive, (2) sending written charges to the jury, and (3) limiting the cross-examination of the victim by not allowing questions regarding her schizophrenia diagnosis, her treatment, and her medications.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Brandon Turner, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26316
Heard March 20, 2007 - Filed April 23, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				J. Falkner Wilkes, of Craven & Wilkes, of Greenville, for appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
				Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant was found guilty on charges of armed robbery and assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN).Â  He was sentenced to fifteen years imprisonment for armed robbery and ten years imprisonment for ABHAN.Â  The terms were to be served concurrently.Â  His appeal was certified from the Court of Appeals.
Appellant was identified as the robber of a pizza delivery woman.Â  On a sunny afternoon, the victim arrived at a house to deliver a pizza but no one answered the door.Â  She heard the back door of the house slam so she went behind the house.Â  She saw two black males coming towards her.Â  The male walking in front, later identified as appellant, looked angry.Â  The victim stated he came towards her and pulled a gun from behind his back and demanded money.Â  The assailant pulled the victim by her shirt towards the back of the home.Â  The victim told the assailant to take her money and he did so by pulling money out of her pocket.Â  The victim was then told to lie down on the ground.Â  While on the ground, the assailant held the gun beside her head.Â  After a few moments, the assailant and the other male left.Â  Based on the victimâ€™s identification of appellant as her assailant, appellant was found guilty of armed robbery and ABHAN.
ISSUES

	
		
			I. 
			Did the court err by admitting identification 
			testimony where the photographic line-up was unduly suggestive?
			
 
		
		
			II. 
			Did the court err by sending written charges to the 
			jury?
			
 
		
		
			III. 
			Did the court err by limiting the cross-examination 
			of the victim by not allowing questions regarding her schizophrenia 
			diagnosis, her treatment, and her medications?
		
	

DISCUSSION
I. Identification
Prior to trial, a suppression hearing was held regarding the victimâ€™s pre-trial identification of appellant.Â  The victim testified about how the crimes occurred and described her assailant by stating he was â€œfairly tall,â€ â€œbuilt pretty good,â€ did not have a shirt on, and he â€œwas dark.â€Â  She stated she went to the law enforcement center the same day to look at pictures in a line-up.Â  She stated Investigator Wes Smith did not instruct her she must choose someone and did not tell her that the person who attacked her was in the line-up.Â  She stated he told her to only choose someone if she was sure.Â  She testified she chose appellant as her assailant.
Investigator Smith testified at the suppression hearing.Â  He stated appellant voluntarily came in and had his photograph taken.Â  Smith placed appellantâ€™s picture with five other pictures of similar-looking males and showed the pictures to the victim.Â  Prior to presenting the pictures, Smith told the victim that the suspects may or may not be one of the people in the photographs and that he wanted her to look at the photographs and identify someone only if she was sure beyond a reasonable doubt.Â  He stated she indicated she understood his instructions.Â  The victim identified appellant after looking only momentarily at the pictures.
On cross-examination, Investigator Smith stated he pulled the other five pictures from his photographic database and that he tried to choose people that had a similarly shaped face with some facial hair because the assailant had some facial hair.Â  He stated he did not pay attention to the contrast of the background but just tried to choose people who looked similar.Â  He admitted that four pictures had purple backgrounds and two pictures had gray backgrounds.Â  He stated he did not have any choice in the use of the gray background in appellantâ€™s picture.
Following the testimony, appellant objected that the photo line-up was suggestive in that only two of the persons in the line-up can be identified as dark-skinned due to the use of the light background.Â  The court ruled that, while there were some differences in the photographs, there will always be differences.Â  The court ruled the line-up was not unduly suggestive.
At trial, the victim testified regarding the photo line-up.Â  Over appellantâ€™s objection, the photo line-up was admitted into evidence.Â  Following that exchange, the victim then identified appellant as her assailant.
Appellant argues the line-up was suggestive because, due to the different color background, appellantâ€™s picture stands out from all but one other picture.[1]
A criminal defendant may be deprived of due process of law by an identification procedure which is unnecessarily suggestive and conducive to irreparable mistaken identification.Â  State v. Traylor, 360 S.C. 74, 600 S.E.2d 523 (2004).[2]Â  An in-court identification of an accused is inadmissible if a suggestive out-of-court identification procedure created a very substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.Â  Id.
The United States Supreme Court has developed a two-prong inquiry to determine the admissibility of an out-of-court identification.Â  Id. (citing Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972)).Â  A court must ascertain whether the identification process was unduly suggestive.Â  Id.Â  Even assuming an identification procedure is suggestive, it need not be excluded so long as, under all the circumstances, the identification was reliable notwithstanding the suggestiveness.Â  State v. Traylor, supra.Â  The inquiry must focus upon whether, under the totality of the circumstances, there was a substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.Â  Id. Â The following factors should be considered in evaluating the totality of the circumstances to determine the likelihood of a misidentification: Â (1) the witnessâ€™s opportunity to view the perpetrator at the time of the crime, (2) the witnessâ€™s degree of attention, (3) the accuracy of the witnessâ€™s prior description of the perpetrator, (4) the level of certainty demonstrated by the witness at the confrontation, and (5) the length of time between the crime and the confrontation.Â  Id.
The photo line-up here is not unduly suggestive.Â  Despite the variation in the background colors, appellant does not stand out in comparison with the other individuals in the line-up.Â  All six men have facial hair and all appear to be â€œbuilt,â€ as described by the victim.Â  The gray background does not make appellantâ€™s complexion seem darker than the complexions of the other four individuals who have purple backgrounds.Â  Accordingly, the photo line-up is not unduly suggestive.Â  See, e.g., United States v. Lincoln, 494 F.2d 833 (9th Cir. 1974) (fact appellantâ€™s photo was in color and photos of the other individuals in the line-up were in black and white is not impermissibly suggestive); Burgess v. State, 827 So.2d 134 (Ala. Crim. App. 1998), affâ€™d, 827 So.2d 193 (Ala. 2000) (fact appellant was wearing a dark jacket or that he was standing before a blank wall while others were standing in front of a curtain did not render line-up unduly suggestive); State v. Holmes, 931 So.2d 1157 (La. App. 4th Cir. 2006) (fact appellantâ€™s photo was placed in the top center position of a line-up and had a lighter background shade than the other photos did not render the line-up unduly suggestive); State v. Gullett, 633 S.W.2d 454 (Mo. App. 1982) (fact appellantâ€™s photo was in color and was slightly larger than other photos, which were in black and white, did not render the line-up unduly suggestive).
Regardless of whether the photo line-up was suggestive, the identification was reliable.Â  The victim had an ample opportunity to view her assailant at the time of the crime.Â  The crime occurred outside during a sunny afternoon.Â  The victim had a full facial view of him while he asked her questions.Â  Her degree of attention was manifested by the description she gave police.Â  Her description included the details that the assailant was tall, was built, was not wearing a shirt, was dark, and had some facial hair.Â  This description she gave police matched the photograph she chose from the line-up.Â  The victim had a high degree of certainty regarding her identification because she looked at the photographs only momentarily before identifying appellant.Â  Finally, the time between the crime and the confrontation was very short as the line-up occurred on the same day as the crime.Â  All of these factors point to the reliability of the victimâ€™s identification of appellant as her assailant.Â  Even assuming the line-up was suggestive due to the different background colors, there is not a substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly admitted the identification.
II. Submission of Written Charge to the Jury
At the conclusion of the courtâ€™s charge to the jury, the court informed the jury they would receive a written copy of his charge in the jury room.Â  Following the attorneysâ€™ review of the charge, appellant objected.Â  The court submitted the written charge to the jury without addressing appellantâ€™s objection.Â  Appellant argues the trial court erred by sending the jury charge in written form to the jury.
A trial court may, in its discretion, submit its instructions on the law to the jury in writing.Â  Cf. Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 529 S.E.2d 528 (2000) (an appellate court will not reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding jury instructions unless the trial court abused its discretion); see State v. McAvoy, 417 S.E.2d 489 (N.C. 1992) (trial court has inherent authority, in its discretion, to submit its instructions on the law to the jury in writing).
Further, appellant has not shown how he was prejudiced by the courtâ€™s alleged error.Â  See State v. Douglas, 369 S.C. 424, 632 S.E.2d 845 (2006) (appellate courts will not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result).Â  Although no error was made in the instant case, we remind the Bench that the submission of written instructions to the jury is not appropriate for every case.Â  While the written submission of the jury instructions could aid a jury in properly applying the law to the facts before it, this practice should be carefully exercised by the Bench.
III.Â  Limitation of Cross-examination
Prior to trial, the State moved to preclude appellant from using the terms â€œschizophreniaâ€ or referring to that particular diagnosis during appellantâ€™s cross-examination of the victim.Â  Before determining whether the testimony should be limited, the court allowed an in camera cross-examination of the victim.Â  The victim testified she has schizophrenia and that she takes Prozac and Risperdal for that condition.Â  She stated that if she does not take her medication she becomes confused, hears voices, and has problems with her memory.Â  However, she indicated she was taking her medication on the date of the crimes.Â  The court asked her if she had been without her medicine either during the time of the crimes or anytime recently and the victim stated she had not.
The court found there would be very little that would assist the jury in evaluating her ability to recall what happened or her credibility.Â  The court felt it would require speculation on the juryâ€™s part to connect the medical testimony to her ability to testify truthfully.Â  The court stated there was a significant potential for unfair prejudice because it may cause the jury to decide the case on an improper basis.
Appellant then requested that he be allowed to ask the following questions:Â  Do you take medication?Â  What do you take?Â  If you do not take your medication over a long period of time, what is your condition?Â  The court stated that the identification of the medicines is prejudicial because it is medication that people associate with mental illness and that the naming of those medicines would not add any probative value.Â  The court asked the questions in camera and concluded that questioning the victim regarding the names of her medicines should not be allowed under Rule 403, SCRE.Â  The court then allowed the State to reopen its direct examination of the victim.
On direct, the victim stated she took medication and that she was taking it on the day of the robbery.Â  On cross-examination, the victim indicated that if she does not take her medication over a period of time she gets confused, is forgetful, and can hear voices.
Appellant argues the court erred by not allowing him to question the victim regarding her diagnosis of schizophrenia and the names of her medications.
The right to a meaningful cross-examination of an adverse witness is included in the defendantâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to confront his accusers.Â  State v. Saltz, 346 S.C. 114, 551 S.E.2d 240 (2001). Â This does not mean, however, that trial courts conducting criminal trials lose their usual discretion to limit the scope of cross-examination.Â  Id.Â  On the contrary, trial courts retain wide latitude, insofar as the Confrontation Clause is concerned, to impose reasonable limits on such cross-examination based on concerns about, among other things, prejudice, confusion of the issues, or interrogation that is only marginally relevant.Â  Id.
The courtâ€™s limitation on the cross-examination of the victim was reasonable.Â  Because the victim was taking her medication at the time of the robbery and at the time of the trial, her schizophrenia diagnosis and the types of medications she was taking were irrelevant to her ability to truthfully recall the events.Â  Further, appellant has not shown why the specific information was needed or any nexus between the medications the victim was taking and any alleged misidentification of appellant.
In any event, the victim testified she takes medication and what happens if she does not take her medication.Â  The jury was made aware that the victim is required to be medicated and that if she does not take her medication she is confused, forgetful, and can hear voices.Â  Although appellant could not elicit testimony about the victimâ€™s specific mental illness and her specific medication, the gist of what appellant wished to elicit from her testimony was elicited.Â  Therefore, appellant has not shown he was unfairly prejudiced by the limitation.Â  Cf. State v. Mizzell, 349 S.C. 326, 563 S.E.2d 315 (2002) (if the defendant establishes he was unfairly prejudiced by the limitation on cross-examination, it is reversible error).Â  The court did not abuse its discretion by limiting the victimâ€™s cross-examination.

CONCLUSION
We find the photo line-up in this case was not unduly suggestive and, even assuming the line-up was suggestive, we find the victimâ€™s identification of appellant to be reliable.Â  We further find the trial court did not abuse its discretion by submitting his written charge to the jury.Â  Finally, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion by limiting appellantâ€™s cross-examination of the victim.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


[1]Appellant further argues that the fact the victim was shown the photo line-up two more times in court prior to her in-court identification of him multiplies the suggestive impact of the photo line-up.Â  However, when the victim identified appellant as her assailant in the courtroom, he did not object.Â  Therefore, appellantâ€™s argument regarding the in-court identification is not preserved for review.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 587 S.E.2d 691 (2003) (issues not raised and ruled upon in the trial court will not be considered on appeal).
[2]Cert. denied, 543 U.S. 1063 (2005).
