title: Majors v. South Carolina Securities Commission
description: The issues on appeal involve whether or not Appellants, Ned Majors and Tax Lien Agents, Inc., were properly order to cease and desist from selling unregistered securities.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				Ned B. Majors and Tax 
				Lien Agents, Inc., Appellants,
				v.
				South Carolina Securities Commission, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26317
Heard November 14, 2006 - Filed April 23, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John F. Beach and John J. Pringle, Jr., both of Ellis, Lawhorne & Sims, of Columbia, and Ned Majors, of Myrtle Beach, for Appellant
				Scott E. Hultstrand and Tracy A. Meyers, both of Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We certified this case from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204 (b), SCACR.Â Â  The South Carolina Securities Exchange Commission ordered Appellants, Ned Majors and Tax Lien Agents, Inc. (collectively TLA), to â€œCease and Desist Selling Unregistered Securities and Engaging in Securities Fraud.â€Â  TLA appeals, contending it is not engaged in the sale of â€œsecurities.â€ Â We disagree and therefore affirm.Â Â  
FACTUAL BACKGROUND
Ned Majors is President and sole shareholder of TLA, a South Carolina Corporation operating in Myrtle Beach since 1998.Â Â  TLAâ€™s business centers around the purchase of tax lien certificates (TLCs) at city and county tax lien auctions throughout the country.Â  Pursuant to TLAâ€™s â€œAgency Contract,â€ TLA is the purchasing agent for its Principals.Â Â  TLA Agents make all purchasing decisions, and they bid competitively for purchases at auctions by offering to accept a lower interest rate than the statutory rate to which purchasers would otherwise be entitled.Â Â  Pursuant to the contract, the Agent bids on tax liens which TLA believes have a reasonable prospect of not being redeemed.Â  The Principal agrees to pay Agent a â€œnon-refundable agency feeâ€ (between 12-25% of the principalâ€™s initial tax lien purchase amount) and grants TLA an inchoate interest of 50% ownership in any unredeemed TLCs.Â  
For each TLC purchased on a principalâ€™s behalf, the principal gives the Agent a cashiers check (or a Trust directive if using a trust) made payable to the â€œCounty Treasurer for Tax Liens.â€Â Â  The TLCs purchased are listed in the principalâ€™s name.Â  If a TLC is redeemed before its maturity date (usually 1-3 years), the Principal keeps all redemption monies, including interest and penalties; however, if the TLC is not redeemed, the Principal agrees to immediately sign papers to assign, convey and register the property, and to confirm the Agent has a 50% ownership interest in the net profit of the TLC and any resultant deed issued.Â  The Principal is required (unless agreed upon with the Agent) to commence good faith efforts to quiet the title and sell the property.Â  Although Principals have the right to select closing attorneys and quiet title, etc., they very seldom do so as the majority are absentee owners living a considerable distance from the properties; the majority use TLAâ€™s services to facilitate both the sale and quieting title.Â  Although TLA represents only one principal for each TLC purchased, an agent represents 15-20 principals (also referred to as â€œemployersâ€) at each tax sale or as many as 200 â€œemployersâ€ over a two week period.Â  
If a Principal wishes to sell TLCs, the Agent has first right of refusal, and if the TLC is sold to any other party, the third party must agree to the same contract terms as the Principal.Â  If either party elects, the underlying property which was not redeemed may be purchased by paying 50% of the average of three appraisals.Â Â  The agency contract also states that â€œwhile there are no risks in owning government sold and issued TLCs that are redeemed (paid off), there are potential down side financial risks if a TLC matures into a property deed as the underlying property market value could substantially drop during the tax lien maturity period.â€Â  
PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In September 2003, the Attorney General, acting as the South Carolina Securities Exchange Commissioner (Commissioner), entered an order for Majors and TLA to â€œCease and Desist Selling Unregistered Securities and Engaging in Securities Fraudâ€ and gave them notice of a right to a hearing.Â  The Commissioner appointed G. Marcus Knight as the Administrative Hearing Officer for the matter, and a public hearing was held on Oct 30-31, 2003.Â  Thereafter, Knight issued a detailed report and recommendation concluding that 1) the South Carolina Uniform Securities Act (the Act) applied because TLA was engaged in the sale of â€œsecuritiesâ€ as defined in that Act, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-20 (15) because its contract constituted an â€œinvestment contract.â€Â Â  The Hearing Officer also rejected TLA and Majorsâ€™ contention that the manner of issuance of the cease and desist order deprived them of due process, or that their due process rights were violated by his appointment as Hearing Officer.Â  The Hearing Officer concluded that the Commissioner should order a final Cease and Desist Order, pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-60, due to a violation of the registration requirements Â§ 35-1-810 of the Act.Â  However, the Commissioner opined the Final Order should exclude any reference to TLA making â€œmaterial misrepresentations and/or omissionsâ€ in connection with its sale of TLCs, and should not pursue any criminal or civil penalties.Â  
In February 2004, the Commissioner issued a â€œFinal Order to Cease and Desist Selling Unregistered Securities.â€Â  The Commissioner found TLAâ€™s investment opportunity constituted a â€œsecurityâ€ under the Act and also found a violation of the registration requirements Â§ 35-1-810.Â  TLA and Majors were ordered to cease and desist from offering or selling the TLC investment opportunity in or from the State of South Carolina.Â  The final order did not find TLA was engaged in securities fraud.Â  
Majors and TLA appealed to the circuit court which ruled 1) the investment opportunity offered was a security, 2) the SEC Commission had authority to issue the original cease and desist order, and 3) Majors and TLA were afforded due process in the underlying administrative proceeding.Â  
ISSUES

	
		
			1. 
			What is the proper standard of review?
			
 
		
		
			2.
			Did the SEC have authority to issue the initial 
			cease and desist order?
			
 
		
		
			3. 
			Were Appellants afforded due process in the underlying administrative proceeding?
			
 
		
		
			4. 
			Were Appellants properly ordered to cease and desist from the sale of unregistered securities in violation of the S.C. Uniform Securities Act?
		
	

1.Â  STANDARD OF REVIEW
The issue in this case involves a decision of whether TLAâ€™s sale of TLCs constitutes the sale of securities.Â  We find this is a novel question of law, such that we are free to decide the issue with no particular deference to the lower court.Â  Baggerly v. CSX Transp. Inc., 370 S.C. 362, 635 S.E.2d 97 2006), citing Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 411, 526 S.E.2d 716, 719 (2000).Â  
2.Â  INITIAL CEASE AND DESIST ORDER
TLA asserts the Commissioner had no statutory authority to enter the initial Cease and Desist order, such that the whole proceeding should be voided for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â Â  We disagree.
This issue is not one of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Subject matter jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.Â  Dove v. Gold Kist, Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 236, 442 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1994); State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005).Â  
In any event, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-60 (2004 Supp), as it read at the time this matter arose, stated in pertinent part, â€œThe Securities Commissioner may make, amend, and rescind those rules, forms, and orders, including cease and desist orders, as are necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter. . .â€Â Â Â  (emphasis supplied).Â  
As originally written, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-60 did not allow the Commissioner to issue cease and desist orders.Â  It was amended in 1992 to permit the Commissioner to make, amend, and rescind those rules, forms, and orders, including cease and desist orders. . .â€Â  1992 Act No. 451 Â§ 1, eff. June 15, 1992.Â  We find it was within the Commissionerâ€™s authority to issue the initial cease and desist order.[1]Â Â  
3.Â  DUE PROCESS
TLA and Majors next assert issuance of the cease and desist order in violated their rights to due process.Â  We disagree.
The initial cease and desist order, prior to a hearing, was permissible.Â  See Ross v. MUSC, 328 S.C. 51, 72, 492 S.E.2d 62, 69 (1997) (Article I, Â§ 22, requires an administrative agency provide notice and an opportunity to be heard, but does not require notice and an opportunity to be heard at each level of the administrative process. It mandates notice and opportunity to be heard at some point before the agency makes its final decision). 
Moreover, contrary to TLAâ€™s contention, we find no due process violation in the SEC Commissionerâ€™s role in this matter.Â  
In Ross v. MUSC, 328 S.C. 51, 492 S.E.2d 62 (1997), we held the purpose of S.C. Const., Art. I, Â§ 22 is to ensure adjudications are conducted by impartial administrative bodies.Â  Partiality exists where an adjudicator either has ex parte information as a result of prior investigation or has developed, by prior involvement with the case, a â€œwill to win.â€Â  Ross, 328 S.C. at 69, 492 S.E.2d at 72.Â Â  In Ross, we found no violation of Section 22 where MUSCâ€™s president investigated a tenured professorâ€™s conduct, terminated the professor, and then testified against him at a committee hearing.Â  We found no due process violation because the president did not later participate as an adjudicator, and he did not improperly consider ex parte information.Â  Id. at 70, 492 S.E.2d at 72.[2] 
In Garris v. Governing Board of S.C. Reinsurance Facility, 333 S.C. 432, 511 S.E.2d 48 (1998), this Court recognized, â€œthe fact that investigative, prosecutorial, and adjudicative functions are performed within the same agency, or even performed by the same persons within an agency, does not, without more, constitute a violation of due process.â€Â  333 S.C. 443, 511 S.E.2d at 54.Â  In that case, Garris was a designated insurance agent for the South Carolina Reinsurance Facility.Â  The Facility began investigating Garris, alleging irregularities in his underwriting practices.Â  After a hearing, the Governing Board of the Facility voted to revoke Garrisâ€™ status as a designated agent.Â  Garris appealed, contesting the composition of the Board which revoked his designation.Â  In Garris, the five Governing board members and one non-member of the South Carolina Reinsurance Facility attended one or more committee meetings at which Garrisâ€™ case was discussed extensively in open and executive sessions, and all six voted to revoke Garrisâ€™ status as a designated agent.Â Â  Of those six, four were members of the committees which considered the Garris matter.Â  Further, two other Governing Board members attended committee meetings and the hearing, but did not vote.Â  We concluded the procedure violated due process, stating:

	we conclude that Governing Board members who participate in the investigation or prosecution of a designated agent as a member or observer at a committee meeting may not participate as adjudicators of that agentâ€™s case at a subsequent hearing. Members who participate in the investigation or prosecution of a case must distance themselves from the adjudicatory process, and should refrain from even discussing that case with future adjudicators. 
	

333 S.C. at 446, 511 S.E.2d at 55.
Garris and Ross are distinguishable from the present case.Â  Unlike those cases, the Commissioner did, in this instance, appoint a Hearing Officer to take evidence and make a report and recommendation.Â  Further, the Commissioner did not personally participate in the gathering of the evidence before the Hearing Officer, and there is no evidence he discussed the underlying case with the Hearing Officer.Â  
Moreover, we find the power of the SEC Commissioner is akin to this Courtâ€™s power to issue an order of interim suspension of an attorney, and then, after an investigation by the Commission on Lawyer Conduct and a Report and Recommendation, issue the ultimate sanction.Â  See Kirven v. Board of Grievances and Discipline, 271 S.C. 194, 246 S.E.2d 857 (1978) (members of Board of Grievance are officers of this Court commissioned and charged by this Court with the duty of investigating alleged acts of professional misconduct on the part of their fellow members of the bar, and of reporting to this Court the proceedings of their inquiry, their findings and recommendations); Matter of Iseman, 356 S.C. 280, 588 S.E.2d 606 (2003) (Supreme Court holds ultimate authority to sanction attorneys).Â  
We find TLA and Majors have been afforded due process in this matter.Â Â  The initial cease and desist order provided them with the right to a hearing, which they requested and were afforded by an independent Hearing Officer.Â  Thereafter, they were permitted to appeal the SEC Commissionerâ€™s Final Cease and Desist Order, and were allowed to post a bond to stay enforcement of that order pending appeal.Â  The order has further been stayed by this appeal.Â  
4.Â  SECURITY
Finally, TLA asserts that its sale of TLCs does not involve the sale of a security, and it is therefore not in violation of the Act, because it was not required to register under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-810 (1987) (making it unlawful to sell any security in this state unless it is either registered or exempt).Â  We disagree.Â  The Commissioner and the circuit court properly held the sale of TLCs in this case constituted the sale of â€œsecuritiesâ€ within the meaning of the Act.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-20 (12), as it read at time of the cease and desist order, defined a â€œsecurityâ€ as, inter alia, â€œany certificate of interest or participation in any . . . investment contract . . . or, in general, any interest or instrument commonly known as a security . . .â€Â Â  
As noted by the Court of Appeals in Garrett v. Snedigar, 293 S.C. 176, 180, 359 S.E.2d 283, 285 (Ct. App. 1987), overruled on other grounds, Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 580 S.E.2d 440 (2003), â€œin construing the state Act, [the Court] may look for guidance to cases construing its federal counterpart.â€Â  In Garrett, the Court of Appeals recognized that both our Act and the Federal Act define the word â€œsecurityâ€ to include any â€œcertificate of interest or participation in any profit-sharing agreement, [or] investment contract.â€Â  The Court of Appeals cited the seminal United States Supreme Court case of Securities and Exchange Commission v. W.J. Howey Co., 328 U.S. 293, rehâ€™g denied, 329 U.S. 819 (1946) in which the Court defined an investment contract as a â€œtransaction or scheme whereby a person invests his money in a common enterprise and is led to expect profits solely from the efforts of the promoter or a third party.â€Â  Id. at 298-299.Â  
Under the Howey test, an investment contract exists where there has been (i) an investment of money, (ii) in a common enterprise, (iii) with an expectation of profits garnered solely from the efforts of others.Â  See Teague v. Bakker, 35 F.3d 978, 986 (4th Cir.1994). The test is a flexible one, â€œcapable of adaptation to meet the countless and variable schemes devised by those who seek the use of the money of others on the promise of profits.â€Â  Howey, 328 U.S. at 299.
We find the Commissioner and the circuit court properly found TLAâ€™s sale of TLCs constitutes the sale of an â€œinvestment contract,â€ such that under Â§ 35-1-20 (12), it constitutes a security and therefore TLA and Majors were properly ordered to cease and desist from the sale absent proper registration with the SEC Commission.Â  
a.Â  Investment of Money
An â€œinvestment of moneyâ€ under Howey means the investor must have committed his assets to the enterprise in such a manner as to subject himself to financial loss.Â  SEC v. Pinckney, 923 F. Supp. 76, 80 (E.D. NC 1996). 
It is indisputable that Principals meet this test.Â  They paid an up-front, non-refundable agency fee of 12-25 % of their TLC purchase price, they paid all fees and expenses associated with the purchase of the TLCs, as well as the expenses associated with establishing clear title to those properties which were not redeemed, and agreed to pay TLA 50% of the profits from the sale of any properties which were not redeemed.Â  It cannot seriously be argued that Principals here did not make an investment of money.Â  
TLA also asserts Principals were not subject to financial loss.Â  However, its contract specifically states that, â€œwhile there are no risks in owning government sold and issued TLCs that are redeemed (paid off), there are potential down side financial risks if a TLC matures into a property deed as the underlying property market value could substantially drop during the tax lien maturity period.â€Â  Accordingly, we find the first prong of Howey is met inasmuch as there is an â€œinvestment of money.â€
b.Â  Common Enterprise Test
TLA next contends the Commissioner, and the circuit court, erred in applying a â€œstrict vertical commonalityâ€ test to determine whether it is engaged in a common enterprise.Â Â  We disagree.
In order to meet the â€œcommon enterpriseâ€ prong of the Howey test, courts around the country have struggled with discerning whether vertical or horizontal commonality, or both, must exist. See Top of Iowa Cooperative v. Schewe, 6 F.Supp.2d 843, 852 (N.D. Iowa 1998) (noting that the Eighth Circuit had not ruled on whether either vertical or horizontal commonality or both are required under the â€œcommon enterpriseâ€ prong of Howey, such that the court examined the contracts for either kind of commonality); see also S.E.C. v. SG Ltd., 265 F.3d 42, 49 (1st Cir.2001) (citing and discussing the different standards in courts across the country); S.E.C. v. Pinckney, 923 F.Supp. 76, 81 (E.D.N.C. 1996) (same).Â  As a general guide, vertical commonality requires only a pooling of the interests of the developer or promoter and each individual investor, while â€œhorizontal commonalityâ€ requires as well a pooling of interests among the investors.Â  Schewe, 6 F.Supp.2d at 852 (citing Wals v. Fox Hills Development Corp., 24 F.3d 1016, 1017-18 (7th Cir. 1994)).Â  See also SEC v. Alpha Telcom, Inc., 187 F.Supp. 2d 1250 (9th Cir. 2002) (holding the second element of the Howey test can be satisfied by the existence of either vertical commonality or horizontal commonality. Vertical commonality is the dependence of the investorsâ€™ fortunes on the success or expertise of the promoter. Horizontal commonality is the pooling of investor funds and interests.Â  CitingBrodt v. Bache & Co., Inc., 595 F.2d 459, 460 (9th Cir. 1978).)
The courts have further identified two kinds of vertical commonality: broad vertical commonality and strict vertical commonality.Â  To establish â€œbroad vertical commonality,â€ the fortunes of the investors need be linked only to the efforts of the promoter.Â  See Long v. Shultz Cattle Co., Inc., 881 F.2d 129, 140-41 (5th Cir.1989). Â â€œStrict vertical commonalityâ€ requires the fortunes of investors be tied to the fortunes of the promoter.Â  Brodt v. Bache & Co. 
TLA asserts the only proper test is horizontal commonality which, by its nature, requires a pooling of interest among investors.Â  We disagree.
Initially, we note that many courts have applied an â€œeither/orâ€ test of vertical and horizontal commonality such that there is a common enterprise if either test is met.Â  See e.g. Integrated Research Svcs. v. Illinois Sec. of State, 765 N.E.2d 130 (Ill. 2002); SEC v. Parkersburg Wireless LLC, 991 F.Supp. 6 (D. Col. 1997); Securities and Exchange Commission v. R.G. Reynolds Enterprises, Inc., 952 F.2d 1125 (9th Cir.1991).
We find the newly revised Uniform Securities Act lend guidance to resolution of this issue.Â  The comments to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 35-1-102 (29)(D) state, in pertinent part: 

	The courts have divided over the interpretation of the â€œcommon enterpriseâ€" element of an investment contract. The courts generally recognize that â€œhorizontalâ€ commonality (for example, the pooling of an investment by two or more investors) is a common enterprise. A small minority of the federal circuits will also find a common enterprise in a â€œverticalâ€ relationship when a single investor is dependent upon the expertise of a single commodities broker. Since two or more persons do not share in the profitability of an undertaking, it is difficult to argue that there is a common enterprise. Section 102(29)(D) follows a significantly larger number of federal circuits and adopts a more restrictive form of vertical commonality that occurs only when there is profit sharing between two persons even if, for example, one is a conventional investor and one is a promoter. 
	See generally 2 Louis Loss & Joel Seligman, Securities Regulation 989-997 (3d ed. Rev. 1999).Â  In interpreting all elements of the investment contract, the courts have emphasized substance, not form.

Clearly, it appears the Legislature intends a strict vertical commonality test to apply.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court and Commissioner applied the proper test.
TLA and Majors also assert that, even under a strict vertical commonality test, the Commissioner erred in finding a common enterprise because the relationship here is precisely the opposite of that found in cases of strict vertical commonality.Â  It contends for such a relationship to exist, there must be a showing that the investorsâ€™ profits are dependent upon the promoterâ€™s profits whereas, here, TLAâ€™s profits are dependent upon the profits of the principals.Â  Â We disagree.
The court in SEC v. TLC Investments, 179 F.Supp. 2d 1149, 1156 (D. CA. 2001), specifically rejected such a claim, holding that â€œTLCâ€™s fortunes were inextricably linked to the fortunes of the individual investors.Â  So long as the promoterâ€™s gain is contingent on the investorâ€™s gain, there is a common enterprise.â€ 
c.Â  Efforts of others
Lastly, TLA asserts that because its Principals have input into purchasing and sales decisions, they do not have â€œan expectation of profits garnered solely from the efforts of others.â€Â  We disagree.
As noted by the Court of Appeals in Garrett, the third prong of Howey has been relaxed.Â  In Garrett, the Court of Appeals held:

	Later cases have eliminated the requirement that one must expect profits solely from the efforts of others in order for an interest to be a security. 
	See United Housing Foundation, Inc. v. Forman, 421 U.S. 837, 852, 
	rehâ€™g denied, 423 U.S. 884 (1975) (the touchstone is the presence of an investment in a common venture premised on a reasonable expectation of profits to be derived from the entrepreneurial or managerial efforts of others); 
	Oâ€™Quinn v. Beach Associates, 272 S.C. 95, 105, 249 S.E.2d 734, 739 (1978) (investment contracts may be found where the investor has duties that are nominal and insignificant or where the investor lacks any real control over the operation of the enterprise).Â  
	

The key determination is whether the promotersâ€™ efforts, not that of the investors, form the â€œessential managerial efforts which affect the failure or success of the enterprise. Â Unique Financial Concepts, 196 F.3d at 1201 (citing SEC v. Glenn W. Turner Enterprises, Inc., 474 F.2d 476, 482 (9th Cir.1973)).Â Â  See also SEC v. Rubera, 350 F.3d 1084 (9th Cir. 2003) (test is whether the efforts made by those other than the investor are the undeniably significant ones, those essential managerial efforts which affect the failure or success of the enterprise).
We find the test is met here.Â  As noted in the Commissionâ€™s order, although TLAâ€™s Principals retained some contractual rights of control, in practice their control was very limited.Â  TLA made all of the purchasing decisions, and exercised the majority of control in issues relative to clearing title, picking closing attorneys, etc., because the majority of its investors lived a considerable distance away.Â  As further noted in the Commissionerâ€™s order, TLAâ€™s marketing material indicated â€œwe do all the work.â€Â  
CONCLUSION
In summary, we hold the SEC Commissioner has authority to issue initial cease and desist orders prior to a hearing, so long as a hearing is thereafter afforded.Â  Further, we find the procedure utilized here did not violate TLAâ€™s due process rights, and that the final cease and desist order was properly issued because TLAâ€™s sale of tax lien certificates was properly found to be the sale of â€œsecuritiesâ€ within the meaning of the S.C. Uniform Securities Act.Â  Accordingly, the order on appeal is 
AFFIRMED.

TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  We note also that, effective Jan. 1, 2006, Chapter 1 of the South Carolina Uniform Securities Act was repealed and replaced with a new Chapter 1, to comport with the Uniform Securities Act promulgated by the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws.Â  Section 35-1-60 has been repealed.Â  In its place, Â§Â§ 35-1-603 and 35-1-604 now govern civil and administrative enforcement of the Act.Â  Section 35-1-603 permits the Commissioner to maintain a civil action in the court of common please.Â  Section 35-1-604 (Supp 2005) states, in pertinent part, as follows: 

	a) If the Securities Commissioner determines that a person has engaged, is engaging, or is about to engage in an act, practice, or course of business constituting a violation of this chapter or a rule adopted or order issued under this chapter or that a person has materially aided, is materially aiding, or is about to materially aid an act, practice, or course of business constituting a violation of this chapter or a rule adopted or order issued under this chapter, the Securities Commissioner may:Â  (1) issue an order directing the person to cease and desist from engaging in the act, practice, or course of business or to take other action necessary or appropriate to comply with this chapter. . . 
	

Clearly, the Commissioner has authority to issue cease and desist orders prior to commencement of a civil proceeding.Â  
[2]Â  However, we did find a violation of Section 22 where the university vice-president investigated the professorâ€™s case, testified as an adverse witness at a committee hearing, and sat as the intermediate judge in a three-step disciplinary procedure.Â  Id.Â

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				Vicki F. Chassereau, Respondent,
				v.
				Global-Sun Pools, Inc. and Ken Darwin, Petitioners.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF 
APPEALS

Appeal from Hampton County
Â Perry M. Buckner, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26318
Heard February 13, 2007 - Filed April 23, 2007Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Michael H. Montgomery and Frank S. Potts, both of Montgomery Patterson Potts & Willard, of Columbia, for Petitioners.
				John E. Parker and Lee D. Cope, both of Peters Murdaugh Parker Eltzroth & Detrick, of Hampton, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This case involves the interpretation of an arbitration agreement.Â  The trial court denied Petitionersâ€™ motion to compel arbitration of several claims Respondent asserted as a result of Petitionersâ€™ aggressive debt collection practices, and the court of appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  We granted certiorari, and we now affirm.

Factual/Procedural Background
In April 2003, Respondent Vicki Chassereau (â€œChassereauâ€) contracted with Petitioner Global Sun Pools (â€œGlobal-Sunâ€) to purchase an above ground pool.Â  Chassereau contends that sometime thereafter, the pool began malfunctioning or was otherwise in need of repair.Â  After Global-Sun allegedly refused to remedy the problems, Chassereau ceased making payments on the pool.
According to Chassereau, Petitioner Ken Darwin (â€œDarwinâ€), an employee of Global-Sun, began systematically harassing her as a result of her cessation of payments on the pool.Â  Specifically, Chassereau alleges that Darwin repeatedly phoned her at her workplace; disclosed private information to Chassereauâ€™s friends, relatives, and co-workers; and also made false and defamatory statements about Chassereau to these same people.Â  Ultimately, Chassereau sued Darwin and Global-Sun for defamation, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and a violation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-17-430 (2003) (defining the criminal offense of â€œunlawful communicationâ€).
Global-Sun and Darwin moved to compel arbitration of Chassereauâ€™s claims, arguing principally that two documents executed during the course of the sale of the pool required that these claims be arbitrated.[1]Â  The trial court disagreed and denied the motion to compel arbitration.Â  Global-Sun and Darwin appealed.
The court of appeals affirmed the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  Chassereau v. Global-Sun Pools, Inc., 363 S.C. 628, 611 S.E.2d 305 (2005).Â  In determining whether Chassereauâ€™s claims were required to be arbitrated, the court of appeals examined only the arbitration clause contained in the Installation Agreement.Â  Id. at 633 n.8, 611 S.E.2d at 307 n.8.Â  The court held that because the trial courtâ€™s order relied only on the arbitration clause in the Installation Agreement, any argument regarding the arbitration clause contained in the Financing Agreement was not preserved for review.Â  Id.Â  Ultimately, the court of appeals agreed with the trial courtâ€™s conclusion that Chassereauâ€™s claims were â€œbased upon tortious conduct of the employees of [Global-Sun Pools] unrelated to the contract,â€ and that the claims did not arise out of or relate to the contract.Â  Id. at 635, 611 S.E.2d at 308.Â  Accordingly, the court held that the arbitration clause in the Installation Agreement did not require that Chassereauâ€™s claims be arbitrated.Â  Id. 
Global-Sun and Darwin unsuccessfully petitioned the court of appeals to supplement the record on appeal with the Financing Agreement and to grant rehearing in the matter.Â  This Court granted certiorari to review the court of appealsâ€™ decision, and Global-Sun and Darwin present the following issue for review:

	Did the court of appeals err in determining that the Installation Agreementâ€™s arbitration clause did not apply to Chassereauâ€™s claims?


Standard of Review
Unless the parties provide otherwise, the question of the arbitrability of a claim is an issue for judicial determination. Â Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001).Â  The determination of whether a claim is subject to arbitration is subject to de novo review.Â  Wellman, Inc. v. Square D Co., 366 S.C. 61, 67, 620 S.E.2d 86, 89 (Ct. App. 2005); United States v. Bankers Ins. Co., 245 F.3d 315, 319 (4th Cir. 2001).Â Â  Nevertheless, a circuit courtâ€™s factual findings will not be reversed on appeal if any evidence reasonably supports the findings.Â  Thornton v. Trident Med. Ctr., L.L.C., 357 S.C. 91, 94, 592 S.E.2d 50, 51 (Ct. App. 2003). Â 

Law/Analysis
Global-Sun and Darwin argue that the court of appeals erred in determining that the Installation Agreementâ€™s arbitration clause did not apply to Chassereauâ€™s claims.Â  We disagree.
Both state and federal policy favor arbitration of disputes.Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 596, 553 S.E.2d at 118.Â  Unless a court can say with positive assurance that the arbitration clause is not susceptible to any interpretation that covers the dispute, arbitration should generally be ordered.Â  Id. at 597, 553 S.E.2d at 118-119.Â  However, arbitration is a matter of contract, and a party cannot be required to arbitrate any dispute which he has not agreed to arbitrate.Â  Id. at 596, 553 S.E.2d at 118.
The resolution of this case is controlled by our recent pronouncement in Aiken v. World Finance Corporation of South Carolina, Op. No. 26313 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed April 23, 2007).Â  In that case, we refused to interpret an arbitration agreement with similar, though not identical, language to apply to illegal or outrageous acts that no reasonable person would have foreseen at the time the parties executed the agreement to arbitrate. Â We instructed: 

	Because even the most broadly-worded arbitration agreements still have limits founded in general principles of contract law, this Court will refuse to interpret any arbitration agreement as applying to outrageous torts that are unforeseeable to a reasonable consumer in the context of normal business dealings.

Id.
From the beginning of her relationship with Global-Sun, Chassereau certainly knew that she would be required to make payments on the pool she purchased.Â  Â Furthermore, Chassereau must have expected that Global-Sun employees would contact her and request that she make payments on the pool if she ceased doing so.Â  However, we believe a reasonable person would not have foreseen and would not have expected (and ought not to expect) Global-Sun employees to commit acts historically associated with the common law tort of outrage in seeking to collect an overdue debt. Our opinion in Aiken unequivocally provides that although these types of uncivilized acts often arise in the course of performance of contracts containing arbitration clauses, South Carolina courts will not interpret arbitration clauses to apply to such acts which are outrageous and unforeseen.Â  
Although we are constrained to resolve all doubts in favor of arbitration, this is not an absolute truism intended to replace careful judicial analysis.Â  While actions taken in an arrangement such as the one entered into by these parties might have the potential to generate several legal claims and causes of action, we have no doubt that Chassereau did not intend to agree to arbitrate the claims she asserts in the instant case.Â  Accordingly, we hold that these claims are not covered by the arbitration agreement at issue in the instant case. [2]

Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm the court of appealsâ€™ decision.
MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  The majority does not explicitly find that the claims alleged by Mrs. Chassereau do not arise in any matter relating to her agreements with Global-Sun, yet nonetheless holds that the arbitration clause contained in the Installation Agreement does not require Mrs. Chassereauâ€™s claims to be arbitrated.Â  
We must decide whether Mrs. Chassereauâ€™s claims arise in any manner or are related to her agreement with Global-Sun.[3]Â  Because I would hold that these claims qualify on both counts, I would reverse the decision of the court of appeals.
In examining whether an arbitration agreement extends to a particular tort claim, South Carolina courts must focus on the factual allegations supporting the claim to determine whether the allegations implicate the contractual agreement, regardless of the legal label assigned to the claim.Â  See Am. Recovery Corp. v. Computerized Thermal Imaging, Inc., 96 F.3d 88, 93 (4th Cir. 1996); Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 597, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001).Â  We have held that a tort claim that does not arise under the governing contract is nevertheless required to be arbitrated if there is a â€œsignificant relationshipâ€ between the tort claim and the contract in which the arbitration clause is contained.Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 598, 553 S.E.2d at 119.Â  Nothing relates more significantly to a contract than efforts to collect amounts due thereunder.
Case law from other jurisdictions supports this conclusion.Â  In Green Tree Fin. Corp.Â  v. Shoemaker, 775 So.2d 149 (Ala. 2000), the purchasers of a mobile home sued the company which financed the purchase.Â  The purchasers claimed that after they became delinquent in their payments, the finance company began a systematic course of harassing them and invading their privacy.Â  Id. at 150.Â  Although the arbitration clause in Shoemaker was broader than the clause at issue in the instant case, the Alabama Supreme Court held:

	The plain language of this provision requires the plaintiffs to submit to arbitration all controversies that arise from, or relate to, the contract. That language clearly encompasses the plaintiffsâ€™ claim alleging invasion of privacy, a claim that arose out of the underlying business transaction of collecting delinquent monthly payments. 
	

Id. at 151.[4]
The case of In re Conseco Fin. Servicing Corp., 19 S.W.3d 562 (Tx. Ct. App. 2000), also arose out of a financed purchase of a mobile home.Â  Interpreting whether an arbitration clause identical to the clause at issue in Shoemaker applied to virtually identical claims, the court held: 

	[The complaint] arises from Consecoâ€™s alleged efforts to collect the amounts due under the terms of the agreement. Absent the contract, there would be no relationship between [the parties], and there would have been no debt collection . . . . Therefore, we conclude that [the plaintiffâ€™s] claims based on Consecoâ€™s acts in collecting the debt owed on the contract arise from or relate to the contract and so are within the scope of the arbitration clause.

Id. at 570.
I believe the reasoning of both Shoemaker and Conseco applies with equal force in the instant case.Â  In my view, it is difficult to imagine something more related to a debt agreement than actions taken to collect the debt.Â  Under any conceivable definition of the word â€œsignificant,â€ actions taken in seeking to collect a debt must be significantly related to the debt.
The rule the majority announces is troubling in several regards.Â  Primarily, the rule is inconsistent with the notion that all doubts regarding the question of arbitration are to be construed in favor of arbitration.Â  See Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 597, 553 S.E.2d at 118. Â Similarly, the rule runs afoul of the oft repeated notion that unless a court can say with positive assurance that the arbitration clause is not susceptible to any interpretation that covers the dispute, arbitration should generally be ordered.Â  See id.Â  Admittedly, these arbitration principles run counter to general notions of contract interpretation; namely, that a court will construe any doubts and ambiguities in an agreement against the drafter of the agreement.Â  See Myrtle Beach Lumber Co., Inc. v. Willoughby, 276 S.C. 3, 8, 274 S.E.2d 423, 426 (1981) (citing 17A C.J.S. Contracts Â§ 324).Â  In contrast to the majorityâ€™s rule, however, the principle that doubts are construed in favor of arbitration is rooted in a statutory proscription.Â  See Moses H. Cone Memâ€™l Hosp. v. Mercury Constr. Corp., 460 U.S. 1, 24 (1983) (stating that Â§ 2 of the Federal Arbitration Act, 9 U.S.C. Â§ 1, et seq., is a congressional declaration of a liberal federal policy favoring arbitration agreements, notwithstanding any state substantive or procedural policies to the contrary).
Mrs. Chassereauâ€™s claims unquestionably arise out of and are significantly related to the Installation Agreement.Â  Accordingly, I would reverse the decision of the Court of Appeals.Â 



[1] The parties refer to these documents as the â€œInstallation Agreementâ€ and the â€œRetail Installment Agreement.â€Â  For the sake of convenience, we will refer to the latter document as the â€œFinancing Agreement.â€
[2] On appeal, Global-Sun and Darwin also contend that the court of appeals erred in holding that any argument regarding the arbitration clause contained in the Financing Agreement was not preserved for review.Â  In light of the foregoing analysis, however, it is unnecessary for us to address this contention.Â  See Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (providing that an appellate court need not address additional issues if the resolution of another issue is dispositive).
[3] This limitation of our inquiry is based on the fact that the arbitration agreement at issue provides that â€œany disputes arising in any manner relating to this agreement . . . shall be subject to mandatory, exclusive and binding arbitration.â€ (emphasis added).
[4] The arbitration clause in Shoemaker purported to apply not only to all claims arising out of or relating to the agreement, but also to all claims between the parties.Â  Id. at 150.Â  This distinction is insignificant, however, because the court in Shoemaker rests its holding only on the relationships of the claims to the agreement.Â  See id. at 151.Â  Thus, Mrs. Chassereauâ€™s attempt to distinguish Shoemaker on this ground is unpersuasive.

title: State v. Childers
description: The Court affirmed the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision that the trial court did not err in denying Childersâ€™ request to relieve counsel.  Also, a majority of the court reversed the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision that the trial court erroneously denied Childersâ€™ request for a voluntary manslaughter charge.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				The State, Respondent/Petitioner,
				v.
				William Larry Childers, Jr., Petitioner/Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF 
APPEALS

Appeal From Kershaw County
Â J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26319Â Â  
Heard December 6, 2006 - Filed April 23, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody J. Brown, and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Respondent/Petitioner.
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner/Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  We granted both partiesâ€™ petitions for writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in State v. Childers, 358 S.C. 614, 595 S.E.2d 872 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On October 14, 2002, William Larry Childers visited his former live-in girlfriend (the victim) at her motherâ€™s home.[1]Â  According to the victimâ€™s sister, Childers became upset during the meeting because the victim would not leave the house to talk to him. Â Later that night, Childers saw the victim along with her sister and her sisterâ€™s ex-husband at a turkey shoot and a confrontation ensued. Â 
About 3:00 a.m. on October 15, the victimâ€™s brother returned to his motherâ€™s home and after hearing footsteps in a wooded area near the home, he determined Childers was prowling around the area.Â  The brother immediately called 911, but the police were unable to locate Childers when they arrived.Â  The brother testified he was awakened approximately thirty minutes later by the sound of gunshots in the front yard and when he went outside, he saw â€œChilders go across the yard.â€
According to the victimâ€™s sister, she along with her ex-husband and the victim were standing in the victimâ€™s motherâ€™s yard talking after the turkey shoot when Childers suddenly appeared in the yard and shot the victim twice, at close range, in the head.Â  The victimâ€™s sister said she immediately ran toward the house and Childers fired two more shots at her.Â  The victimâ€™s former brother-in-law testified he attempted to warn the victim and his ex-wife that Childers was approaching them, but Childers shot the victim in the back of the head before he could do so.Â  Â 
According to Childers, he went to a friendâ€™s home, which was close to the victimâ€™s motherâ€™s home, after the turkey shoot.Â  Childers testified he then decided to walk to the victimâ€™s motherâ€™s home to talk to the victim.Â  He testified he carried a loaded gun with him to protect himself from stray dogs during the walk, and as he approached the group standing in the yard, he had the gun in his coat pocket.Â  Childers stated the victimâ€™s former brother-in-law shot at him first.Â  He returned fire, and in doing so, he shot the victim.Â  Childers also testified he did not visit the victim that night with the intention of shooting anyone, but he fired because he was fired upon.
After the jury had been selected, Childers requested the trial judge relieve his defense counsel, but the trial court denied this request.Â  At the end of trial, defense counsel requested a jury charge on voluntary manslaughter.Â  The trial judge refused to charge voluntary manslaughter, but charged murder, involuntary manslaughter, and self-defense.Â  Childers was convicted of murder, assault of a high and aggravated nature,[2] and discharging a firearm into a dwelling.Â  He received a life sentence for murder and concurrent terms of ten yearsâ€™ imprisonment for each of the remaining two convictions.Â  
Childers appealed his convictions.Â  The Court of Appeals upheld the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to relieve defense counsel.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed and remanded Childersâ€™ murder conviction after finding the trial judge erred in failing to give a jury charge on voluntary manslaughter.Â  Childers, 358 S.C. at 614-21, 595 S.E.2d at 872-76.Â Â Â  
CHILDERSâ€™ ISSUE

	Did the Court of Appeals err in finding the trial judge did not abuse hisdiscretion by denying Childersâ€™ request to relieve defense counsel?

LAW/ANALYSIS
Childers argues his defense counsel should have been relieved because defense counsel, while employed as an assistant solicitor, had previously prosecuted him on an unrelated charge.[3]Â  We disagree.
A motion to relieve counsel is addressed to the discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Gregory, 364 S.C. 150, 152, 612 S.E.2d 449, 450 (2005); State v. Graddick, 345 S.C. 383, 385, 548 S.E.2d 210, 211 (2001).Â  The movant bears the burden to show satisfactory cause for removal.Â  Gregory, 364 S.C. at 152, 612 S.E.2d at 450; Graddick, 345 S.C. at 386, 548 S.E.2d at 211.Â  
Childers asked the trial judge to relieve defense counsel based on defense counselâ€™s prior prosecution of him and his perceived lack of defense counselâ€™s trial preparation.Â  Defense counsel told the trial judge he was ready and prepared to go to trial and he had no independent recollection of prosecuting Childers.Â  Childers failed to show his counsel had any divided loyalties or an actual conflict of interest.Â  See Gregory, 364 S.C. at 152, 612 S.E.2d at 450 (â€œAn actual conflict of interest occurs where an attorney owes a duty to a party whose interests are adverse to the defendantâ€™s.â€); see also People v. Abar, 736 N.Y.S.2d 155 (N.Y. App. Div. 2002) (finding there was no conflict of interest where defendantâ€™s public defender had previously prosecuted him on unrelated charges when she was employed as an assistant district attorney); State v. Cobbs, 584 N.W.2d 709 (Wis. Ct. App. 1998) (concluding there was no actual or serious potential conflict where defendantâ€™s counsel had previously prosecuted defendant while working in the district attorneyâ€™s office).Â  The Court of Appeals correctly found the trial judge did not abuse his discretion by denying Childersâ€™ request to relieve counsel.Â  Â 
THE STATEâ€™S ISSUE

	Did the Court of Appeals err in finding the trial judge improperly denied Childersâ€™ request for a voluntary manslaughter charge?

LAW/ANALYSIS
The State argues Childers was not entitled to a voluntary manslaughter charge given the facts of this case.Â  We agree.
Voluntary manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human being in the sudden heat of passion upon a sufficient legal provocation.Â  State v. Kornahrens, 290 S.C. 281, 285-86, 350 S.E.2d 180, 184 (1986).Â  â€œThe sudden heat of passion, upon sufficient legal provocation, which mitigates a felonious killing to manslaughter, while it need not dethrone reason entirely, or shut out knowledge and volition, must be such as would naturally disturb the sway of reason, and render the mind of an ordinary person incapable of cool reflection, and produce what, according to human experience, may be called an uncontrollable impulse to do violence.â€Â  State v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 322, 474 S.E.2d 430, 432 (1996) (internal quotations omitted).Â  Both heat of passion and sufficient legal provocation must be present at the time of the killing to constitute voluntary manslaughter.Â  State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 451, 529 S.E.2d 721, 727 (2000).Â  
The law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.Â  State v. Cole, 338 S.C. 97, 101, 525 S.E.2d 511, 512 (2000).Â  In determining whether the evidence requires a charge on voluntary manslaughter, this Court must view the facts in the light most favorable to the defendant.Â  Id. at 101, 525 S.E.2d at 512-13.Â  To warrant a courtâ€™s eliminating the offense of manslaughter, it should very clearly appear that there is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce the crime from murder to manslaughter.Â  Id.
The Court of Appeals determined the evidence showed that Childers only fired his gun after being fired upon by the victimâ€™s former brother-in-law.Â  The Court of Appeals found, although the victim did not provoke Childers, the provocation by her ex-brother-in-law could be transferred to the victim under the doctrine of transferred intent.Â  Based on this analysis, the Court of Appeals concluded Childers was entitled to a voluntary manslaughter charge.Â  Childers, 358 S.C. at 621, 595 S.E.2d at 876.
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Childers, this factual scenario is completely void of any evidence supporting a charge of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Childers testified he was provoked by the victimâ€™s former brother-in-law and he fired his gun in response to being first shot at by the ex-brother-in-law.Â  Childersâ€™ testimony does not support the contention that the killing was in the sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation by the victim because, contrary to the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision, the overt act that produces the sudden heat of passion must be made by the victim.Â  See State v. Lowry, 315 S.C. 396, 399, 434 S.E.2d 272, 274 (1993) (â€œ[W]hen death is caused by the use of a deadly weapon, the opprobrious words must be accompanied by the appearance of an assault-by some overt, threatening act-which could have produced the heat of passion.â€); State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 363, 535 S.E.2d 420, 425 (the defendant was not entitled to a voluntary manslaughter charge because the â€œovert act was made by a third party, not the deceased, and South Carolina has not recognized sufficient legal provocation from a third party that can be transferred to the victim.â€); State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 171, 478 S.E.2d 260, 269 (1996) (â€œThe provocation must come from some act of or related to the victim in order to constitute sufficient legal provocation.â€). Â Because there is no evidence whatsoever tending to reduce the crime from murder to voluntary manslaughter, the Court of Appeals erred in finding the trial judge erroneously failed to give a voluntary manslaughter charge.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we uphold Childersâ€™ convictions.
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
WALLER, J., concurs.Â  TOAL, C.J., concurring in result only in a separate opinion.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which MOORE, J., concurs.
Chief Justice Toal: I concur in the result reached by the majority, but I write separately because I would resolve the case on different grounds.Â  Like the majority, I believe the court of appeals incorrectly determined that the evidence presented at trial entitled the defendant to a voluntary manslaughter charge.Â  In my view, however, the concept of transferred intent has little relevance to the outcome of the instant case.
As this Courtâ€™s precedent provides, voluntary manslaughter is the unlawful killing of a human being in a sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation.Â  State v. Walker, 324 S.C. 257, 260, 478 S.E.2d 280, 281 (1996).Â  Voluntary manslaughter mitigates an otherwise felonious killing to manslaughter, and while the elements of passion and provocation need not be of such a degree so as to dethrone reason entirely, or shut out knowledge and volition, they must â€œbe such as would naturally disturb the sway of reason, and render the mind of an ordinary person incapable of cool reflection, and produce what, according to human experience, may be called an uncontrollable impulse to do violence.â€Â  Id. (citing State v. Byrd, 323 S.C. 319, 474 S.E.2d 430 (1996)).Â  When determining whether a defendant is entitled to a voluntary manslaughter charge, the court must view the facts in the defendantâ€™s favor.Â  Byrd, 323 S.C. at 321, 474 S.E.2d at 431.
The defendantâ€™s own narrative is instructive.Â  According to the defendant, the events leading up to the fatal shooting began with a minor altercation early in the evening between the defendant, his live-in girlfriend (from whom he was separated seven days earlier), and his girlfriendâ€™s ex-brother-in-law.Â  The defendant testified that he left the scene of the altercation, visited several other destinations, and eventually decided to attempt to reconcile with his girlfriend at her motherâ€™s house at approximately 3:30 in the morning.Â  The defendant believed it prudent to leave his car nearly two miles away from the house and approach the house from the rear, and as he approached the house, the defendant testified that he observed his girlfriend, his girlfriendâ€™s sister, and the sisterâ€™s ex-husband outside the home.Â  The defendant alleges that as he approached the trio, the sisterâ€™s ex-husband fired a weapon at him.Â  According to the defendant, he used his own gun to return fire, and then retreated from the property while firing multiple times over his shoulder.
This factual scenario is completely void of any evidence remotely supporting a charge of voluntary manslaughter.Â  Voluntary manslaughter, by definition, requires a criminal intent to do harm to another.Â  But according to the defendantâ€™s story, he had no criminal intent whatsoever.
If, as he suggests, the defendant returned fire in a panic for his life, surely the defense of self-defense would be appropriate.Â  Notably, this was charged by the trial court.Â  Similarly, the trial court charged the jury on the law of involuntary manslaughter; perhaps because it was possible for the jury to believe that the defendantâ€™s initial returning of fire was justified, but ultimately find that the defendant was criminally reckless in firing multiple times over his shoulder as he retreated.Â  Without any evidence supporting the view that the defendant fired the fatal shots while under an â€œuncontrollable impulse to do violence,â€ the trial court properly declined to charge the law of voluntary manslaughter to the jury.[4]
In support of their holding that the defendant was entitled to a voluntary manslaughter charge, the court of appeals relied on this Courtâ€™s holding in State v. Penland, 275 S.C. 537, 540, 273 S.E.2d 765, 766 (1981).Â  As the court of appeals noted, that case arguably stands for the proposition that a jury issue on the voluntary manslaughter element of heat of passion can be created in a case similar to the instant case.Â  
Â Penland cannot be so broad.Â  Read literally, the opinion seems to impermissibly blend the concept of voluntary manslaughter with the defense of self-defense.Â  The opinion provides no substantial factual background for the case, and no description of the events leading up to the apparently fatal incident.Â  To the extent Penland stands for the proposition that a person who simply defends himself while in fear for his life is entitled to a voluntary manslaughter charge, the case should be overruled.Â  
For the foregoing reasons, I would reverse the court of appealsâ€™ decision and reinstate the defendantâ€™s murder conviction.Â  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree that there was no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Childersâ€™ motion to relieve his trial counsel, and therefore join that part of the majorityâ€™s opinion.Â  I respectfully dissent, however, from that part of the decision which reverses the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding that the trial judge committed reversible error in denying Childersâ€™ request for a voluntary manslaughter charge.
The majority reverses the voluntary manslaughter holding, finding the Court of Appeals misapplied the doctrine of transferred intent.Â  Aside from the fact that this issue is not before the Court,[5] as explained below, this case represents a classic claim of transferred intent.
â€œCriminal liability is normally based upon the concurrence of two factors, â€˜an evil meaning mind [and an] evil doing hand.â€™â€Â  United States v. Bailey, 444 U.S. 394, 402 (1980).Â  Thus, in a homicide case, the law is concerned with the killerâ€™s state of mind, not with the identity of the victim.Â  State v. Fennell, 340 S.C. 266, 531 S.E.2d 512 (2000).Â  As the Fennell court explained, â€œ[A] defendant may be found guilty of murder or manslaughter in a case of bad or mistaken aim under the doctrine of transferred intent.Â  In the classic case, the defendant intends to kill or seriously injure one person, but misses that person and mistakenly kills another.â€Â  Id. at 272, 531 S.E.2d at 515.Â  
Thus, the critical question was Childersâ€™ mental state at the time he shot.Â  If there is evidence that he fired in the sudden heat of passion upon sufficient legal provocation, it matters not that his aim was poor.Â  State v. Fennell, supra. Here, Childers testified that his sudden heat of passion was aroused when the victimâ€™s former brother-in-law shot at him, and that in returning the fire, he mistakenly shot the victim.Â Â  The majority misapplies the doctrine in order to find no voluntary manslaughter charge was warranted. Â See also e.g. State v. Gandy, 283 S.C. 571, 324 S.E.2d 65 (1984) overruled on other grounds Casey v. State, 305 S.C. 445, 409 S.E.2d 391 (1991); State v. McElveen, 280 S.C. 325, 313 S.E.2d 298 (1984). [6]Â  

	The sole issue before the Court on the Stateâ€™s certiorari is 
	
		Whether the Court of Appeals erred by finding the trial judge incorrectly denied Childersâ€™ request for a voluntary manslaughter charge when the record shows there is no evidence of heat of passion?[7]
	

The Stateâ€™s argument rests on its contention that Childers did not present evidence that he was â€œinflamed by passionâ€ when he returned the brother-in-lawâ€™s fire.Â  I disagree, and would hold that the jury could have found the â€œheat of passionâ€ in Childersâ€™ testimony that he fired back because he was scared and feared he would be shot at again.
For these reasons, I would affirm the decision of the Court of Appeals.
MOORE, J., concurs.


[1]  For a more complete recitation of the facts, see State v. Childers, 358 S.C. 614, 595 S.E.2d 872 (Ct. App. 2004).
[2]  The Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion incorrectly referred to this conviction as assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature.Â  Childers, 358 S.C. at 615, 618, 621, 595 S.E.2d at 873-74, 876.Â  
[3]  Childers also argues the trial judge erred in denying his request to relieve counsel because counsel had previously represented the victimâ€™s brother.Â  This issue is not preserved for review because it was not raised at trial.Â  See State v. Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 216, 499 S.E.2d 209, 214 (1998) (to be preserved for appeal, an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge).
[4]  Tellingly, the fatal shots consisted of two gunshot wounds to the victimâ€™s head.Â  At trial, the Stateâ€™s medical expert testified that powder marks around both wounds suggested that the shots were administered at a close range.Â  Though the implications of this evidence contradict the defendantâ€™s account of the events, we must believe the defendant when determining jury charges.
[5] The State did not challenge the Court of Appeals transferred intent holding on rehearing and consequently could not, and did not, seek certiorari to review that ruling.Â  An unchallenged ruling by the Court of Appeals, even if erroneous, is the law of the case on certiorari.Â  E.g., State v. Barroso, 328 S.C. 268, 493 S.E.2d 854 (1997).
[6]  The majority relies on a case where the legal provocation of â€œAâ€ was used by the defendant to justify his intentional shooting of â€œB,â€ State v. Locklair, 341 S.C. 352, 535 S.E.2d 420 (2000), and one where there was simply no legal provocation.Â  State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996).Â  In contrast, here the State has conceded legal provocation.
[7]  â€œStateâ€™s Brief of Petitionerâ€ at page 2.

title: RWE NUKEM Corporation v. ENSR Corporation
description: The Court reversed the circuit courtâ€™s grant of partial summary judgment and remanded for further proceedings.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        RWE NUKEM Corporation, f/k/a WasteChem Corporation, Respondent,
        v.
        ENSR Corporation, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26320
Â Heard April 5, 2007 - Filed April 30, 2007

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Jeffrey S. Patterson, Karl S. Bowers, Jr., and A. Mattison Bogan, all of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, L.L.P., of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Robert E. Stepp, Amy L.B. Hill, and Roland M. Franklin, Jr., all of Sowell Gray Stepp & Laffitte, L.L.C., of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  ENSR Corporation (Appellant) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of partial summary judgment in favor of RWE NUKEM Corporation, f/k/a WasteChem Corporation (Respondent).Â  We certified the appeal from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and we reverse and remand.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
In the early 1990s, Appellant and Respondent were subsidiaries of American NuKEM Corporation (American NuKEM).Â  In 1995, American NuKEM sold its shares in Respondent to its parent company, RWE NUKEM GmbH.[1]Â  This sale was memorialized in a Stock Purchase Agreement (Stock Agreement), which was signed by representatives of American NuKEM, RWE NUKEM GmbH, Appellant, and Respondent.Â  
As part of the sale, RWE NUKEM GmbH had the option of requiring American NuKEM to direct Appellant to enter into an agreement with Respondent to continue to provide administrative and management services.Â  Although the Administrative and Management Services Agreement (Administrative Agreement), which was attached to the Stock Agreement, was not separately executed by any party, Appellant continued to perform administrative and management services for Respondent following the sale.Â  Between 1995 and 1999, Respondent paid Appellant approximately $1.4 million for its administrative and management services.Â  In July 1999, the relationship between Respondent and Appellant began phasing out and was completely phased out on or about December 31, 1999. 
In September 1999 and in February 2000, Respondent requested that Appellant return all of its documents in Appellantâ€™s possession.Â  In March 2000, Appellant notified Respondent that some of the records were missing and some were commingled with Appellantâ€™s records.Â  Appellant also indicated it was experiencing difficulty in shipping the records in a timely manner.Â  Also in March, Appellant notified Respondent that certain documents were being gathered and would be produced shortly thereafter, but the commingled documents would be produced on an as needed basis due to the prohibitive time and cost.Â  Respondent repeatedly requested documents from Appellant, and Appellant continually provided Respondent with documents, but Appellant also repeatedly reiterated its position that it would not disaggregate the commingled documents because of the unreasonable cost and time.Â  On January 17, 2003, Respondent again demanded that Appellant produce all of its documents and threatened legal action if the demand was not met by March 31, 2003.Â  On January 28, 2003, Appellant notified Respondent that it would make one final attempt to locate the missing documents, but if Respondent was not satisfied by March 31, 2003, Respondent should take whatever action it deemed appropriate.
Respondent filed this action on September 29, 2003, alleging a breach of contract based on Appellantâ€™s failure to provide it with all of its records.Â  Appellant answered and asserted Respondentâ€™s claim was barred by the statute of limitations, laches, release, waiver, estoppel, and the statute of frauds.Â  On cross-motions for summary judgment, the circuit court denied Appellantâ€™s motion for summary judgment.Â  The circuit court also denied in part Respondentâ€™s motion for partial summary judgment as to the existence of a contract; a breach, if any, of the alleged contract; and the validity of the defenses of release, estoppel, and waiver.Â  The circuit court granted in part Respondentâ€™s motion for partial summary judgment finding the statute of limitations, laches, and the statute of frauds were not valid defenses in this case. 
ISSUES

  I.   Did the circuit court err in granting partial summary judgment in favor of Respondent based on the statute of limitations?
  II.  Did the circuit court err in granting partial summary judgment in favor of Respondent based on laches?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
The circuit court may properly grant a motion for summary judgment when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the circuit court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences that may be drawn from the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Manning v. Quinn, 294 S.C. 383, 385, 365 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988).Â  â€œ[I]n considering cross motions, the court should draw all inferences against each movant in turn.â€Â  73 Am. Jur. 2d Summary Judgment Â§ 43 (2001).Â  On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below.Â  Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 7, 550 S.E.2d 319, 321 (2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Statute of Limitations
Appellant argues the circuit court erred in granting Respondentâ€™s motion for partial summary judgment as to Appellantâ€™s statute of limitations defense.Â  We agree.
The circuit court determined the alleged breach, if any, did not occur until March 2003 when Appellant refused to deliver the remaining records within its possession to Respondent.Â  The circuit court held, in the alternative, Appellantâ€™s letter dated January 28, 2003, acted as a waiver to any statute of limitations defense prior to March 2003.Â  The circuit court also found the discovery rule did not apply, but even if it did, Appellant would be estopped from claiming the statute of limitations as a defense because of its numerous attempts to comply with Respondentâ€™s requests.
A.Â  Date of Breach
Both parties agree the applicable statute of limitations in this action is set forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(1) (2005).Â  An action for breach of contract must be brought within three years from the date it accrues.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-3-530(1).Â  Under the discovery rule, a breach of contract action accrues on the date the injured party either discovered the breach or should have discovered the breach through the exercise of reasonable diligence.Â  State v. McClinton, 369 S.C. 167, 173, 631 S.E.2d 895, 898 (2006) (breach of contract action generally accrues at the time the contract is breached); Santee Portland Cement Co. v. Daniel Intâ€™l Corp., 299 S.C. 269, 271, 384 S.E.2d 693, 694 (1989) (discovery rule applies in contract actions), overruled on other grounds by Atlas Food Sys. & Servs., Inc. v. Crane Natâ€™l Vendors Div. of Unidynamics Corp., 319 S.C. 556, 462 S.E.2d 858 (1995); see also Maher v. Tietex Corp., 331 S.C. 371, 377, 500 S.E.2d 204, 207 (Ct. App. 1998) (applying the discovery rule to a breach of contract action).
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Appellant, on March 24, 2000 and on June 23, 2000, Appellant advised Respondent that it would not produce all of Respondentâ€™s documents because some of the documents were commingled with Appellantâ€™s documents and disaggregating them would be too costly and time consuming.Â  On August 21, 2000, Respondent issued a â€œfinal demandâ€ to Appellant.Â  On September 14, 2000, Appellant notified Respondent that it did not consider the Administrative Agreement to be a binding contract, but Appellant would continue to supply specific documents if Respondent needed them to respond to a third-partyâ€™s request for information.Â  On February 22, 2002, Appellant notified Respondent that the latest document review should conclude the ongoing matter and Appellant would supply additional documents only upon Respondentâ€™s specific request.Â  In response to a letter written by Respondent on January 17, 2003, Appellant agreed on January 28, 2003, to look for the missing documents and Appellant advised Respondent to take whatever action it deemed necessary if Respondent was not satisfied by March 31, 2003.Â  In light of this series of events and Appellantâ€™s repeated unwillingness to disaggregate the commingled documents and provide Respondent with a copy of them, there is a genuine issue of material fact as to when Respondent discovered or should have discovered the breach, if any, through the exercise of reasonable diligence.
B.Â  Waiver
A party can waive a statute of limitations defense.Â  McLendon v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Hwys. & Pub. Transp., 313 S.C. 525, 525-26, 443 S.E.2d 539, 540 (1994).Â  â€œâ€˜Waiver of [the statute of] limitations may be shown by words or conduct.Â  Thus, waiver may result from express agreement, . . . from failure to claim the defense, or by any action or inaction manifestly inconsistent with an intention to insist on the statute.â€™â€Â  Mende v. Conway Hosp., Inc., 304 S.C. 313, 315, 404 S.E.2d 33, 34 (1991) (citing 54 C.J.S. Limitation of Actions Â§ 22 (1987)).Â  Waiver is a question of fact for the finder of fact.Â  Parker v. Parker, 313 S.C. 482, 487, 443 S.E.2d 388, 391 (1994). Â 
Respondent specifically argues Appellantâ€™s email dated February 22, 2002, is evidence of Appellantâ€™s waiver of the statute of limitations.Â  On February 22, Appellant notified Respondent it would ship â€œfour boxes of records which represent our final installment of documents.â€Â  However, Appellant also advised that certain invoices were commingled with its documents and Appellant refused to send those documents to Respondent, except by Respondentâ€™s request for specific documents.Â  Viewing this in the light most favorable to Appellant, this email does not indicate Appellant waived the statute of limitations as a matter of law, but rather indicates there is a factual question regarding waiver.
Moreover, the issue is whether Appellantâ€™s willingness to continue to locate documents was an action manifestly inconsistent with an intention to insist upon the statute of limitations.Â  Even though Appellant provided Respondent with a steady flow of documents, Appellant continually notified Respondent that it would not provide all of Respondentâ€™s documents and it would produce the commingled documents on an as needed basis only.Â  Appellant complied with Respondentâ€™s request on a conditional basis until March 2003, and, this conditional response creates a genuine issue of material fact as to whether Appellant waived the statute of limitations.
C.Â  Estoppel
â€œ[A] defendant may be estopped from claiming the statute of limitations as a defense if the delay that otherwise would give operation to the statute had been induced by the defendantâ€™s conduct.â€Â  Black v. Lexington Sch. Dist. No. 2, 327 S.C. 55, 61, 488 S.E.2d 327, 330 (1997) (quotations omitted).Â  The inducement may consist of an express representation that the claim will be settled without litigation or conduct that suggests a lawsuit is not necessary.Â  Id.Â  Although the issue of whether a defendant is estopped from claiming the statute of limitations is ordinarily a question of fact to be determined by the judge, summary judgment is appropriate where there is no evidence of conduct on the defendantâ€™s part warranting estoppel.Â  Id. at 61, 62 n.1, 488 S.E.2d at 330, 331 n.1.
Even though Appellant cooperated with Respondentâ€™s requests for documents for several years, Appellant also repeatedly objected to disaggregating the commingled documents due to the unreasonable time and cost involved in the task and advised Respondent that it would produce the commingled documents only upon Respondentâ€™s request for specific documents.Â  Due to this conditional cooperation by Appellant, a factual question exists regarding whether Appellant induced the delay it now asserts as a defense to Respondentâ€™s claim. 
II.Â  Laches
Appellant argues the circuit court erred in dismissing its laches defense.Â  We agree.
Under the doctrine of laches, if a party, knowing his rights, does not seasonably assert them, but by unreasonable delay causes his adversary to incur expenses or enter into obligations or otherwise detrimentally change his position, then equity will ordinarily refuse to enforce those rights.Â  Chambers of South Carolina, Inc. v. County Council for Lee County, 315 S.C. 418, 421, 434 S.E.2d 279, 280 (1993).Â  Laches connotes not only an undue lapse of time, but also negligence and opportunity to have acted sooner.Â  Id. at 421, 434 at 281.Â  The party seeking to establish laches must show (1) delay, (2) unreasonable delay, and (3) prejudice.Â  Hallums v. Hallums, 296 S.C. 195, 199, 371 S.E.2d 525, 528 (1988).
The circuit court denied summary judgment as to whether a contract existed and if so, whether the contract had been breached.Â  Because the date of the breach, if any, is unknown, there are factual questions as to whether there was a delay, whether the delay was unreasonable, and whether the delay, if any, prejudiced Appellant.Â  Even if laches is implicated in this case, summary judgment was improperly granted on Appellantâ€™s laches defense given these factual questions. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing analysis, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s grant of partial summary judgment and remand for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.Â  We need not address Appellantâ€™s remaining issue.Â  See Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
