description: The issue on appeal is whether it is within the Department of Revenueâ€™s authority to impose an administrative sanction for the unlawful transfer of alcohol to a minor, without the necessity of the minor being prosecuted.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Elephant, Inc., Appellant,
        v.
        South Carolina Department of Revenue, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville CountyÂ 
Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26321
Heard April 4, 2007 - Filed April 30, 2007Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Randall Scott Hiller, of Greenville, for Appellant.
        Harry A. Hancock, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  This is an appeal from an order of the circuit court, which affirmed the ruling of the Administrative Law Court (ALC), and held that Elephant, Inc., violated S.C. Code Ann. Reg. Â§ 7-200.4, in transferring alcohol to an under-aged confidential informant (CI).[1]Â  Elephant appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Elephant owns Platinum Plus, a bar in Greenville, SC.Â  On January 21, 2005, South Carolina Law Enforcement (SLED) agents sent an undercover, nineteen-year old confidential informant (CI) into Platinum Plus.Â  Employees of the bar checked the CIâ€™s driverâ€™s license at the door and noted that he was under twenty-one years of age.Â  They confiscated the CIâ€™s driverâ€™s license, put wristbands on his wrists, and stamped large Xâ€™s on the back of his hands. The CI then walked to the bar, ordered, paid for, and was served a Coorâ€™s Light beer.Â  Upon observing this, a Platinum Plus employee immediately walked over to the CI and attempted to confiscate the beer.Â  However, the employee was stopped by SLED agents, and the bartender was arrested for serving alcohol to the minor CI.Â  An administrative citation was issued to Elephant, Inc. for violation of Reg. 7-200.4.Â  
The bartender was subsequently charged with transferring beer to a minor under the age of twenty-one and was found not guilty.Â  Elephant, Inc. was issued a $1000.00 fine by the Department of Revenue.Â  On appeal, the ALC reduced the fine to $100.00, finding the fine excessive in light of Elephantâ€™s corporate policy attempting to prevent the sale or possession of alcohol by minors.Â  Elephant appeals, contending it is not subject to â€œprosecutionâ€ because the minor CI was never prosecuted for under-age possession.Â  
DISCUSSION
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-4-10 et seq. sets forth general provisions governing beer, ale, porter and wine.Â  Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-4-50:

  It is unlawful for a person to sell beer to a person under twenty one years of age.Â  A person who makes a sale in violation of this section must, upon conviction, be fined not less than one hundred dollars nor more than two hundred dollars or imprisoned not less than thirty days nor more than sixty days, or both, in the discretion of the court.Â  

(Emphasis supplied).Â  Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-4-90:

  It is unlawful for a person to transfer or give to a person under the age of twenty one years for the purpose of consumption beer or wine at any place in the State. A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, must be fined not more than two hundred dollars or imprisoned not more than thirty days.

(Emphasis supplied).Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-4-100 provides, in pertinent part:

  If a person is charged with a violation of Section 61-4-50 (the unlawful sale of beer or wine to minors), the minor must also be charged with a violation of Section 20-7-8920 (unlawful purchase or possession of beer or wine). . . . 
  Unless the provisions of this section are complied with, no person charged with a violation of Section 61-4-50 may be convicted of the offense.Â  

(Emphasis supplied).Â  
Elephant argues that because the under-aged CI was not prosecuted, it cannot be prosecuted either criminally or administratively.Â  We disagree.Â  Section 61-4-100 requires only that if a person is charged with a violation of Â§ 61-4-50 (the unlawful sale of beer or wine to minors), the minor must also be charged with a violation of Section 20-7-8920 (unlawful purchase or possession of beer or wine).Â  Noticeably, Â§ 61-4-100 does not require that when a person is charged with the transfer of beer or wine to a minor (under Â§ 61-4-90), that the minor must also be charged with charged with a violation.Â  There is a legitimate basis for the distinction between the two offenses.Â  The sale of beer to minors in violation of Â§ 61-4-50 is punishable by up to sixty days imprisonment, thereby making it a general sessions offense, whereas a violation of Â§ 61-4-90 carries a maximum thirty day sentence, so as to be a magistrateâ€™s court offense.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-3-330 (Magistrates have jurisdiction over offenses with fines up to five hundred dollars, or imprisonment not exceeding thirty days, or both).Â Â Â  
Further, Elephant was not prosecuted under the above statues but was administratively sanctioned pursuant to S.C. Code Reg. 7-200.4,[2] which provides:

  To permit or knowingly allow a person under twenty-one year of age to purchase or possess or consume alcoholic liquors, beer or wine in or on a licensed place of business which holds a license or permit issued by the Department is prohibited and constitutes a violation against the license or permit. Such violation shall be sufficient cause to suspend or revoke the license or permit by the Department.
  Â  For a violation of any regulation pertaining to beer or wine, the department may impose a monetary penalty of up to one-thousand dollars upon the holder of a beer or wine license in lieu of suspension or revocation.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-4-250.

Elephantâ€™s contention is meritless.Â  Although it is correct that it may not be prosecuted for the sale of alcohol under Â§ 61-4-50 unless the minor is also prosecuted, it cites no authority for the proposition that it may not be administratively sanctioned for violation of a regulation.Â  Administrative sanctions simply are not equivalent to a criminal prosecution.Â  See e.g., State v. Price, 333 S.C. 267, 510 S.E.2d 215 (1998) (administrative suspension of driverâ€™s license does not constitute a criminal penalty); State v. Blick, 325 S.C. 636, 481 S.E.2d 452 (Ct. App. 1997) (adoption and execution of policies and practices necessary to preserve internal order and discipline, and to maintain institutional security in the prison are within the province and expertise of correctional officials and do not bar subsequent criminal prosecution).Â  We find it is within the Department of Revenueâ€™s authority to impose an administrative sanction for the unlawful transfer of alcohol to a minor, without the necessity of the minor being prosecuted.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  S.C. Code Reg. 7-200.4, concerning the possession of alcoholic beverages by minors under 21 years old, makes the following a violation of the ownerâ€™s beverage license:

  To permit or knowingly allow a person under twenty-one year of age to purchase or possess or consume alcoholic liquors, beer or wine in or on a licensed place of business which holds a license or permit issued by the Department is prohibited and constitutes a violation against the license or permit. Such violation shall be sufficient cause to suspend or revoke the license or permit by the Department. 

[2] Â Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 61-2-60, the South Carolina Department of Revenue has the authority to promulgate regulations necessary to carry out the duties imposed upon them by law for the proper administration and enforcement of laws pertaining to the distribution of alcohol.Â

description: The Court affirms the trial courtâ€™s decision granting summary judgment to Respondents based on a lack of product exposure pursuant to the Door Closing Statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-150, and finds no error in the trial courtâ€™s exclusion of certain evidence as cumulative.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        James W. Henderson, Jr., and Betty Lee Henderson, Appellants,
        v.
        Allied Signal, Inc. (Successor to The Bendix Corp.), Aqua-Chem, Inc., (d/b/a Cleaver-Brooks Division), Certain-Teed Corporation, Combustion Engineering, Inc., Daimler Chrysler, Ford Motor Company, Freightliner, General Motors Corporation, International Truck & Engine Corporation (formerly Navistar International Transportation), Kenworth (Paccar), Inc., North American Refractories Company, Peterbilt (Paccar), Inc., Pneumo Abex (Successor to Abex Corp. and American Brake Shoe Company), Rayloc Company, T&N, Ltd., Uniroyal Holding, Inc. (Successor to U.S. Rubber Co.), Of whom Allied Signal, Inc., Daimler Chrysler, Ford Motor Company, General Motors Corporation, North American Refractories Company, Uniroyal Holding, Inc., are, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville CountyÂ 
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26322
Heard March 6, 2007 - Filed April 30, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Mona Lisa Wallace, of Wallace and Graham, P.A., of Salisbury, NC, for Appellants.
        C. Mitchell Brown and W. Thomas Causby, of Nelson, Mullins, Riley, & Scarborough, LLP, of Columbia; James H. Elliott, Jr., of Pritchard & Elliot, LLC, of Charleston; W. David Conner, James B. Pressley, Jr., and Moffatt G. McDonald, all of Haynsworth, Sinkler, Boyd, P.A., of Greenville; Daniel B. White, of Gallivan, White & Boyd, P.A., of Greenville; and G. Mark Phillips, of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT: James W. Henderson, Jr., and his wife, Betty Lee, (collectively referred to as Appellants) appeal the order of the trial court granting summary judgment to Allied Signal, Inc., Daimler Chrysler, Ford Motor Company, General Motors Corporation, North American Refractories Company, Pneumo Abex, and Uniroyal Holding, Inc. (Respondents).Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Appellants, North Carolina residents, filed a complaint in 1997 arising out of Mr. Hendersonâ€™s exposure to asbestos containing products while working as a boilermaker, pipefitter, and sheet metal worker for many years at various industrial sites in South Carolina.Â  Mrs. Hendersonâ€™s claims arose out of her loss of consortium and enjoyment of life.Â  According to the complaint, Respondents â€œmined, manufactured, processed, imported, converted, compounded and/or retailed substantial amounts of asbestos and asbestos-related materialsâ€ and caused such materials to be placed in the stream of interstate commerce with the result that the materials were sold, distributed and used in South Carolina.Â  Appellants alleged Mr. Henderson â€œused, worked with, was in the vicinity of, and was exposed to asbestos and asbestos containing productsâ€ during the course of his employment and, as a result, contracted mesothelioma and other asbestos-related illnesses.Â  Mr. Henderson was diagnosed in North Carolina.Â  
In a 2001 order, the trial court excluded certain affidavits presented by Appellants for their failure to comply with Rule 33, SCRCP, and dismissed the following defendants from the case pursuant to the Door Closing Statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-150 (2005), and Rule 12(b)(1), SCRCP: AC&S, Certain-Teed Corporation, Carlisle Corporation, Qualco Products, North American Refractories, Uniroyal, Pnuemo Abex, Kelsey-Hayes, Freightliner, Peterbilt (Paccar), Kenworth (Paccar), International Truck and Engine (formerly Navistar), Daimler Chrysler, General Motors, Ford, Combustion Engineering, Aqua-Chem, and Bird[1].Â  The trial court found no evidence to support the allegation that Mr. Henderson was exposed to asbestos containing products in South Carolina.Â  
The trial court granted defendants Rayloc and Covil summary judgment on product identification grounds, finding no evidence their products contained asbestos.Â  The trial court also denied the motions of Allied Signal and McCord Corporation, finding genuine issues of material fact existed as to Mr. Hendersonâ€™s exposure to their asbestos containing products in South Carolina.Â  The trial court denied Appellantsâ€™ motions for reconsideration.Â Â Â  
The case went to trial against Allied, McCord, and Dana with McCord and Dana settling during trial.Â  The jury found for Allied, and Appellants appealed.[2]Â  We certified this case for review from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  Â Â Â Â 
ISSUES

  I.  Did the trial court err in granting summary judgment based on product exposure?
  II.  Did the trial court err in limiting the scope of Appellantsâ€™ evidence solely to mesothelioma?Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Â Osborne v. Adams, 346 S.C. 4, 550 S.E.2d 319 (2001).Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can reasonably be drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 492 S.E.2d 55 (1997). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Product Exposure
Appellants argue: (1) the trial court erred in granting summary judgment on product exposure to Uniroyal, Ford, General Motors, Chrysler, Abex, and Rayloc; and (2) a jury question exists as to exposure in relation to Kenworth, Freightliner, Paccar, and International Truck.Â  We disagree.Â  

  The Door Closing Statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-5-150, provides:
  An action against a corporation created by or under the laws of any other state, government or country may be brought in the circuit court:
  (1)   By any resident of this State for any cause of action; or
  (2)   By a plaintiff not a resident of this State when the cause of action shall have arisen or the subject of the action shall be situated within this State.Â  

At trial, the Respondents argued Mr. Henderson had no exposure within South Carolina to their asbestos containing products and the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction based on the Door Closing Statute and Rule 12(b)(1), SCRCP.Â  Noting Mr. Henderson was admittedly not a resident of South Carolina, the trial court focused on whether the cause of action arose in South Carolina, relying on Murphy v. Owens-Corning Fiberglass Corp., 346 S.C. 37, 550 S.E.2d 589 (Ct. App. 2001), overruled on other grounds by Farmer v. Monsanto Corp., 353 S.C. 553, 579 S.E.2d 325 (2003) (â€œBecause Â§ 15-5-150 does not involve subject matter jurisdiction but rather determines the capacity of a party to sue, we overrule these cases to the extent they hold otherwise.â€).Â  
In Murphy, the Court of Appeals held: â€œIn applying the Door Closing Statute, the manifestation of injury through diagnosis, while relevant, is not dispositive in every case for the purpose of determining whether a cause of action shall have arisen in South Carolina.â€Â  Murphy, 346 S.C. at 48, 550 S.E.2d at 594-95.Â  Finding the exposure to asbestos originated in South Carolina, the Court of Appeals held plaintiffâ€™s claims arose in this State â€œeven though they did not accrue until the mesothelioma was diagnosed.â€Â  Id. at 48, 550 S.E.2d at 594.Â  The Court of Appeals, therefore, found the Door Closing Statute did not bar plaintiffâ€™s claims because there was a sufficient connection to South Carolina when the acts which gave rise to the cause of action occurred in this State.Â  Id. at 48, 550 S.E.2d at 595.Â  Following the trial courtâ€™s order in this case, this Court affirmed Murphy and held: â€œ[T]he proper inquiry is whether the foreign corporationâ€™s activities that allegedly exposed the victim to the injurious substance, and the exposure itself, occurred within the State.Â  If so, then the legal wrong was committed here.â€Â  356 S.C. 592, 598, 590 S.E.2d 479, 482 (2003).Â  
Appellants failed to meet the Murphy test because they failed to show Respondentsâ€™ products contained asbestos, and they failed to show any actionable exposure in South Carolina.Â  In determining whether exposure is actionable, we adopt the â€œfrequency, regularity, and proximity testâ€ set forth in Lohrmann v. Pittsburgh Corning Corp., 782 F.2d 1156, 1162 (4th Cir. 1986): Â â€œTo support a reasonable inference of substantial causation from circumstantial evidence, there must be evidence of exposure to a specific product on a regular basis over some extended period of time in proximity to where the plaintiff actually worked.â€Â  
We agree with the trial court that â€œpresence in the vicinity of static asbestos is not exposure to asbestos,â€ and find Appellants failed to present evidence of regular and frequent exposure to asbestos containing products in proximity to where Mr. Henderson worked.Â  Due to the lack of evidence Mr. Henderson was exposed to the Respondentsâ€™ asbestos containing products in South Carolina, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s holding.
II.Â  Limited Evidence
Appellants argue the trial court unduly limited their evidence to mesothelioma.Â  We disagree.
Appellantsâ€™ claim against Allied arises out of Mr. Hendersonâ€™s experience working with brake products manufactured by Allied and his diagnosis of mesothelioma.Â  Appellants argue the trial court erred in excluding certain evidence concerning other asbestos-related diseases and limiting evidence to cases, reports, and studies showing a link between asbestos exposure and mesothelioma.Â  
The trial court correctly excluded evidence concerning other asebestos-related diseases because such evidence was merely cumulative of evidence actually allowed.Â  See, e.g., Commerce Center of Greenville, Inc. v. W. Powers McElveen & Assocs., Inc., 347 S.C. 545, 559, 556 S.E.2d 718, 726 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œGenerally, there is no abuse of discretion where the excluded testimony is merely cumulative of other evidence proffered to the jury.â€)Â  Appellants were given the opportunity to present evidence concerning asbestos and Mr. Hendersonâ€™s asbestos-related illness.Â  Because the factual issues of the case were fully aired, the exclusion of cumulative reports and studies did not prejudice Appellants.Â  Furthermore, such evidence was arguably irrelevant under Rule 403, SCRE.Â  See, e.g., State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 378, 580 S.E.2d 785, 794 (Ct. App. 2003) (â€œA trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding the comparative probative value and prejudicial effect of evidence should be reversed only in exceptional circumstances.Â  We review a trial courtâ€™s decision regarding Rule 403 pursuant to the abuse of discretion standard and are obligated to give great deference to the trial courtâ€™s judgment.â€)Â  (internal citations omitted).
CONCLUSION
Applying both Murphy and Lohrman, we find Appellants failed to prove actionable exposure to Respondentsâ€™ asbestos-containing products.Â  We affirm the decision of the trial court granting summary judgment to Respondents based on the Door Closing statute.Â  We also affirm the decision of the trial court excluding certain affidavits as cumulative.
AFFIRMED.Â  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, and PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Edward B. Cottingham, concur.

[1] During the course of litigation, numerous defendants filed for bankruptcy and, therefore, are not parties to this action.Â  Also, Pnuemo-Abex reached a settlement agreement with Appellants prior to oral arguments before this Court.Â  
[2]Â  Mr. Henderson died shortly after trial, and Ms. Henderson, as personal representative of his estate, proceeded with this appeal.
